human_translation: is taught another who sets aside his field as designated repayment to a creditor or for a woman’s marriage contract, collects from other property Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A creditor collects from other property, a woman does not collect from other property. Since it is not the way of a woman to go to court,
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: The one who makes his field collateral for a creditor and for his wife's marriage contract - they collect from the rest of his assets. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A creditor has priority over the rest of the assets, but a wife does not have priority over the rest of the assets - because it is not the way of a woman to go back to the courts.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁחֶצְיוֹ עֶבֶד וְחֶצְיוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין – עוֹבֵד אֶת רַבּוֹ יוֹם אֶחָד, וְאֶת עַצְמוֹ יוֹם אֶחָד; דִּבְרֵי בֵּית הִלֵּל. בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: תִּקַּנְתֶּם אֶת רַבּוֹ, וְאֶת עַצְמוֹ לֹא תִּקַּנְתֶּם – לִישָּׂא שִׁפְחָה אִי אֶפְשָׁר, שֶׁכְּבָר חֶצְיוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין;
human_translation: one who is a half-slave half-freeman he serves his master one day and himself one day; the statement of Beit Hillel. Beit Shammai say: you have remedied his master, you have not remedied himself, It is not possible to marry a maidservant he is already a half-freeman,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One whose half is a slave and half is free – he works for his master one day, and for himself one day; these are the words of Beit Hillel. Beit Shammai say: You have benefited his master, but you have not benefited himself – to marry a maidservant is impossible, for he is already half free.

hebrew_text: בַּת חוֹרִין אִי אֶפְשָׁר, שֶׁכְּבָר חֶצְיוֹ עֶבֶד. יִבָּטֵל? וַהֲלֹא לֹא נִבְרָא הָעוֹלָם אֶלָּא לִפְרִיָּה וּרְבִיָּה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא תוֹהוּ בְרָאָהּ לָשֶׁבֶת יְצָרָהּ״! אֶלָּא מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הָעוֹלָם – כּוֹפִין אֶת רַבּוֹ וְעוֹשֶׂה אוֹתוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין, וְכוֹתֵב שְׁטָר עַל חֲצִי דָמָיו. וְחָזְרוּ בֵּית הִלֵּל לְהוֹרוֹת כְּדִבְרֵי בֵּית שַׁמַּאי.
human_translation: It is not possible a free woman, as he is still a half-slave. he should be idle but isn’t it the world was created only for procreation, as it is stated: “He did not create it to be a waste; He formed it to be inhabited” Rather, for the betterment of the world his master is forced to make him a freeman, and writes note half his value And Beit Hillel retracted to rule in accordance with the statement of Beit Shammai,
llm_translation: Daughter of freedom, if not possible, because already half slave. Will she be annulled? Wasn't the world created only for procreation, as it says: "He did not create it a waste, He formed it to be inhabited"? Rather, for the betterment of the world - they compel his master and make him a free man, and write a document for half of his value. And the House of Hillel retracted to teach in accordance with the words of the House of Shammai.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַמְשַׁחְרֵר חֲצִי עַבְדּוֹ, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: קָנָה, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: לֹא קָנָה.
human_translation: The Sages taught: who emancipates half of his slave, Rabbi says: He acquired and the Rabbis say: He not acquired
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One who frees half of his slave, Rabbi says: he acquires, and the Rabbis say: he does not acquire.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: מַחְלוֹקֶת בִּשְׁטָר – דְּרַבִּי סָבַר: ״וְהׇפְדֵּה לֹא נִפְדָּתָה אוֹ חוּפְשָׁה לֹא נִתַּן לָהּ״ –
human_translation: Rabba said: dispute with a bill as Rabbi holds: “And not at all redeemed, nor was freedom given to her”
llm_translation: Rabba said: The dispute in the document - for Rabbi holds: "And if she was not redeemed, or freedom was not given to her" -

hebrew_text: מַקִּישׁ שְׁטָר לְכֶסֶף, מָה כֶּסֶף – בֵּין כּוּלּוֹ בֵּין חֶצְיוֹ, אַף שְׁטָר נָמֵי – בֵּין כּוּלּוֹ בֵּין חֶצְיוֹ;
human_translation: juxtaposes a bill to money, just as money either all of him or half of him, so too, a bill either all of him or half of him
llm_translation: The document is compared to money, what is money - whether in its entirety or half, so too a valid document - whether in its entirety or half.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן גָּמְרִי ״לָהּ״–״לָהּ״ מֵאִשָּׁה – מָה אִשָּׁה חֶצְיָהּ לֹא, אַף עֶבֶד נָמֵי חֶצְיוֹ לֹא; אֲבָל בְּכֶסֶף – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל קָנָה, פְּדוּיָה וְאֵינָהּ פְּדוּיָה.
human_translation: And the Rabbis derive from “her [ lah ]” “her [ lah ]” a woman: Just as a woman, not half of her so too, a slave, not half of him However, with regard to money, everyone agrees that acquires redeemed but not redeemed.
llm_translation: The sages said: "For her" - "For her" from a woman - just as a woman's half is not considered her property, so too a slave's half is not considered his property; but with money - everyone agrees that he acquires it, whether redeemed or not redeemed.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי – דְּמָר סָבַר: הֶקֵּישָׁא עֲדִיף, וּמָר סָבַר: גְּזֵרָה שָׁוָה עֲדִיפָא?
human_translation: Let us say that they disagree about this: As Sage, holds a juxtaposition is preferable, And Sage, holds a verbal analogy is preferable
llm_translation: Let us say in this case where they disagree - for Mar holds: the analogy is preferable, and for Mar holds: the similar decree is preferable?

hebrew_text: לָא; דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא גְּזֵירָה שָׁוָה עֲדִיפָא, וְשָׁאנֵי הָכָא דְּאִיכָּא לְמִיפְרַךְ: מָה לְאִשָּׁה שֶׁכֵּן אֵינָהּ יוֹצְאָה בְּכֶסֶף, תֹּאמַר בְּעֶבֶד שֶׁיּוֹצֵא בְּכֶסֶף.
human_translation: No, everyone agrees a verbal analogy is preferable, but it is different here because can be refuted What about a woman cannot leave via money shall you say to a slave, who does leave via money?
llm_translation: Not; for all the world, a decree is equal, preferable, and different here, where there is room to distinguish: Just as for a woman, so too she does not go out with money, you may say for a slave who goes out with money.

hebrew_text: וְרַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר: מַחְלוֹקֶת בְּכֶסֶף – דְּרַבִּי סָבַר: ״וְהׇפְדֵּה לֹא נִפְדָּתָה״ – פְּדוּיָה וְאֵינָהּ פְּדוּיָה; וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: דִּבְּרָה תּוֹרָה כִּלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם; אֲבָל בִּשְׁטָר – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל לֹא קָנָה.
human_translation: And Rav Yosef said: dispute via money, for Rabbi holds: “And not at all redeemed [ vehofde lo nifdata ]” redeemed but not redeemed. And the Rabbis hold: The Torah spoke in the language of people, However, via a bill everyone agrees that not acquired
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: A dispute regarding money - for Rabbi holds: "And she has not been redeemed" - redeemed and not redeemed; and the Rabbis hold: The Torah spoke in the language of people; but in a document - everyone agrees he did not acquire.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הַמְשַׁחְרֵר חֲצִי עַבְדּוֹ בִּשְׁטָר, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: קָנָה, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: לֹא קָנָה. תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּרַב יוֹסֵף! תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: raises an objection one who emancipates half his slave with a bill Rabbi says: He acquired and the Rabbis say: He has not acquired The refutation of Rav Yosef is a conclusive refutation.
llm_translation: Challenger: one who frees half his slave with a document. Rabbi says: he acquired, and the Sages say: he did not acquire. A refutation of Rav Yosef! A refutation.

hebrew_text: (נֵימָא) בִּשְׁטָר הוּא דִּפְלִיגִי, אֲבָל בְּכֶסֶף לָא פְּלִיגִי; לֵימָא תֶּיהְוֵי תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּרַב יוֹסֵף בְּתַרְתֵּי!
human_translation: they disagree via a bill However, they do not disagree with money. Shall we say this is a conclusive refutation of Rav Yosef with regard to two
llm_translation: (נֵימָא) In a document they disputed, but not in money; let it be the preference of Rav Yosef in two!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ רַב יוֹסֵף: פְּלִיגִי בִּשְׁטָר, וְהוּא הַדִּין בְּכֶסֶף. וְהָא דְּקָא מִיפַּלְגִי בִּשְׁטָר – לְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כֹּחוֹ דְּרַבִּי.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said to you: disagree with regard to via a bill and the same is true, with money. And this, that they disagree with regard to via a bill to convey to you the far-reaching of Rabbi
llm_translation: He said to you, Rav Yosef: Distinguish in a document, and it is the same ruling with money. And that which he distinguishes in a document - to inform you of the strength of Rabbi.

hebrew_text: וְלִיפְלְגֻי בְּכֶסֶף, וּלְהוֹדִיעֲךָ כֹּחָן דְּרַבָּנַן! כֹּחַ דְּהֶיתֵּירָא עֲדִיף לֵיהּ.
human_translation: And let them disagree with money, and to convey to you the far-reaching nature of the Rabbis, preferable to the power of leniency,
llm_translation: And to divide with money, and to make known to you the power of the Rabbis! The power of the majority is superior to him.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״וְהׇפְדֵּה״; יָכוֹל לַכֹּל? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לֹא נִפְדָּתָה״. אִי ״לֹא נִפְדָּתָה״, יָכוֹל לַכֹּל? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהׇפְדֵּה״. הָא כֵּיצַד? פְּדוּיָה וְאֵינָהּ פְּדוּיָה; בְּכֶסֶף וּבְשָׁוֶה כֶּסֶף.
human_translation: Come hear “and redeemed,” might entirely the verse states “not redeemed.” If “not redeemed,” might an entirely the verse states “and redeemed.” How these redeemed but not redeemed. via money or an equivalent money.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Come and hear: 'And he shall redeem'; can it apply to everyone? The verse teaches: 'She was not redeemed.' If 'she was not redeemed,' can it apply to everyone? The verse teaches: 'And he shall redeem.' How so? She is redeemed and she is not redeemed; with money and with an object of equal value."

hebrew_text: וְאֵין לִי אֶלָּא בְּכֶסֶף, בִּשְׁטָר מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהׇפְדֵּה לֹא נִפְדָּתָה אוֹ חוּפְשָׁה לֹא נִתַּן לָהּ״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וְכָתַב לָהּ סֵפֶר כְּרִיתוּת״ – מָה לְהַלָּן בִּשְׁטָר, אַף כָּאן בִּשְׁטָר.
human_translation: And I have only via money. From where via a bill The verse states: “And not at all redeemed, nor was freedom given to her” and later on, it states: “And he writes her a scroll of severance” Just as later on via a bill so too here, via a bill
llm_translation: "And I have nothing but with money, with a document from where? The Talmud teaches: 'And if she was not redeemed, or freedom was not given to her,' and elsewhere it says: 'And he shall write her a bill of divorce' - just as there it is with a document, so too here with a document."

hebrew_text: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא חֶצְיוֹ בְּכֶסֶף, אוֹ כּוּלּוֹ בִּשְׁטָר; חֶצְיוֹ בִּשְׁטָר מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהׇפְדֵּה לֹא נִפְדָּתָה אוֹ חוּפְשָׁה לֹא נִתַּן לָהּ״ – מַקִּישׁ שְׁטָר לְכֶסֶף, מָה כֶּסֶף בֵּין כּוּלּוֹ בֵּין חֶצְיוֹ, אַף שְׁטָר נָמֵי בֵּין כּוּלּוֹ בֵּין חֶצְיוֹ.
human_translation: I have only half of via money, or all of him via a bill From where half of him via a bill The verse states: “And not at all redeemed, nor was freedom given her,” juxtaposes a bill to money. Just as either fully or money, so too, he be either fully or a bill
llm_translation: I have only half in silver, or all in a promissory note; from where do we derive that half in a promissory note? The Talmud teaches: "And if she was not redeemed, or freedom was not granted to her" - comparing a promissory note to silver, just as with silver, whether all or half, so too with a promissory note, whether all or half.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַב יוֹסֵף בָּתַר דְּאִיתּוֹתַב, הָא מַנִּי – רַבִּי הִיא. אֶלָּא לְרַבָּה – רֵישָׁא דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל, וְסֵיפָא רַבִּי?!
human_translation: Granted, according to Rav Yosef after he was conclusively refuted, whose is this It is Rabbi However, according to Rabba, all agree the first clause, but the last clause Rabbi
llm_translation: In truth, to Rav Yosef after he sat down, this is a question - is it Rabbi? Rather, to Rabbah - the beginning is the words of everyone, and the end is Rabbi?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רַבָּה: אִין, רֵישָׁא דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל, וְסֵיפָא רַבִּי. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: רַבִּי הִיא.
human_translation: Rabba said to you: Yes, all agree the first clause, and the last clause Rabbi Rav Ashi said: is Rabbi
llm_translation: Rabba said to you: No, the beginning of the words of everyone, and the end is Rabbi. Rav Ashi said: It is Rabbi.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מַתְנִיתִין דְּקָתָנֵי: מִי שֶׁחֶצְיוֹ עֶבֶד וְחֶצְיוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין; בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבָּה – מוֹקֵים לַהּ בְּכֶסֶף, וְדִבְרֵי הַכֹּל; אֶלָּא לְרַב יוֹסֵף – לֵימָא רַבִּי הִיא וְלָא רַבָּנַן?! אָמַר רָבִינָא:
human_translation: But the mishna that teaches: one who is a half-slave half-freeman, granted, according to Rabba, he establishes with money, and everyone agrees However, according to Rav Yosef, shall we say is Rabbi and not the Rabbis? Ravina said:
llm_translation: Rather, the Mishnah teaches: If one's half is a slave and half is a free man; according to Rabba - they are redeemed with money, and this is the view of all. But according to Rav Yosef - should we say it is Rabbi's opinion and not the Rabbis'?! Rabinah said:

hebrew_text: בְּעֶבֶד שֶׁל שְׁנֵי שׁוּתָּפִין, וְדִבְרֵי הַכֹּל.
human_translation: to a slave belonging to two partners, and everyone agrees
llm_translation: In a slave of two partners, and the words of all.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה: מַחֲלוֹקֶת – בְּשֶׁשִּׁיחְרֵר חֶצְיוֹ וְהִנִּיחַ חֶצְיוֹ; אֲבָל שִׁיחְרֵר חֶצְיוֹ, וּמָכַר חֶצְיוֹ אוֹ נָתַן בְּמַתָּנָה חֶצְיוֹ, כֵּיוָן דְּקָנָפֵיק מִינֵּיהּ כּוּלֵּיהּ – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל קָנָה.
human_translation: Rabba said: dispute when freed half of him and left half of him However, freed half of him and sold half of him, or gave half of him as a gift since left him entirely, everyone agrees acquired
llm_translation: Rabba said: A dispute - when he freed half of it and left half of it; but if he freed half of it, and sold half of it or gave half of it as a gift, once he has separated from it entirely - everyone agrees he has acquired it.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וּבְכוּלּוֹ – לָא פְּלִיגִי?! וְהָתָנֵי חֲדָא: הַכּוֹתֵב נְכָסָיו לִשְׁנֵי עֲבָדָיו – קָנוּ וּמְשַׁחְרְרִין זֶה אֶת זֶה. וְתַנְיָא אִידַּךְ, הָאוֹמֵר: ״כׇּל נְכָסַי נְתוּנִין לִפְלוֹנִי וּפְלוֹנִי עֲבָדַיי״ – אַף עַצְמָם לֹא קָנוּ.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: And do they not disagree with regard to he entirely? But is taught one one who writes his property to his two slaves, they acquired and they free each other, And it was taught another one who says: All of my property is given to so-and-so and so-and-so my slaves, they did not acquire even themselves,
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: And in all of it - do they not disagree?! And it was taught: One who writes his possessions to his two slaves - they acquire and emancipate each other. And it was taught elsewhere: One who says, "All my possessions are given to so-and-so and so-and-so my slaves" - they themselves do not acquire.

hebrew_text: מַאי, לָאו הָא רַבִּי, וְהָא רַבָּנַן?!
human_translation: What, is it not this, Rabbi And that, the Rabbis,
llm_translation: What, is it not this Rabbi, and these Rabbis?!

hebrew_text: לָא, אִידִי וְאִידִי רַבָּנַן; הָא דְּאָמַר כּוּלּוֹ, הָא דְּאָמַר חֲצִי חֲצִי.
human_translation: No, this and that the Rabbis. This where one said all of That where one said half half
llm_translation: Not so, both this and that are the words of the sages; this one who said all of it, and that one who said half and half.

hebrew_text: וְהָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: וְאִם אָמַר חֲצִי חֲצִי – לֹא קָנוּ, מִכְּלָל דְּרֵישָׁא דְּאָמַר כּוּלּוֹ! פָּרוֹשֵׁי קָא מְפָרֵשׁ – אַף עַצְמָן לֹא קָנוּ, כֵּיצַד? כְּגוֹן דְּאָמַר חֲצִי חֲצִי.
human_translation: But from that the latter clause teaches: But if he said half half they did not acquire it may be inferred that the first clause where he said all of is explaining They did not acquire even themselves. How so? For example, where said half half
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And this is what was taught in the latter part: And if he said half-half - they did not acquire. From the inference of the first part that said in its entirety! The commentators are explaining - they themselves also did not acquire, how so? For example, if he said half-half.

hebrew_text: הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ רֵישָׁא דְּאָמַר כּוּלּוֹ – הַשְׁתָּא אָמַר כּוּלּוֹ לֹא קָנוּ, אָמַר חֲצִי חֲצִי מִיבַּעְיָא?!
human_translation: So too, it is reasonable for if it enters your mind the first clause where he said all of Now one said all of did not acquire is necessary half half
llm_translation: So it was thought, for if it entered your mind that he said the entire thing at the beginning - now he says the entire thing was not acquired, does he require half and half?!

hebrew_text: אִי מִשּׁוּם הָא לָא אִירְיָא – תְּנָא סֵיפָא לְגַלּוֹיֵי רֵישָׁא, שֶׁלֹּא תֹּאמַר: רֵישָׁא דְּאָמַר חֲצִי חֲצִי, אֲבָל אָמַר כּוּלּוֹ קָנוּ; תְּנָא סֵיפָא דְּאָמַר חֲצִי חֲצִי, מִכְּלָל דְּרֵישָׁא דְּאָמַר כּוּלּוֹ – וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי לֹא קָנוּ.
human_translation: If it is due to that there is no argument. taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause, so that you do not say: The first clause where one said half half but one said all of it they did acquire taught the latter clause, where he said half half by inference that the first clause where he said all of it and even so they did not acquire
llm_translation: If not because of this, it would not be called "Irya" - a Tanna teaches the latter part to reveal the beginning, so you will not say: the beginning that said half and half, but he said they acquired the entire thing; a Tanna teaches the latter part that said half and half, from the general principle of the beginning that said they acquired the entire thing - and even so, they did not acquire.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא, לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן בִּשְׁטָר אֶחָד, כָּאן בִּשְׁנֵי שְׁטָרוֹת.
human_translation: And if you wish, say not difficult. Here, in one document. There, in two documents.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say, it is not difficult: here in one document, here in two documents.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁטָר אֶחָד, מַאי אִירְיָא חֲצִי חֲצִי? אֲפִילּוּ אָמַר כּוּלּוֹ נָמֵי לֹא קָנוּ! הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: אַף עַצְמָן לֹא קָנוּ, בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים – בִּשְׁטָר אֶחָד, אֲבָל בִּשְׁנֵי שְׁטָרוֹת – קָנוּ; וְאִם אָמַר חֲצִי חֲצִי – אַף בִּשְׁנֵי שְׁטָרוֹת נָמֵי לָא קָנוּ.
human_translation: in one document, why specifically half half Even if he said all of it as well, they did not acquire That is also what is saying: They did not acquire even themselves. In what this statement said? in one document. But in two documents, they acquired And if said half half even in two documents they also did not acquire
llm_translation: In one document, what is the meaning of "half and half"? Even if he said all of it is not acquired! This is what he means to say: Even they themselves did not acquire, in what case are these matters said - in one document, but in two documents - they acquired; and if he said "half and half" - even in two documents they did not acquire.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא – כָּאן בְּבַת אַחַת, כָּאן בְּזֶה אַחַר זֶה.
human_translation: And if you wish, say not difficult, Here, simultaneously. There, sequentially.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: It is not difficult - here in one place, here in another after it.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא בָּתְרָא לָא קָנֵי, דְּהָא קָנֵי לֵיהּ קַמָּא; אֶלָּא קַמָּא, לִיקְנֵי נַפְשֵׁיהּ וְלִקְנְיֵיהּ לְחַבְרֵיהּ! אֶלָּא מְחַוַּורְתָּא כִּדְשַׁנִּינַן מֵעִיקָּרָא.
human_translation: Granted, the last did not acquire, for the first had already acquired him, However, the first should acquire himself and should acquire the other Rather, it is clear as we initially answered,
llm_translation: In truth, he did not acquire the latter, for he acquired the former; rather, he should acquire the former, to acquire for himself and acquire for his companions! Rather, the conclusion is as we initially stated.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּקָא קָרֵי לְהוּ ״עֲבָדַיי״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַפְרָם לְרַב אָשֵׁי: וְדִלְמָא ״עֲבָדַיי״ – שֶׁהָיוּ כְּבָר!
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: it is different there, because calls them: My slaves. Rafram said to Rav Ashi: But perhaps My slaves, who were in the past.
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: It is different there, because it is called to them "my servants." Refram said to Rav Ashi: And perhaps "my servants" - they were already!

hebrew_text: מִי לָא תְּנַן: הַכּוֹתֵב כׇּל נְכָסָיו לְעַבְדּוֹ – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת; שִׁיֵּיר קַרְקַע כָּל שֶׁהוּא – לֹא יָצָא לְחֵירוּת. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: לְעוֹלָם הוּא בֶּן חוֹרִין, עַד שֶׁיֹּאמַר: ״כׇּל נְכָסַי נְתוּנִין לִפְלוֹנִי עַבְדִּי, חוּץ מֵאֶחָד מֵרִבּוֹא שֶׁבָּהֶן״.
human_translation: Didn’t we learn one who writes all of his property to his slave, has been emancipated. he reserved any amount of land, he has not been emancipated. Rabbi Shimon says: Actually, is a freeman until says All of my property is given to so-and-so my slave except for one ten-thousandth of it,
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: One who writes all his possessions to his slave - he goes out to freedom; if he leaves any amount of land - he does not go out to freedom. Rabbi Shimon says: He is always considered a free man, until he says, "All my possessions are given to so-and-so my slave, except for one of the many that I have."

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דְּאָמַר [״חוּץ מֵאֶחָד מֵרִבּוֹא שֶׁבָּהֶן״], הָא לָא אָמַר הָכִי – קָנֵי; אַמַּאי? וְהָא ״עֶבֶד״ קָא קָרֵי לֵיהּ! אֶלָּא ״עַבְדִּי״ שֶׁהָיָה כְּבָר, הָכָא נָמֵי ״עֲבָדַיי״ שֶׁהָיוּ כְּבָר.
human_translation: The reason because said: Except for one ten-thousandth of it. But he did not say this, acquires why Didn’t he call him a slave? Rather, My slave, that was in the past. Here also, My slaves, who were in the past.
llm_translation: Reason of saying "except for one of them", this not said thus - acquires; why? And this "servant" is called to him! Rather "my servant" that was already, here also "my servants" that were already.

hebrew_text: נְגָחוֹ שׁוֹר; יוֹם שֶׁל רַבּוֹ – לְרַבּוֹ, יוֹם שֶׁל עַצְמוֹ – לְעַצְמוֹ. אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה – יוֹם שֶׁל רַבּוֹ יִשָּׂא שִׁפְחָה, יוֹם שֶׁל עַצְמוֹ יִשָּׂא בַּת חוֹרִין! אִיסּוּרָא לָא קָאָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: was gored by an ox the day of his master, to his master. on his day, to himself. However, if that is so, on the day of his master he should marry a maidservant his day he should marry a free woman. We are not saying prohibitions.
llm_translation: The ox gored; on the owner's day – for the owner, on its own day – for itself. Rather, from now on – on the owner's day a maidservant may be married off, on its own day a free woman may be married off! This is not referring to a prohibition.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הֵמִית מִי שֶׁחֶצְיוֹ עֶבֶד וְחֶצְיוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין – נוֹתֵן חֲצִי קְנָס לְרַבּוֹ,
human_translation: Come hear killed a half-slave half-freeman, gives half a penalty, to his master
llm_translation: Come and hear: If one kills someone who is half slave and half free man - he gives half of the fine to his master.

hebrew_text: וַחֲצִי כוֹפֶר לְיוֹרְשָׁיו. אַמַּאי? הָכִי נָמֵי לֵימָא: יוֹם שֶׁל רַבּוֹ – לְרַבּוֹ, יוֹם שֶׁל עַצְמוֹ – לְעַצְמוֹ! שָׁאנֵי הָכָא דְּקָא כָלְיָא קַרְנָא.
human_translation: and half a ransom, to his heirs. why So too, let us say: the day of his master, to his master, on his day, to himself, This is different, for the principal is consumed.
llm_translation: And half the atonement for his heirs. What is the reason? So it should be said: A day that belongs to his master – for his master, a day that belongs to himself – for himself! It is different here because the horn is being completed.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא הֵיכִי דָּמֵי דְּלָא קָא כָלְיָא קַרְנָא? כְּגוֹן שֶׁהִכָּהוּ עַל יָדוֹ, וְצָמְתָה יָדוֹ וְסוֹפָהּ לַחֲזוֹר.
human_translation: Rather, what are the circumstances when the principal is not consumed where struck him on his hand and his hand withered, it will eventually return
llm_translation: And rather how so the blood of not is finished horn like example that struck him on his hand and dried his hand and it returned.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְאַבָּיֵי, דְּאָמַר: נוֹתֵן לוֹ שֶׁבֶת גְּדוֹלָה, וְשֶׁבֶת קְטַנָּה – שַׁפִּיר.
human_translation: This works out well to Abaye, who says: he gives him major loss of livelihood, And minor loss of livelihood, well,
llm_translation: The text reads: "Hanicha l'Abaye, d'amar: Noten lo shabbat gedolah, v'shabbat ketanah - shapir." Translation: "It is satisfactory according to Abaye, who said: If one gives him a large Sabbath and a small Sabbath - it is fine."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְרָבָא, דְּאָמַר: אֵינוֹ נוֹתֵן לוֹ אֶלָּא שִׁבְתּוֹ שֶׁבְּכׇל יוֹם וָיוֹם; הַאי – שׁוֹר הוּא, וְשׁוֹר אֵינוֹ מְשַׁלֵּם אֶלָּא נֶזֶק!
human_translation: However, according to Rava, who says: He gives him only his loss of livelihood for each and every day this is an ox And an ox, pays only damage,
llm_translation: Rather, to Rava, who said: He only gives him his rest every day; this is an ox, and an ox only pays for damage!

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כְּשֶׁהִכָּהוּ אָדָם. וְאִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא: מֵימְרָא הִיא, וּמֵימְרָא לְרָבָא לָא סְבִירָא לֵיהּ.
human_translation: If you wish, say where was struck by a person, And if you wish, say is a statement and Rava not hold in accordance a statement
llm_translation: If you wish, say: When a person struck him. And if you wish, say: It is from heaven, and from heaven, Rava does not hold it likely.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מְעוּכָּב גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר, יֵשׁ לוֹ קְנָס אוֹ אֵין לוֹ קְנָס?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before detained a bill of manumission, does he penalty or does he not penalty?
llm_translation: He asked them: If a delayed bill of divorce, does it have a penalty or does it not have a penalty?

hebrew_text: ״כֶּסֶף שְׁלֹשִׁים שְׁקָלִים יִתֵּן לַאדוֹנָיו״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא – וְהַאי לָאו אָדוֹן הוּא, אוֹ דִלְמָא כֵּיוָן דִּמְחוּסָּר גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר, אָדוֹן קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ?
human_translation: The Merciful One states “He shall give thirty shekels of silver to his master” and this is not a master, Or perhaps, since he is lacking a bill of manumission, he is called a master.
llm_translation: "Thirty silver shekels he shall give to his master," the Merciful One said - But is this not a master, or perhaps since a document of manumission is lacking, is he called a master?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הֵמִית מִי שֶׁחֶצְיוֹ עֶבֶד וְחֶצְיוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין – נוֹתֵן חֲצִי קְנָס לְרַבּוֹ וַחֲצִי כוֹפֶר לְיוֹרְשָׁיו. מַאי, לָאו כְּמִשְׁנָה אַחֲרוֹנָה?
human_translation: Come hear killed one who is a half-slave half-freeman, gives half a penalty, to master and half a ransom, to his heirs. What, is not in accordance with ultimate mishna,
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who kills someone who is half slave and half free – he gives half of the fine to his master and half of the atonement to his heirs. What, is it not like the last Mishnah?

hebrew_text: לֹא, כְּמִשְׁנָה רִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: No, in accordance with initial mishna
llm_translation: Not, like the first Mishnah.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הִפִּיל אֶת שִׁינּוֹ וְסִימָא אֶת עֵינוֹ – יוֹצֵא בְּשִׁינּוֹ, וְנוֹתֵן דְּמֵי עֵינוֹ. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ יֵשׁ לוֹ קְנָס, וּקְנָס לְרַבּוֹ – הַשְׁתָּא חָבְלִי בֵּיהּ אַחֲרִינֵי יָהֲבִי לֵיהּ לְרַבֵּיהּ, חָבֵל בֵּיהּ רַבֵּיהּ גּוּפֵיהּ, יָהֵיב לֵיהּ לְדִידֵיהּ?!
human_translation: Come hear knocked out tooth and blinded his eye, is emancipated due to his tooth, And gives him the value of his eye, And if you say does penalty, and the penalty is to his master, Now other injure him, give to his master; his master himself injures him, should he give to him?
llm_translation: Come and hear: If one knocks out his tooth and blinds his eye - he goes out with his tooth, and pays for his eye. And if you say he has a penalty, and a penalty for his master - is it possible that others should give him to his master, and his master should give him to his master, and he should give him to his friends?!

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ – דְּתַנְיָא: בְּכוּלָּן, עֶבֶד יוֹצֵא בָּהֶן לְחֵירוּת, וְצָרִיךְ גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר מֵרַבּוֹ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: צָרִיךְ. רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: צָרִיךְ.
human_translation: Perhaps with the one who said he does not need as it is taught For all of them, a slave is emancipated by means of them, and he requires a bill of manumission from his master; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Meir says: He does not require Rabbi Eliezer says: He requires Rabbi Tarfon says: He does not require Rabbi Akiva says: He requires
llm_translation: Perhaps according to the one who says "he does not need" - as it was taught: In all of them, a slave goes out with them to freedom, and he requires a bill of emancipation from his master, the words of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Meir says: he does not need, Rabbi Eliezer says: he needs. Rabbi Tarfon says: he does not need, Rabbi Akiva says: he needs.

hebrew_text: הַמַּכְרִיעִין לִפְנֵי חֲכָמִים, אוֹמְרִים: נִרְאִים דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן – בְּשֵׁן וָעַיִן, הוֹאִיל וְתוֹרָה זִכְּתָה לוֹ, וְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא – בִּשְׁאָר אֵבָרִים, הוֹאִיל וּקְנַס חֲכָמִים הוּא.
human_translation: Those who rule before the Sages, say The statement of Rabbi Tarfon, seems in a tooth or an eye, since the Torah transferred to him And the statement of Rabbi Akiva, seems in other limbs, since it is a rabbinic penalty
llm_translation: Those who argue before the sages say: The words of Rabbi Tarfon appear reasonable - regarding tooth and eye, since the Torah has acquitted him. And the words of Rabbi Akiva - regarding the other limbs, since it is a penalty imposed by the sages.

hebrew_text: קְנָס?! הָא קְרָאֵי קָא דָרְשִׁינַן! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: הוֹאִיל וּמִדְרַשׁ חֲכָמִים הוּא.
human_translation: penalty? Don’t we interpret verses Rather, say since it is an interpretation the Sages,
llm_translation: Penalty?! But we expound the verses! Rather say: Since it is a Rabbinic interpretation.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מְעוּכָּב גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר, אוֹכֵל בִּתְרוּמָה אוֹ אֵינוֹ אוֹכֵל? ״קִנְיַן כַּסְפּוֹ״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא – וְהַאי לָאו קִנְיַן כַּסְפּוֹ הוּא, אוֹ דִלְמָא, כֵּיוָן דִּמְחוּסָּר גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר, ״קִנְיַן כַּסְפּוֹ״ קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before detained a bill of manumission, partake of teruma , or he not partake The Merciful One states the purchase of his money, and this is not the purchase of his money, Or perhaps since is lacking a bill of manumission, “the purchase of his money” are said about him.
llm_translation: He asked them: If a delayed bill of divorce, may he eat terumah or not? "Acquisition of his money," the Merciful One said - but is this not acquisition of his money, or perhaps, since the bill of divorce is lacking, "acquisition of his money" is read in it?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַב מְשַׁרְשְׁיָא: כֹּהֶנֶת שֶׁנִּתְעָרֵב וְלָדָהּ בִּוְלַד שִׁפְחָתָהּ, הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ אוֹכְלִין בִּתְרוּמָה, וְחוֹלְקִין חֵלֶק אֶחָד עַל הַגּוֹרֶן. הִגְדִּילוּ הַתַּעֲרוֹבוֹת – מְשַׁחְרְרִין זֶה אֶת זֶה!
human_translation: Come hear what Rav Mesharshiyya says: With regard to a woman a priest whose offspring was mixed with her maidservant’s offspring, these may partake of teruma . And divide one portion of teruma at the threshing floor, the mixed have grown up, they free each other,
llm_translation: Come and hear, for Rav Mesharshya said: A priestess who became intermingled and gave birth with her maidservant's offspring, behold, these may eat of the terumah, and they divide one portion on the threshing floor. If the intermingled ones multiplied - they may free one another!

hebrew_text: הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם, אִם יָבֹא אֵלִיָּהוּ וְיֹאמַר בְּחַד מִינַּיְיהוּ דְּעֶבֶד הוּא, ״קִנְיַן כַּסְפּוֹ״ קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ; הָכָא, לָאו קִנְיַן כַּסְפּוֹ הוּא כְּלָל.
human_translation: How can be compared? There, if Elijah will come and say about one of them that he is a slave, he is called “the purchase of his money,” Here, is not the purchase of his money at all
llm_translation: So now?! There, if Elijah should come and say about one of them that he is a slave, "his money acquisition" we call it; here, it is not his money acquisition at all.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: עֶבֶד שֶׁמְּכָרוֹ רַבּוֹ לִקְנָס, מָכוּר אוֹ אֵינוֹ מָכוּר?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before a slave whose master sold him with regard to penalty, sold or is he not sold?
llm_translation: He asked them: A slave that his master sold him for a penalty, is he sold or is he not sold?

hebrew_text: תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר, תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבָּנַן; תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר אָדָם מַקְנֶה דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לָעוֹלָם, אֶלָּא כְּגוֹן פֵּירוֹת דֶּקֶל – דַּעֲבִידִי דְּאָתוּ; אֲבָל הָכָא – מִי יֵימַר דְּמִינְּגַח? וְאִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר דְּמִינְּגַח – מִמַּאי דִּמְשַׁלֵּם?
human_translation: Raise the dilemma according to Rabbi Meir, raise the dilemma according to the Rabbis, Raise the dilemma according to Rabbi Meir, Rabbi Meir states a person can transfer ownership an entity that has not yet come into the world only such as produce a date palm, whose manner it is to come, However, here, who will say that will be gored? And if you say that he will be gored, from where that will pay
llm_translation: The question was asked to Rabbi Meir, the question was asked to the Rabbis; the question was asked to Rabbi Meir - up to this point Rabbi Meir did not say that a person acquires something that has not yet come into the world, but rather, for example, with regard to dates of a palm tree - since they will come; but here - who can say that he is acquiring? And if you find to say that he is acquiring - from where does he pay?

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא מוֹדֶה וּמִיפְּטַר.
human_translation: Perhaps he will admit and become exempt
llm_translation: Perhaps he admits and exempts.

hebrew_text: וְתִבְּעֵי לְרַבָּנַן – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן אֵין אָדָם מַקְנֶה דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לָעוֹלָם – אֶלָּא כְּגוֹן פֵּירוֹת דֶּקֶל, דְּהַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא לֵיתַנְהוּ; אֲבָל הָכָא – הָא קָאֵי שׁוֹר וְהָא קָאֵי עֶבֶד. מַאי?
human_translation: And you could raise this dilemma according to the Rabbis the Rabbis state a person cannot transfer ownership an entity that has not yet come into the world only such as the produce a date palm, which now, at least, is not However, here, ox is standing and slave is standing, What
llm_translation: The Sages raised an objection: Until this point, the Sages did not say that a person can acquire something that has not come into the world - rather, for example, dates of a palm tree, which are not yet in existence; but here - here stands an ox and here stands a slave. What is the law?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא, תָּא שְׁמַע: ״וִילִיד בַּיִת״ – מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר? אִם קִנְיַן כֶּסֶף – אוֹכֵל, יְלִיד בַּיִת – לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?!
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said: Come hear What the verse states: “And those who are born in his house”? If the purchase of money, partake those who are born in his house, not all the more so
llm_translation: Rabbi Abba said, come and hear: "And a house-born slave" - what is the Talmud teaching us? If a purchased slave eats, should a house-born slave not all the more so?!

hebrew_text: אִילּוּ כֵּן, הָיִיתִי אוֹמֵר: מָה קִנְיַן כֶּסֶף, שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שָׁוֶה כֶּסֶף – אוֹכֵל; אַף יְלִיד בַּיִת, שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שָׁוֶה כֶּסֶף – אוֹכֵל; וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ שָׁוֶה כְּלוּם? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״יְלִיד בַּיִת״ – מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: If so, I would have said: Just as the purchase of money one who has monetary value partakes, so too, one born in house, one who has monetary value partakes. And from where that when is not worth anything, The verse states: “Those who are born in his house,” in any case,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If so, I would say: What is the acquisition of money, that it is equivalent to money - one may eat; so too, a home-born slave, that he is equivalent to money - one may eat; and from where do we derive that even though he is not worth anything? The Torah teaches "a home-born slave" - in any case.

hebrew_text: וַעֲדַיִין אֲנִי אוֹמֵר: יְלִיד בַּיִת, בֵּין שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ שָׁוֶה כֶּסֶף, בֵּין שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה כֶּסֶף – אוֹכֵל; קִנְיַן כֶּסֶף, יֵשׁ בּוֹ שָׁוֶה כֶּסֶף – אוֹכֵל, אֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה כֶּסֶף – אֵינוֹ אוֹכֵל; תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״קִנְיַן כַּסְפּוֹ וִילִיד בֵּיתוֹ״ – מָה יְלִיד בַּיִת, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ שָׁוֶה כְּלוּם – אוֹכֵל; אַף קִנְיַן כַּסְפּוֹ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ שָׁוֶה כְּלוּם – אוֹכֵל.
human_translation: And I still say one born in house partake whether he has monetary value whether he does not have monetary value. purchased of money, he has monetary value, he partake; he does not have monetary value, he not partake. The verse states: “The purchase of his money…and those who are born in his house, Just as one born in house may partake although he is not worth anything, so too, the purchase of his money partake although he is not worth anything.
llm_translation: And still I say: a native of the house, whether it contains equivalent money, or it does not contain equivalent money – he may eat; acquisition of money, if it contains equivalent money – he may eat, if it does not contain equivalent money – he may not eat; the Talmud teaches: "his acquisition and a native of his house" – just as a native of the house, even though he is not equivalent to anything – may eat; so too his acquisition, even though it is not equivalent to anything – may eat.

hebrew_text: וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ, עֶבֶד שֶׁמְּכָרוֹ רַבּוֹ לִקְנָס – מָכוּר; מִי אִיכָּא עַבְדָּא דְּלָא מִזְדַּבַּן לִקְנָסָא?! אִין, אִיכָּא עֶבֶד טְרֵפָה.
human_translation: And if it enters your mind a slave whose master sold him with regard to penalty is sold, is there a slave that cannot be sold with regard to the penalty? Yes, there is a slave who has a wound that will cause him to die within twelve months [ tereifa ].
llm_translation: And if it should enter your mind, a slave that his master sold to be penalized - sold; is there a slave who is not sold for a penalty?! No, there is a slave who is a treifah.

hebrew_text: וְהָא חֲזֵי לְמֵיקַם קַמֵּיהּ! בִּמְנֻוּוֹל וּמוּכֵּה שְׁחִין.
human_translation: But isn’t fit to stand before to disgusting [ menuvval ] or afflicted with boils [ mukeh sheḥin ].
llm_translation: And behold, he saw that he was standing before him! With a fork and a knife he removes the boil.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מִי שֶׁחֶצְיוֹ עֶבֶד וְחֶצְיוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין, שֶׁקִּידֵּשׁ בַּת חוֹרִין, מַהוּ? אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר: ״בֶּן יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁאָמַר לְבַת יִשְׂרָאֵל: ׳הִתְקַדְּשִׁי לְחֶצְיִי׳ – מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת״ – דְּחַזְיָא לְכוּלֵּיהּ; הָא – לָא חַזְיָא לְכוּלֵּיהּ.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before one who is a half-slave half-freeman who betrothed a free woman, what is If you say a Jewish man who said to a Jewish woman: Become betrothed to half of me, she is betrothed, because she is fit to all of him. this she is not fit to all of him
llm_translation: He asked them: If one's half is a slave and half is free, and he sanctified a free woman, what is the law? If you can say: "A Jewish man who said to a Jewish woman, 'Be consecrated to my half' – she becomes consecrated" – see for all; but – not see for all.

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר: ״בֶּן יִשְׂרָאֵל הַמְקַדֵּשׁ חֲצִי אִשָּׁה – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת״ – דְּשִׁיֵּיר בְּקִנְיָנוֹ; וְהָא עֶבֶד – לֹא שִׁיֵּיר בְּקִנְיָנוֹ. מַאי?
human_translation: However, if you say a Jewish man who betroths half a woman, she is not betrothed he left out of his acquisition, but this slave did not leave out of his acquisition, What
llm_translation: "And if you were to say: 'A Jewish man who betroths half a woman - she is not betrothed' - he retains his acquisition; but a slave - he does not retain his acquisition. What is the reason?"

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הֵמִית מִי שֶׁחֶצְיוֹ עֶבֶד וְחֶצְיוֹ בֶּן חוֹרִין – נוֹתֵן חֲצִי קְנָס לְרַבּוֹ, וַחֲצִי כוֹפֶר לְיוֹרְשָׁיו. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ קִידּוּשָׁיו לָאו קִידּוּשִׁין, יוֹרְשִׁין מְנָא לֵיהּ?
human_translation: Come hear killed a half-slave half-freeman, gives half a penalty, to his master and half a ransom, to his heirs. And if you say his betrothal is not betrothal, from where does he have heirs?
llm_translation: Come and hear: If one kills someone who is half slave and half free, he gives half of the fine to his master, and half of the atonement to his heirs. And if you say, his consecrations are not consecrations, how do his heirs inherit from him?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה: כְּשֶׁעֲשָׂאוֹ טְרֵפָה; וּמַאי ״יוֹרְשָׁיו״ – נַפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava says: it made him a tereifa , And what His heirs? himself.
llm_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava said: When he made it treif; and what is "his heirs" - his own soul.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, שְׁתֵּי תְּשׁוּבוֹת בַּדָּבָר: חֲדָא – דְּ״יוֹרְשָׁיו״ קָתָנֵי; וְעוֹד – כּוֹפֶר הוּא, וְאָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: כּוֹפֶר אֵין מִשְׁתַּלֵּם אֶלָּא לְאַחַר מִיתָה! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: רָאוּי לִיטּוֹל, וְאֵין לוֹ.
human_translation: Rava said two refutations of statement: One that it teaches: His heirs, And furthermore, it ransom and Reish Lakish says: Ransom is paid only after death Rather, Rava says: it is fitting to take but he does not have
llm_translation: Rava said, there are two opinions on the matter: one - that it is considered "inheritance," and furthermore - it is a denial, and Reish Lakish said: Denial is only effective after death! Rather, Rava said: It is fitting to take, but he does not have it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁהַמְקַדֵּשׁ חֲצִי אִשָּׁה – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, כָּךְ חֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין שֶׁנִּתְקַדְּשָׁה – אֵין קִדּוּשֶׁיהָ קִדּוּשִׁין.
human_translation: Rava says: Just as that one who betroths half a woman, she is not betrothed, so too, a half-maidservant half-free woman who was betrothed, her betrothal is not betrothal.
llm_translation: Rava said: Just as when one sanctifies half a woman, she is not sanctified, so too, when half of her is a maidservant and half is a free woman, and she becomes sanctified, her sanctity is not valid.

hebrew_text: דָּרֵשׁ רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁהַמְקַדֵּשׁ חֲצִי אִשָּׁה – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, כָּךְ חֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין שֶׁנִּתְקַדְּשָׁה – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב חִסְדָּא: מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם שִׁיֵּיר בְּקִנְיָנוֹ, הָכָא לֹא שִׁיֵּיר בְּקִנְיָנוֹ!
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna taught Just as that one who betroths half a woman, she is not betrothed, so too, a half-maidservant half-free woman who was betrothed, her betrothal is not betrothal. Rav Ḥisda said to him Are comparable? There, he leaves out of his acquisition. here, he did not leave out of his acquisition,
llm_translation: Rabah bar Rav Huna expounded: Just as when one sanctifies half a woman, she is not sanctified, so too when half of her is a maidservant and half is a free woman and she becomes sanctified, she is not sanctified. Rav Ḥisdah said to him: Who is comparable? There, he left out part of the acquisition, but here, he did not leave out part of the acquisition!

hebrew_text: הֲדַר אוֹקֵים רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא אָמוֹרָא עֲלֵיהּ, וּדְרַשׁ: ״וְהַמַּכְשֵׁלָה הַזֹּאת תַּחַת יָדֶיךָ״ – אֵין אָדָם עוֹמֵד עַל דִּבְרֵי תוֹרָה, אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן נִכְשָׁל בָּהֶן; אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאָמְרוּ הַמְקַדֵּשׁ חֲצִי אִשָּׁה – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, אֲבָל חֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין שֶׁנִּתְקַדְּשָׁה – קִדּוּשֶׁיהָ קִדּוּשִׁין. מַאי טַעְמָא? הָתָם שִׁיֵּיר בְּקִנְיָנוֹ, הָכָא לֹא שִׁיֵּיר בְּקִנְיָנוֹ.
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Huna went back and placed an interpreter before him and he interpreted homiletically. “And let this stumbling-block be under your hand” A person does not understand statements of Torah unless he stumbles in them. although said one who betroths half a woman, she is not betrothed, however, a half-maidservant half-free woman who was betrothed, her betrothal is betrothal. What is the reason There, he left out of his acquisition; here, he did not leave out of his acquisition.
llm_translation: The Gemara establishes Rabba bar Rav Huna as an amora on it, and expounded: "And this stumbling block is under your hands" - a person does not stand on matters of Torah unless he stumbles in them; even though they said, one who sanctifies half a woman - she is not sanctified, but if half of her is a maidservant and half is a free woman and she became sanctified - her sanctity is valid. What is the reason? There, he leaves his acquisition, here, he does not leave his acquisition.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁהַמְקַדֵּשׁ חֲצִי אִשָּׁה – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, כָּךְ חֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין שֶׁנִּתְקַדְּשָׁה – אֵין קִידּוּשֶׁיהָ קִידּוּשִׁין. וְאִם לְחָשְׁךָ אָדָם לוֹמַר: אֵיזוֹ הִיא שִׁפְחָה חֲרוּפָה – זוֹ שֶׁחֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין הַמְאוֹרֶסֶת לְעֶבֶד עִבְרִי; אַלְמָא בַּת אִיתְּרוֹסֵי הִיא! אֱמוֹר לוֹ: כְּלָךְ אֵצֶל רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, שֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר – בְּשִׁפְחָה כְּנַעֲנִית הַמְאוֹרֶסֶת לְעֶבֶד עִבְרִי.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said Just as that one who betroths half a woman, she is not betrothed, so too, a half-maidservant half-free woman who was betrothed, her betrothal is not betrothal. And if a person whispers to you [ leḥashekha ], saying, Who is designated maidservant This is a half-maidservant half-free woman who is betrothed to a Hebrew slave, apparently she can be betrothed, say to him: Go to Rabbi Yishmael, for he says to a Canaanite maidservant betrothed to a Hebrew slave.
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said: Just as when one sanctifies half a woman, she is not sanctified, so too when half of her is a maidservant and half is a free woman and she becomes sanctified, her sanctifications are not valid. And if someone were to whisper to you, "Who is a disgraced maidservant?" - this is one whose half is a maidservant and half is a free woman who is betrothed to a Hebrew slave; evidently, she is the daughter of an Israelite. Say to him: Go to Rabbi Yishmael, for he says - in the case of a Canaanite maidservant who is betrothed to a Hebrew slave.

hebrew_text: וְשִׁפְחָה כְּנַעֲנִית בַּת אִיתְּרוֹסֵי הִיא?! אֶלָּא מַאי אִית לָךְ לְמֵימַר, מַאי ״מְאוֹרֶסֶת״ – מְיוּחֶדֶת; הָכָא נָמֵי, מַאי ״מְאוֹרֶסֶת״ – מְיוּחֶדֶת.
human_translation: But can a Canaanite maidservant be betrothed? Rather, what have you to say: What betrothed she is designated Here, also, what betrothed designated
llm_translation: And a Canaanite maidservant, daughter of Ithrosai she is?! Rather, what do you have to say, what is "me'oreses" - designated; here too, what is "me'oreses" - designated.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: חֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין שֶׁנִּתְקַדְּשָׁה לִרְאוּבֵן, וְנִשְׁתַּחְרְרָה, וְחָזְרָה וְנִתְקַדְּשָׁה לְשִׁמְעוֹן, וּמֵתוּ שְׁנֵיהֶם – מִתְיַיבֶּמֶת לְלֵוִי,
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says: a half-maidservant half-free woman who was betrothed to Reuven, and she was emancipated and she went back and was betrothed to Shimon and both died she enters into levirate marriage with Levi,
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah said: Half of her is a maidservant and half of her is a free woman, who was consecrated to Reuben, and she was freed, and then she returned and was consecrated to Simeon, and both of them died - she performs levirate marriage with Levi.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין אֲנִי קוֹרֵא בָּהּ אֵשֶׁת שְׁנֵי מֵתִים; מָה נַפְשָׁךְ, אִי קִדּוּשֵׁי דִּרְאוּבֵן קִדּוּשִׁין – קִדּוּשֵׁי דְּשִׁמְעוֹן לָאו קִדּוּשִׁין, וְאִי קִדּוּשֵׁי דְּשִׁמְעוֹן קִדּוּשִׁין – קִדּוּשֵׁי דִּרְאוּבֵן לָאו קִדּוּשִׁין.
human_translation: and I do not declare her to be the wife of two dead whichever way you If Reuven’s betrothal betrothal, Shimon’s betrothal not betrothal, And if Shimon’s betrothal betrothal, Reuven’s betrothal not betrothal.
llm_translation: I do not read in it the wife of two deceased; what is your opinion, if the betrothals of Reuben are betrothals - the betrothals of Simeon are not betrothals, and if the betrothals of Simeon are betrothals - the betrothals of Reuben are not betrothals.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: חֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין שֶׁנִּתְקַדְּשָׁה לִרְאוּבֵן, וְנִשְׁתַּחְרְרָה, וְחָזְרָה וְנִתְקַדְּשָׁה לְשִׁמְעוֹן, רַב יוֹסֵף בַּר חָמָא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: פָּקְעוּ קִדּוּשֵׁי רִאשׁוֹן; רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: גָּמְרוּ קִדּוּשֵׁי רִאשׁוֹן.
human_translation: It was stated: half-maidservant half-free woman who was betrothed to Reuven, and she was emancipated and she went back and was betrothed to Shimon, Rav Yosef bar Ḥama Rav Naḥman says: first betrothal was abrogated, Rabbi Zeira Rav Naḥman says: first betrothal was completed.
llm_translation: It was stated: Half of her is a maidservant and half of her is a free woman, who was consecrated to Reuben, and she was freed, and she returned and was consecrated to Simeon. Rav Yosef son of Hama said Rav Nachman: The first consecrations were annulled; Rabbi Zeira said Rav Nachman: The first consecrations were completed.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: כְּווֹתֵיהּ דִּידִי מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא יוּמְתוּ כִּי לֹא חוּפָּשָׁה״ – הָא חוּפָּשָׁה, יוּמְתוּ!
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira says: It stands to reason in accordance with my as it is written “They shall not be put to death, because she was not free” But she was free, they will be put to death,
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: My colleague is correct, as it is written: "They shall not die, for they are not free." If they are free, let them die!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וּלְתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, דְּאָמַר: בְּשִׁפְחָה כְּנַעֲנִית הַמְאוֹרֶסֶת לְעֶבֶד עִבְרִי; הָכִי נָמֵי דְּכִי חוּפָּשָׁה – יוּמְתוּ?! אֶלָּא מַאי אִית לָךְ לְמֵימַר – שֶׁחוּפְּשָׁה וְחָזְרָה וְנִתְקַדְּשָׁה, הָכָא נָמֵי – שֶׁחוּפְּשָׁה וְחָזְרָה וְנִתְקַדְּשָׁה.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: And according to the tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, who says: to a Canaanite maidservant betrothed to a Hebrew slave, so too, that when she is free they are put to death? Rather, what have you to say where she was free, and she went back and was betrothed. Here too, where she was free and she went back and was betrothed,
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: And according to the teaching of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, who said: With a Canaanite maidservant who is betrothed to a Hebrew slave; so it is said, when she is freed - shall they die?! Rather, what can you say - that she was freed and returned and became sanctified, here too it is said - that she was freed and returned and became sanctified.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא בַּר קַטִּינָא אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּאִשָּׁה אַחַת שֶׁחֶצְיָהּ שִׁפְחָה וְחֶצְיָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין, וְכָפוּ אֶת רַבָּהּ וַעֲשָׂאָהּ בַּת חוֹרִין. כְּמַאן? כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן בְּרוֹקָה, דְּאָמַר: עַל שְׁנֵיהֶם הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וַיְבָרֶךְ אוֹתָם אֱלֹהִים וַיֹּאמֶר וְגוֹ׳ פְּרוּ וּרְבוּ וּמִלְאוּ וְגוֹ׳״
human_translation: Rav Huna bar Ketina says Rabbi Yitzḥak says: An incident involving one woman who was a half-maidservant half-free woman, and they forced her master and he made her a free woman. In accordance with whose in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, who says: For both states: “And God blessed them, and said Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish
llm_translation: Rav Huna son of Katina said, Rabbi Yitzchak said: There was an incident with a woman, half of her was a maidservant and half was a free woman, and they forced her master and made her a free woman. According to whom? According to Rabbi Yochanan ben Beroka, who said: He blesses them, "God said, 'Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.'"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: לֹא, מִנְהַג הֶפְקֵר נָהֲגוּ בָּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: No, took liberties with her,
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: No, they conducted it with the custom of hefker.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לַגּוֹיִם אוֹ לְחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ – יָצָא בֶּן חוֹרִין.
human_translation: one who sells his slave to gentiles, or to outside of Eretz is emancipated.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who sells his slave to non-Jews or outside the land - the slave goes out free.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לַגּוֹיִם – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת, וְצָרִיךְ גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר מֵרַבּוֹ רִאשׁוֹן. אָמַר רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים – שֶׁלֹּא כָּתַב עָלָיו אוֹנוֹ, אֲבָל כָּתַב עָלָיו אוֹנוֹ – זֶהוּ שִׁחְרוּרוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught one who sells his slave to gentiles, is emancipated, but requires a bill of manumission from his first master. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what is this statement said? When did not write a document for him, but he wrote a document for him, this is his emancipation
llm_translation: The sages taught: One who sells his slave to non-Jews - he goes out to freedom, and requires a bill of emancipation from his original master. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what case are these words said - that he did not write a lien on him, but if he wrote a lien on him - this is his emancipation.

hebrew_text: מַאי ״אוֹנוֹ״? אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת, דִּכְתַב לֵיהּ הָכִי: לִכְשֶׁתִּבְרַח מִמֶּנּוּ, אֵין לִי עֵסֶק בָּךְ.
human_translation: What document? Rav Sheshet said: He writes to him like this: When you will escape from I have no business with you.
llm_translation: What is "onu"? Rav Sheshet said, for it is written to him thus: "When you flee from it, I have no business with you."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: לָוָה עָלָיו מִן הַגּוֹי, כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָשָׂה לוֹ גּוֹי נִמוּסוֹ – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת. מַאי נִמוּסוֹ? אָמַר רַב הוּנָא בַּר יְהוּדָה: נַשְׁקִי.
human_translation: The Sages taught: he borrows from a gentile on the basis of once gentile behaves with his law [ nimmuso ], is emancipated, What His law? Rav Huna bar Yehuda said: a seal [ nashkei ]
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: If one borrowed from a gentile, and once the gentile has made his loan document (i.e., the promissory note) void - he is released from his obligation. What does it mean "made it void"? Rav Huna son of Yehuda said: "It was torn."

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: הָאֲרִיסִין, וְהַחֲכִירוֹת, וַאֲרִיסֵי בָּתֵּי אָבוֹת, וְגוֹי שֶׁמִּשְׁכֵּן שָׂדֵהוּ לְיִשְׂרָאֵל; אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁעָשָׂה לוֹ נִמוּסוֹ – פְּטוּרָה מִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet raises an objection sharecroppers, or tenant farmers, or family sharecroppers, or a gentile who mortgaged his field to a Jew, even though acted for based on his, law, exempt from tithes,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Sheshet raised a difficulty: Sharecroppers, and lessees, and lessees of ancestral houses, and a non-Jew who leases his field to a Jew; even though he made it a condition for himself that his produce be tithed – he is exempt from tithing.

hebrew_text: וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ נַשְׁקִי, שָׂדֶה בַּת נַשְׁקִי הִיא? אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: זְמַן.
human_translation: And if it enters your mind a seal, is a field able to be sealed? Rather, Rav Sheshet says: time.
llm_translation: And if it enters your mind, "Is it a field of a daughter of a weapon?" Rather, Rav Sheshet said: "Time."

hebrew_text: קַשְׁיָא זְמַן אַזְּמַן! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא דִּמְטָא זִמְנֵיהּ, הָא דְּלָא מְטָא זִמְנֵיהּ.
human_translation: difficulty time and time not difficult, This, when his time has arrived, this, its time has not arrived.
llm_translation: Time is a time! Not time: this that comes its time, this that does not come its time.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא גַּבֵּי עֶבֶד, דִּמְטָא זִמְנֵיהּ צְרִיכָא לְמֵימַר?! אֶלָּא אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי דְּלָא מְטָא זִמְנֵיהּ, וְלָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא לְגוּפָא, וְהָא לְפֵירָא.
human_translation: But with regard to a slave whose time to be transferred has arrived, need to be said Rather, This and that when his time has not arrived, and not difficult: This, to himself, and that to produce.
llm_translation: Rather, regarding a slave, when his time comes, is it necessary to say?! Rather, both this and that, when his time does not come, and it is not difficult: this for the body, and that for the fruit.

hebrew_text: וְאִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא: בְּשֶׁלָּוָה עַל מְנָת לְמַשְׁכְּנוֹ, וְלֹא מִשְׁכְּנוֹ.
human_translation: And if you wish, say in where he borrowed on the condition that collect it, but they did not collect it.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: "For his dwelling in order to draw him close, and not his drawing close."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: גְּבָאוֹ בְּחוֹבוֹ אוֹ שֶׁלְּקָחוֹ סִיקָרִיקוֹן, לֹא יָצָא לְחֵירוּת. וּבְחוֹבוֹ לֹא?!
human_translation: The Sages taught collected for his debt, or was taken by a Sicarius, he is not emancipated. And for his debt, not
llm_translation: The sages taught: If his wallet is in his hand or he took it with him, he has not fulfilled his obligation of freedom. And if it is in his hand, has he not fulfilled his obligation?!

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהִי: הֲרֵי שֶׁאָנְסוּ בֵּית הַמֶּלֶךְ גּוֹרְנוֹ, אִם בְּחוֹבוֹ – חַיָּיב לְעַשֵּׂר, אִם בָּאַנְפָּרוֹת – פָּטוּר מִלְּעַשֵּׂר!
human_translation: And raises a contradiction where the household of the king seized one’s threshing floor if for his debt he is obligated to tithe If unjust seizure [ anparot ] he is exempt from tithing.
llm_translation: And ask: Behold, if they were forced in the king's house, Gornu, if with his consent - obligated to tithe, if with coercion - exempt from tithing!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם, דְּקָא מִשְׁתָּרְשִׁי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: It is different there, because he profits
llm_translation: There, the matter differs, for it is becoming permitted to him.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַב: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לְפַרְהַנְגְּ גּוֹי – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת! הָתָם, הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְפַיֵּיס וְלֹא פִּיֵּיס.
human_translation: Come hear as Rav says: One who sells his slave to a gentile official [ parhang ], is emancipated There, should have appeased and he did not appease
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Ta shema, de'amar Rav: hamocher avdo le'parhaneg goy - yatza lecheirut! Hatam, hava leih lepayes velo piyes." English translation: "Come and hear, for Rav said: One who sells his slave to a non-Jew - he goes out to freedom! There, he had the opportunity to ransom him, but did not ransom him."

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא – אָמַר רַב: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לְפַרְהַנְגְּ גּוֹי – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת. מַאי הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְמֶעְבַּד? הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְפַיֵּיס, וְלֹא פִּיֵּיס.
human_translation: the itself. Rav says: One who sells his slave to a gentile official, is emancipated. What could he have done; He should have appeased and he did not appease
llm_translation: Body - Rav said: One who sells his slave to a non-Jew - he goes out to freedom. What was there for him to do? He could have redeemed him, but he did not redeem him.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: מְכָרוֹ לִשְׁלשִׁים יוֹם, מַהוּ? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַב: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לְפַרְהַנְגְּ גּוֹי – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת! הָתָם בְּפַרְהַנְגְּ גּוֹי שֶׁאֵינָהּ חוֹזֶרֶת.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma: he sold for thirty days, what is Come hear as Rav says: one who sells his slave to a gentile official, is emancipated. There, to a gentile official, as is not reversed.
llm_translation: Inquiries of Rabbi Yirmiyah: If one sold his slave for thirty days, what is the law? Come and hear, for Rav said: One who sells his slave to a non-Jew - he goes out to freedom! There, in the case of a non-Jewish buyer, she does not return.

hebrew_text: מְכָרוֹ חוּץ מִמְּלַאכְתּוֹ, מַהוּ? חוּץ מִן הַמִּצְוֹת, מַהוּ? חוּץ מִשַּׁבָּתוֹת וְיָמִים טוֹבִים, מַהוּ? לְגֵר תּוֹשָׁב, לְיִשְׂרָאֵל מְשׁוּמָּד, מַהוּ? לְכוּתִי, מַהוּ? פְּשׁוֹט מִיהָא חֲדָא: גֵּר תּוֹשָׁב הֲרֵי הוּא כְּגוֹי. כּוּתִי וְיִשְׂרָאֵל מְשׁוּמָּד – אָמְרִי לַהּ כְּגוֹי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ כְּיִשְׂרָאֵל.
human_translation: he sold aside from his labor, what is aside from the mitzvot, what is aside from Shabbatot and Festivals, what is to a gentile who resides in Eretz Yisrael and observes the seven Noahide mitzvot [ ger toshav ], to a Jewish apostate, what is to a Samaritan, what is You can resolve at least one A ger toshav is like a gentile. Samaritan and a Jewish apostate, some say like gentiles and some say like Jews.
llm_translation: His sale outside of his work, what? Outside of the commandments, what? Outside of Sabbaths and festivals, what? To a resident alien, to an apostate Israelite, what? To a Samaritan, what? It is obvious: a resident alien is like a gentile. A Samaritan and an apostate Israelite - some say he is like a gentile, and some say he is like an Israelite.

hebrew_text: בְּעוֹ מִינֵּיהּ מֵרַבִּי אַמֵּי: עֶבֶד שֶׁהִפִּיל עַצְמוֹ לִגְיָיסוֹת, וְאֵין רַבּוֹ יָכוֹל לְהוֹצִיאוֹ – לֹא בְּדִינֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְלֹא בְּדִינֵי אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם, מַהוּ שֶׁיִּטּוֹל אֶת דָּמָיו?
human_translation: They raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ami: a slave gave himself over to a army and his master cannot remove him, neither through Jewish law nor through the laws of the nations of the world, what is for to take his value
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Be'o mineih meRabbi Amei: eved shehipil atzmo ligyaisot, ve'ein rabo yakhol lehotzi'o - lo b'dinei Yisrael velo b'dinei ummot ha'olam, mah hu sheyit'ol et damav?" English translation: "They asked Rabbi Amei: A slave who threw himself into a pool of water, and his master cannot save him - neither under the laws of Israel nor under the laws of the nations of the world, what should he do with his money?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה לְרַבִּי זְרִיקָא: פּוֹק עַיֵּין בִּמְכִילָתָיךְ. נְפַק דָּק וְאַשְׁכַּח, דְּתַנְיָא: הַמּוֹכֵר בֵּיתוֹ לְגוֹי – דָּמָיו אֲסוּרִין. וְגוֹי שֶׁאָנַס בֵּיתוֹ שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְאֵין בְּעָלָיו יָכוֹל לְהוֹצִיאוֹ – לֹא בְּדִינֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְלֹא בְּדִינֵי אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם, מוּתָּר לִיטּוֹל אֶת דָּמָיו, וְכוֹתֵב וּמַעֲלֶה בְּעַרְכָּאוֹת שֶׁלָּהֶן – מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא כְּמַצִּיל מִיָּדָם.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zerika: Go out and examine your mishnayot He went out, examined, and discovered as it is taught One who sells his house to a gentile, the monies are forbidden And a gentile who seized a Jew’s house and its owner cannot remove it, neither through Jewish law nor through the laws of the nations of the world, he is permitted to take value and he write and register in their courts, because he is like one who rescues from their possession.
llm_translation: He said to him, Rabbi Yirmeya to Rabbi Zerika: Go out and look in your scrolls. He went out, searched, and found, as it was taught: One who sells his house to a gentile - its value is forbidden. And if a gentile forcibly enters the house of an Israelite, and the owner cannot remove him - neither by the laws of Israel nor by the laws of the nations of the world, he is permitted to take his value, and he writes and brings up their evaluations - because he is like one who saves from their hands.

hebrew_text: וְדִילְמָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי בַּיִת – דְּכֵיוָן דְּלָא סַגִּי לֵיהּ בְּלֹא בַּיִת, לָא אָתֵי לְזַבּוֹנֵיהּ; אֲבָל עַבְדָּא – דְּסַגִּי לֵיהּ בְּלָא עַבְדָּא, אָתֵי לְזַבּוֹנֵיהּ – אוֹ לָא.
human_translation: But perhaps this matter applies house, that since it is not sufficient, for him without a house, he would not sell it But a slave, as it is sufficient for him without a slave, he will come to sell him Or not
llm_translation: And perhaps these matters of the house - since it is not sufficient for him without the house, he will not come to redeem it; but a slave - since it is sufficient for him without the slave, he will come to redeem it - or not.

hebrew_text: שְׁלַח לְהוּ רַבִּי אַמֵּי: ״מִינַּי אַמֵּי בַּר נָתָן, תּוֹרָה יוֹצְאָה לְכׇל יִשְׂרָאֵל: עֶבֶד שֶׁהִפִּיל עַצְמוֹ לִגְיָיסוֹת, וְאֵין רַבּוֹ יָכוֹל לְהוֹצִיאוֹ – לֹא בְּדִינֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְלֹא בְּדִינֵי אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם, מוּתָּר לִיטּוֹל אֶת דָּמָיו, וְכוֹתֵב וּמַעֲלֶה בְּעַרְכָּאוֹת שֶׁל גּוֹיִם – מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא כְּמַצִּיל מִיָּדָם.
human_translation: Rabbi Ami sent to From me, Ami bar Natan, Torah emerges to all of Israel: a slave gave himself to a army and his master cannot remove him, neither through Jewish law nor through the laws of the nations of the world, permitted to take value, and he writes and registers in gentile courts, because he is like one who rescues from their possession.
llm_translation: Send to him Rabbi Ammi: "From the words of Rabbi Ammi bar Nathan, the Torah extends to all of Israel: A slave who threw himself into idolatry, and his master cannot redeem him - neither in the laws of Israel nor in the laws of the nations of the world, it is permitted to take his life, and one may write and elevate him in the valuation of non-Jews - because he is like one who saves from their hands."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לְגוֹי – קוֹנְסִים אוֹתוֹ עַד מֵאָה בְּדָמָיו.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: one who sells his slave to a gentile, he is penalized up to one hundred value.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: One who sells his slave to a non-Jew - they penalize him up to one hundred for his value.

hebrew_text: דַּוְקָא, אוֹ לָאו דַּוְקָא? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: הַמּוֹכֵר בְּהֵמָה גַּסָּה לְגוֹי – קוֹנְסִים אוֹתוֹ עַד עֲשָׂרָה בְּדָמֶיהָ!
human_translation: specifically or not specifically? Come hear that Reish Lakish says: One who sells a large domesticated animal to a gentile, he is penalized up to ten its value.
llm_translation: Specifically, or not specifically? Come and hear, as Reish Lakish said: One who sells an animal to a non-Jew for a high price - we penalize him up to ten times its value!

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא שָׁאנֵי עֶבֶד, דְּכֹל יוֹמָא וְיוֹמָא מַפְקַע לֵיהּ מִמִּצְוֹת.
human_translation: But perhaps a slave is different, as each and every day releases him from mitzvot
llm_translation: Perhaps it is different with a slave, for every day he is exempt from commandments.

hebrew_text: וְאִיכָּא דְאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לְגוֹי – קוֹנְסִין אוֹתוֹ עַד עֲשָׂרָה בְּדָמָיו. דַּוְקָא אוֹ לָאו דַּוְקָא? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: הַמּוֹכֵר בְּהֵמָה גַּסָּה לְגוֹי – קוֹנְסִין אוֹתוֹ עַד מֵאָה בְּדָמֶיהָ!
human_translation: And there are who say Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says one who sells his slave to a gentile, he is penalized up to ten value. specifically or not specifically; Come hear that Reish Lakish says: one who sells a large domesticated animal to a gentile, he is penalized up to one hundred its value,
llm_translation: And there are those who say, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: One who sells his slave to a non-Jew - we penalize him up to ten of his value. Is this specifically so or not specifically so? Come and hear, as Reish Lakish said: One who sells a large animal to a non-Jew - we penalize him up to a hundred of its value!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי עֶבֶד, דְּלָא הָדַר לֵיהּ.
human_translation: A slave is different, as he does not return to him.
llm_translation: The servant is different, for he did not return it.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא בְּהֵמָה טַעְמָא מַאי – מִשּׁוּם דְּהָדְרָא לֵיהּ?! לִקְנְסֵיהּ טְפֵי חַד! אֶלָּא עֶבֶד מִילְּתָא דְלָא שְׁכִיחָא, וּמִלְּתָא דְלָא שְׁכִיחָא לָא גָּזְרִי בַּהּ רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rather, what is the reason animal because that it returns to him? he should be penalized one additional Rather, a slave an uncommon matter, and the Sages did not decree an uncommon matter.
llm_translation: Rather, regarding an animal, what is the reason? Because it will return to him?! To penalize him doubly! Rather, a matter that is not common, and a matter that is not common, the Rabbis do not decree upon it.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה מֵרַבִּי אַסִּי: מָכַר עַבְדּוֹ וָמֵת, מַהוּ שֶׁיִּקְנְסוּ אֶת בְּנוֹ אַחֲרָיו? אִם תִּימְצֵי לוֹמַר: ״צָרַם אוֹזֶן בְּכוֹר, וָמֵת – קָנְסוּ בְּנוֹ אַחֲרָיו״ – מִשּׁוּם דְּאִיסּוּרָא דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הִיא, אֲבָל הָכָא אִיסּוּרָא דְרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma before Rabbi Asi: sold his slave and died, what is Is his son penalized after him? If you say, slit ear firstborn and died, his son is penalized after him because it is a prohibition by Torah law. Here, however, a prohibition by rabbinic
llm_translation: Requested by Rabbi Yirmeya from Rabbi Assi: If one sold his slave and he died, what should be the penalty for his son afterwards? If you might say, "He caused the death of the firstborn son, and he died - his son should be penalized afterwards" - because it is a prohibition from the Torah, but here it is a prohibition from the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּימְצֵי לוֹמַר: ״כִּוֵּון מְלַאכְתּוֹ בַּמּוֹעֵד, וָמֵת – לֹא קָנְסוּ בְּנוֹ אַחֲרָיו״ – מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא עֲבַד אִיסּוּרָא, הָכָא מַאי? לְדִידֵיהּ קְנַסוּ רַבָּנַן – וְהָא לֵיתֵיהּ; אוֹ דִילְמָא לְמָמוֹנֵיהּ קְנַסוּ רַבָּנַן – וְהָא אִיתֵיהּ?
human_translation: And if you say planned his labor on the Festival, and he died, his child is not penalized after him, because did not perform a prohibited Here, what the Sages penalize him, and he is no longer or perhaps the Sages penalized his property, and exists?
llm_translation: And if you might suggest: "Since his work was completed on the festival, and he died - his sons were not penalized after him" - because he did not perform a prohibition, what is the case here? According to his own actions, the Rabbis penalized him - and here he is not present; or perhaps they penalized him for his possessions - and here he is present?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, תְּנֵיתוּהָ: שָׂדֶה שֶׁנִּתְקַוְּוצָה בַּשְּׁבִיעִית, תִּזָּרַע לְמוֹצָאֵי שְׁבִיעִית. נִטַּיְּיבָה אוֹ נִדַּיְּירָה – לֹא תִּזָּרַע לְמוֹצָאֵי שְׁבִיעִית.
human_translation: said to him: You learned A field whose thorns were removed during the Sabbatical may be sown after the conclusion of the Sabbatical it had been improved or it had been populated it may not be sown after the conclusion of the Sabbatical
llm_translation: He said to him, "You should teach it: a field that was uprooted in the Sabbatical year, should be sown for the produce of the Sabbatical year. Whether it was plowed or left fallow - do not sow for the produce of the Sabbatical year."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא, נָקְטִינַן: הֱטִיבָהּ וָמֵת – בְּנוֹ זוֹרְעָהּ. אַלְמָא לְדִידֵיהּ קְנַסוּ רַבָּנַן, לִבְרֵיהּ לָא קְנַסוּ רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: We have a tradition improved and died, his son may sow it. Apparently, the Sages applied the penalty to himself, the Sages did not penalize his son.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, said, we have learned: "If it was good and he died - his son planted it." This implies that the Rabbis penalized him for his own sake, but they did not penalize his son.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, נָקְטִינַן: טִימֵּא טְהָרוֹת שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, וָמֵת – לָא קְנַסוּ רַבָּנַן בְּנוֹ אַחֲרָיו. מַאי טַעְמָא? הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר לָא שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק, וּקְנָסָא דְּרַבָּנַן הִיא – לְדִידֵיהּ קַנְסוּהוּ רַבָּנַן, לִבְרֵיהּ לָא קָא קְנַסוּ רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Abaye said: We have a tradition defiled his friend’s ritually pure items, and died did not penalize his son after him What is the reason Damage that is not evident, is not considered damage but is a penalty of the Sages. The Sages applied the penalty to himself, the Sages did not apply the penalty to his son.
llm_translation: Abaye said, we have learned: If one acquires the ritual purity of his fellow, and the fellow dies - the Rabbis did not impose a penalty on his son. What is the reason? The damage that is not recognizable by name is not considered damage, and the penalty of the Rabbis is - they imposed it on him, but not on his son.

hebrew_text: אוֹ לְחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לְחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת, וְצָרִיךְ גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר מֵרַבּוֹ שֵׁנִי. רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: פְּעָמִים יָצָא, וּפְעָמִים לֹא יָצָא. כֵּיצַד? אָמַר: ״פְּלוֹנִי עַבְדִּי מְכַרְתִּיהוּ לִפְלוֹנִי אַנְטוֹכִי״ – לֹא יָצָא. ״לְאַנְטוֹכִי שֶׁבְּאַנְטוֹכְיָא״ – יָצָא.
human_translation: or to outside of Eretz The Sages taught one who sells his slave to outside of Eretz is emancipated, but requires a bill of manumission from his second master. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Sometimes he is emancipated and sometimes he is not emancipated. How so? said: So-and-so my slave, I sold him to so-and-so of Antioch, he is not emancipated, to of Antioch who is in Antioch, he is emancipated,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Or to outside the land: The Rabbis taught: One who sells his slave to outside the land - he goes out to freedom, and he requires a bill of emancipation from his master a second time. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Sometimes he goes out, and sometimes he does not go out. How so? He said: "Ploni my slave I sold to Ploni the Anatolian" - he does not go out. "To the Anatolian in Anatolia" - he goes out.

hebrew_text: וְהָא תַּנְיָא: ״מְכַרְתִּיהוּ לְאַנְטוֹכִי״ – יָצָא, ״לְאַנְטוֹכִי הַשָּׁרוּי בְּלוֹד״ – לֹא יָצָא!
human_translation: But isn’t it taught I sold him to of Antioch, is emancipated, to of Antioch who dwells in Lod, is not emancipated.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And it was taught: 'I sold it to an Antiochian' – he is exempt, 'to an Antiochian dwelling in Lod' – he is not exempt!"

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא דְּאִית לֵיהּ בֵּיתָא בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, הָא דְּאִית לֵיהּ אוּשְׁפִּיזָא בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל.
human_translation: not difficult. This has a house in Eretz Yisrael, That when he has an inn [ ushpiza ] in Eretz Yisrael,
llm_translation: Not difficult, this that there is a house in the land of Israel, this that there is a storehouse in the land of Israel.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: בֶּן בָּבֶל שֶׁנָּשָׂא אִשָּׁה בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְהִכְנִיסָה לוֹ עֲבָדִים וּשְׁפָחוֹת, וְדַעְתּוֹ לַחֲזוֹר, מַהוּ?
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma: a resident of Babylonia who married a woman in Eretz Yisrael, and she brought in slaves and maidservants for him, and he intends to return what is
llm_translation: Inquiries of Rabbi Yirmeya: A Babylonian who married a woman in the land of Israel, and she brought him slaves and maidservants, and he intends to return, what is the law?

hebrew_text: תִּיבְּעֵי לְמַאן דְּאָמַר הַדִּין עִמָּהּ, תִּיבְּעֵי לְמַאן דְּאָמַר הַדִּין עִמּוֹ.
human_translation: Let the dilemma be raised according to the one who said: The law is with her, let the dilemma be raised according to the one who said: The law is with him,
llm_translation: He inquires according to the one who says the law is with her, he inquires according to the one who says the law is with him.

hebrew_text: תִּיבְּעֵי לְמַאן דְּאָמַר הַדִּין עִמָּהּ – כֵּיוָן דְּהַדִּין עִמָּהּ, כְּדִידֵהּ דָּמוּ; אוֹ דִילְמָא, כֵּיוָן דִּמְשַׁעְבְּדִי לֵיהּ לְפֵירָא, כְּדִידֵיהּ דָּמוּ?
human_translation: Let the dilemma be raised according to the one who says the law is with her, since the law is with her, are considered as hers. or perhaps since they are liened to for profits are considered as his,
llm_translation: The text reads: "Tibei l'man de'amar hadin imah - keivan de'hadin imah, kedideh damu; o dilma, keivan dimshabdi lei lefeira, kedideih damu?" Translation: "It is asked according to the one who says the law is with her - since the law is with her, is her judgment similar; or perhaps, since they serve her wine, is her judgment similar?"

hebrew_text: וְתִיבְּעֵי לְמַאן דְּאָמַר הַדִּין עִמּוֹ – כֵּיוָן דְּהַדִּין עִמּוֹ, כְּדִידֵיהּ דָּמוּ; אוֹ דִלְמָא, כֵּיוָן דְּלָא קָנֵי לֵיהּ לְגוּפֵיהּ – כְּדִידֵהּ דָּמוּ? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: And let the dilemma be raised according to the one who says: The law is with him, since the law is with him, are considered as his, or perhaps since did not acquire the slave himself, are considered as hers. shall stand
llm_translation: And it is asked according to the one who says the law is with him - since the law is with him, his money is like his; or perhaps, since he does not acquire it for himself - is his money like his? This remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, שָׁנָה לִי רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: עֶבֶד שֶׁיָּצָא אַחַר רַבּוֹ לְסוּרְיָא, וּמְכָרוֹ שָׁם רַבּוֹ – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת. וְהָתָנֵי רַבִּי חִיָּיא: אִיבֵּד אֶת זְכוּתוֹ!
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu says: Rabbi Yoḥanan taught me: a slave who followed his master to Syria, and his master sold him there, is emancipated. But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach: lost his right
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu said, "Rabbi Yochanan taught me: If a slave goes out after his master to Syria, and his master sells him there - he goes out to freedom." And Rabbi Chiya taught: "Examine his merit!"

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא, כָּאן שֶׁדַּעַת רַבּוֹ לַחְזוֹר, כָּאן שֶׁאֵין דַּעַת רַבּוֹ לַחְזוֹר.
human_translation: not difficult. Here, where his master’s intention to return, There, where his master does not intend to return,
llm_translation: Not difficult, here where the master's knowledge is to return, here where the master's knowledge is not to return.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: יוֹצֵא הָעֶבֶד אַחַר רַבּוֹ לְסוּרְיָא – ״יוֹצֵא״?! לָא סַגִּי דְּלָא נָפֵיק?! וְהָתְנַן: וְאֵין הַכֹּל מוֹצִיאִין!
human_translation: And is taught The slave follows his master to Syria. he follow not possible for him not to follow But didn’t we learn but all may not remove,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught: If the slave goes out after his master to Suria - "goes out"?! Is it not enough that he does not go out?! And we learned: And not everyone goes out!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא יָצָא הָעֶבֶד אַחַר רַבּוֹ לְסוּרְיָא, וּמְכָרוֹ רַבּוֹ שָׁם; אִם דַּעַת רַבּוֹ לַחְזוֹר – כּוֹפִין אוֹתוֹ, וְאִם אֵין דַּעַת רַבּוֹ לַחְזוֹר – אֵין כּוֹפִין אוֹתוֹ.
human_translation: Rather, a slave followed his master to Syria, and his master sold him there, if his master’s intention to return he is forced but if his master did not intend to return he is not forced
llm_translation: Rather, the slave went out after his master to Sura, and his master sold him there; if his master intends to return - they compel him, but if his master does not intend to return - they do not compel him.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב עָנָן, שְׁמַעִית מִינֵּיהּ דְּמָר שְׁמוּאֵל תַּרְתֵּי: חֲדָא – הָךְ; וְאִידָּךְ – דְּאִיתְּמַר: הַמּוֹכֵר שָׂדֵהוּ בִּשְׁנַת הַיּוֹבֵל עַצְמָהּ; רַב אָמַר: מְכוּרָה, וְיוֹצְאָה. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֵינָהּ מְכוּרָה כׇּל עִיקָּר.
human_translation: Rav Anan said: I learned two from Mar Shmuel. One this and the other as it was stated one who sells his field in the Jubilee Year itself? Rav says: It is sold it leaves And Shmuel says: It is not sold at all.
llm_translation: Rav Anan said, "I heard two teachings from Mar Shmuel: One - this; and the other - that it was stated: 'One who sells his field in the year of the Jubilee, its essence.' Rav said: It is sold, and it goes out. And Shmuel said: It is not sold at all essentially."

hebrew_text: בַּחֲדָא – הָדְרִי זְבִינֵי, וּבַחֲדָא – לָא הָדְרִי זְבִינֵי; וְלָא יָדַעְנָא הֵי מִינַּיְיהוּ.
human_translation: In one the sale is returned, and in one the sale is not returned, but I do not know which of
llm_translation: In one case - the wine improved, and in another case - the wine did not improve; and we do not know which one.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: נִיחְזֵי אֲנַן, מִדְּתָנֵי בְּבָרַיְיתָא: הַמּוֹכֵר עַבְדּוֹ לְחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ – יָצָא לְחֵירוּת, וְצָרִיךְ גֵּט שִׁחְרוּר מֵרַבּוֹ שֵׁנִי. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ קַנְיֵיהּ רַבּוֹ שֵׁנִי, וְלָא הָדְרִי זְבִינֵי; וְכִי אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל הָתָם אֵינָהּ מְכוּרָה – וּמָעוֹת חוֹזְרִין.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: Let us see From what is taught in the baraita : One who sells his slave to outside Eretz he is emancipated, but requires a bill of manumission from his second master. Learn from his second master acquired him, and the sale is not returned. And when Shmuel said there is not sold, and the money returns
