hebrew_text: מְשׁוּךְ פֵּירֵי מִיַּתְמֵי; אִיַּיקּוּר – הַיְינוּ דְּרַב חֲנִילַאי בַּר אִידִי. זוּל – לֹא יְהֵא כֹּחַ הֶדְיוֹט חָמוּר מֵהֶקְדֵּשׁ.
human_translation: pulled produce belonging to orphans increased in value, this is Rav Ḥanilai bar Idi decreased in value, the power of an ordinary person should not be greater than Temple
llm_translation: Pulled fruits from Yatmei; Iyakur - that is Rav Chanilai son of Idi. Zul - the power of a layman should not be more severe than that of a priest.

hebrew_text: אִמְּשִׁיכוּ לְהוּ פֵּירֵי לְיַתְמֵי; אִיַּיקַּר – לֹא יְהֵא כֹּחַ הֶדְיוֹט חָמוּר מֵהֶקְדֵּשׁ. זוּל – סְבוּר מִינָּה, הַיְינוּ דְּרַב חֲנִילַאי בַּר אִידִי;
human_translation: pulled produce on behalf of the orphans, increased in value, the power of an ordinary person should not be greater than Temple the produce decreased in value, understood from here this is Rav Ḥanilai bar Idi
llm_translation: They should give him fruits for the orphans; if he is precious - the power of the commoner should not be more severe than that of the holy. Zul - he thought differently, that is what Rav Chanilai son of Idi said.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ רַב שִׁישָׁא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי: הָא רָעָה הִיא לְדִידְהוּ – דְּזִמְנִין דְּמִצְטַרְכִי לְפֵירֵי, וְלֵיכָּא דְּיָהֵיב לְהוּ עַד דְּיָהֲבִי זוּזֵי.
human_translation: Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said to them: This would be bad for as times need produce and nobody will give to them before they pay the money.
llm_translation: He said to them, Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi: "This is a bad thing for them - sometimes they need fruit, and there is no one to give them until they give money."

hebrew_text: יָהֲבִי יַתְמֵי זוּזֵי אַפֵּירֵי; זוּל – לֹא יְהֵא כֹּחַ הֶדְיוֹט חָמוּר מִן הֶקְדֵּשׁ. אִיַּיקַּר – סְבוּר מִינַּהּ, הַיְינוּ דְּרַב חֲנִילַאי בַּר אִידִי;
human_translation: the orphans gave money for produce decreased in value, the power of an ordinary person, should not be greater than Temple increased in value, understood from here this is Rav Ḥanilai bar Idi
llm_translation: He gave two coins of Zuzim to the poor; Zul - the power of a layman should not be more severe than that of the Temple. Iyikar - he thought from it, that is what Rav Chanilai bar Idi said.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ רַב שִׁישָׁא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי: הָא רָעָה הִיא לְדִידְהוּ –
human_translation: Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said to them: This would be bad for
llm_translation: Said to them Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi: "This is a bad thing for them -"

hebrew_text: דְּאָתוּ לְמֵימַר לְהוּ: נִשְׂרְפוּ חִיטֵּיכֶם בַּעֲלִיָּיה.
human_translation: as will come to say to them: Your wheat was burned in the upper story
llm_translation: They came to say to him: "Your wheat has been burned in the barn."

hebrew_text: יָהֲבִי לְהוּ זוּזֵי לְיַתְמֵי אַפֵּירֵי; אִיַּיקַּר – לֹא יְהֵא כֹּחַ הֶדְיוֹט חָמוּר מֵהֶקְדֵּשׁ. זוּל – סְבוּר מִינָּה, הַיְינוּ דְּרַב חֲנִילַאי בַּר אִידִי;
human_translation: gave the orphans money for produce, increased in value, the power of an ordinary person should not be greater than Temple decreased in value, understood from here this is Rav Ḥanilai bar Idi
llm_translation: They gave him money to the orphans of Afirei; if he is precious - the power of a layman should not be more severe than that of a priest. Zul - he thought from her, that is what Rav Chanilai son of Idi said.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ רַב שִׁישָׁא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִידִי: הָא רָעָה הוּא לְדִידְהוּ – דְּזִמְנִין דְּמִצְטַרְכִי לְזוּזֵי, וְלֵיכָּא דְּיָהֵיב לְהוּ עַד דְּיָהֲבִי לְהוּ פֵּירֵי.
human_translation: Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said to them: This would be bad for as times that need money and no one will give to them before they give them the produce.
llm_translation: He said to them, Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi: "This is a bad thing for us - sometimes we need to move, and there is no one to give us fruit until we give them payment."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: אֲנָא וְרַב כָּהֲנָא חָתְמִינַן אַשְּׁטָרָא דְּאִימֵּיהּ דִּזְעֵירָא יַתְמָא, דִּמְזַבְּנָא אַרְעָא לִכְרָגָא בְּלָא אַכְרַזְתָּא; דְּאָמְרִי נְהַרְדָּעֵי: לִכְרָגָא וְלִמְזוֹנֵי וְלִקְבוּרָה – מְזַבְּנִינַן בְּלָא אַכְרַזְתָּא.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: Rav Kahana and I signed a deed for the mother of Ze’eira the orphan, who, sold land without announcement in order to head tax [ karga ]. what of Neharde’a said: for head tax, or for sustenance or for burial may be sold without announcement.
llm_translation: Rav Ashei said: An'a and Rav Kahana signed the document of his mother's estate in Z'airah, that we may sell land for a cemetery without a public announcement; for the Nehardeans say: for a cemetery, for sustenance, and for a burial cave - we may sell without a public announcement.

hebrew_text: עַמְרָם צַבָּעָא אַפּוֹטְרוֹפָּא דְיַתְמֵי הֲוָה, אֲתוֹ קְרוֹבִים לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן, אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: קָא לָבֵישׁ וּמִכַּסֵּי מִיַּתְמֵי! אֲמַר לְהוּ: כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלִישְׁתַּמְעָן מִילֵּיהּ.
human_translation: Amram the dyer was a steward for orphans, relatives came before Rav Naḥman said to him: He dresses and covers from the orphans. said to them: in order that his words be heard,
llm_translation: Amram the dyer, his cloak was stolen, they came close to stand before Rav Nachman, they said to him: "He is wearing and covering with dyed garments!" He said to them: "So that his words should be fulfilled."

hebrew_text: קָאָכֵיל וְשָׁתֵי מִדִּידְהוּ, וְלָא אֲמִיד! אֵימוֹר מְצִיאָה אַשְׁכַּח. וְהָא קָא מַפְסֵיד! אֲמַר לְהוּ: אַיְיתוֹ לִי סָהֲדִי דְּמַפְסֵיד, וְאֵיסַלְּקִינֵּיהּ; דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא חַבְרִין מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב: אַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס דְּמַפְסֵיד, מְסַלְּקִינַן לֵיהּ. דְּאִיתְּמַר: אַפּוֹטְרוֹפָּא דְּמַפְסֵיד, רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַב: מְסַלְּקִינַן לֵיהּ; דְּבֵי רַבִּי שֵׁילָא אָמְרִי: לָא מְסַלְּקִינַן לֵיהּ. וְהִלְכְתָא: מְסַלְּקִינַן לֵיהּ.
human_translation: He eats and drinks from and is not rich Say he found a lost item, But he is damaging said to them: Bring me witnesses that he is damaging and I will remove him as our colleague Rav Huna said in the name of Rav a steward who damages removes him. As it was stated: a steward who damages Rav Huna Rav says: In the school of Rabbi Sheila they say: does not remove him. And the halakha removes him.
llm_translation: He would eat and drink from them, but not always! He said: I found a contradiction. But he is losing! He said to them: Bring me the witness who is losing, and we will dismiss him; for Rav Huna's colleagues in the name of Rav said: If a witness who is losing, we dismiss him. It was stated: If a witness who is losing, Rav said: we dismiss him; but the house of Rabbi Sheila said: we do not dismiss him. And the halakha is: we dismiss him.

hebrew_text: אַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס שֶׁמִּינָּהוּ אֲבִי יְתוֹמִים – יִשָּׁבַע: מַאי טַעְמָא? אִי לָאו דְּאִית לֵיהּ הֲנָאָה מִינֵּיהּ – לָא הֲוָה לֵיהּ אַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס; וּמִשּׁוּם שְׁבוּעָה לָא אָתֵי לְאִמְּנוֹעֵי.
human_translation: a steward who was appointed by the orphans’ father, he takes an oath What is the reason If had not received benefit from he would not have become a steward And he will not come to avoid because of an oath
llm_translation: Apotropos, whose name is Avi Yetomim - Yishava: What is the reason? If he does not have any benefit from him - he would not be an Apotropos; and because an oath does not come to those who are trusted.

hebrew_text: מִינּוּהוּ בֵּית דִּין – לֹא יִשָּׁבַע: מִלְּתָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא דְּעָבֵיד לְבֵי דִינָא; וְאִי רָמֵית עֲלֵיהּ שְׁבוּעָה אָתֵי לְאִמְּנוֹעֵי.
human_translation: the court appointed him he is not take an oath. it is merely a favor that does for the court, And if you cast an oath, he will come to avoid
llm_translation: The court - not shall swear: matter in world it is that he does to the court; and if he evaded upon it an oath comes to the faithful.

hebrew_text: אַבָּא שָׁאוּל אוֹמֵר: חִילּוּף הַדְּבָרִים: מַאי טַעְמָא מִינּוּהוּ בֵּית דִּין – יִשָּׁבַע? בְּהַהִיא הֲנָאָה דְּקָא נָפֵיק עֲלֵיהּ קָלָא דְּאִינִישׁ מְהֵימְנָא הוּא – דְּהָא סָמֵיךְ עֲלֵיהּ בֵּי דִינָא – מִשּׁוּם שְׁבוּעָה לָא אָתֵי לְאִמְּנוֹעֵי.
human_translation: Abba Shaul says: The matters are reversed; What is the reason the court appointed he takes an oath? Since a certain benefit that publicity is generated about him that he is a trustworthy man, as the court relies upon him he will not come to avoid because of an oath
llm_translation: Abba Shaul says: The exchange of words: What is the reason that the court administers an oath to him? In that case where a light of trustworthiness emanates from him - for he relies on the court - due to the fact that an oath does not come to trustworthy individuals.

hebrew_text: מִינָּהוּ אֲבִי יְתוֹמִים, לֹא יִשָּׁבַע – מִילְּתָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא דְּעָבְדִי לַהֲדָדֵי, וְאִי רָמֵית עֲלֵיהּ שְׁבוּעָה – אָתֵי לְאִמְּנוֹעֵי. אָמַר רַב חָנָן בַּר אַמֵּי אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הִלְכְתָא כְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל.
human_translation: the orphans’ father appointed him not take an oath. It is merely a favor that do for each other. And if you cast an oath, he will come to avoid Rav Ḥanan bar Ami says Shmuel says: The halakha in accordance with Abba Shaul.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Regarding the matter of an orphan's father, he shall not swear - it is a common matter in the world that people swear falsely, and if you imposed an oath upon him, he will come to swear falsely. Rav Hanan bar Ammi said in the name of Shmuel: The halakha is like Abba Shaul."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: זֶה וָזֶה יִשָּׁבַע, וַהֲלָכָה כִּדְבָרָיו.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: this and that take an oath, and the halakha in accordance with his statement.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: This and that shall both swear, and the halakha follows his words.

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי רַב תַּחְלִיפָא בַּר מַעְרְבָא קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: אַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס שֶׁמִּינָּהוּ אֲבִי יְתוֹמִים – יִשָּׁבַע, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא נוֹשֵׂא שָׂכָר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אַתְּ אַיְיתֵת קַבָּא וְכָיְילַתְּ לֵיהּ? אֶלָּא אֵימָא: מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא כְּנוֹשֵׂא שָׂכָר.
human_translation: Rav Taḥalifa, from the West, taught before Rabbi Abbahu: a steward who was appointed by the father of the orphans, he takes an oath because he receives payment, said to him: Did you bring a kav and measure Rather, say because it is as if he received payment.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rav Tahalifa bar Ma'arva stood before Rabbi Avahu. Apotropos, who is called the father of orphans, should swear, because he receives payment. He said to him: Did you bring a measure and a basket for him? Rather say: because he receives payment.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַמְטַמֵּא, וְהַמְדַמֵּעַ, וְהַמְנַסֵּךְ; בְּשׁוֹגֵג – פָּטוּר, בְּמֵזִיד – חַיָּיב.
human_translation: one who renders impure, or one who mixes or one who pours unintentionally, exempt intentionally, liable
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: one who becomes impure, one who sheds tears, and one who pours a libation; if it was unintentional - exempt, if it was intentional - liable.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיתְּמַר: ״מְנַסֵּךְ״ – רַב אָמַר: מְנַסֵּךְ מַמָּשׁ, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: מְעָרֵב.
human_translation: It was stated pours Rav says: he actually pours And Shmuel says: he mixes
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara: "Menashech" - Rav said: Menashech literally, and Shmuel said: Me'arev. English translation: Gemara: "Menashech" - Rav said: Pouring libations literally, and Shmuel said: Mixing.

hebrew_text: מַאן דְּאָמַר מְעָרֵב, מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אָמַר מְנַסֵּךְ? אָמַר לָךְ: מְנַסֵּךְ – קָם לֵיהּ בִּדְרַבָּה מִינֵּיהּ.
human_translation: the one who says mixing, what is the reason did not say pouring? He said to you: one who pours receives the greater
llm_translation: One who says "me'arev," what is the reason he does not say "menashech"? He said to you: "menashech" - he arose to him in his argument.

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ, כִּדְרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה – דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: מִשְּׁעַת הַגְבָּהָה הוּא דִּקְנָה; מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּנַפְשׁוֹ לָא הָוֵי עַד שְׁעַת נִיסּוּךְ.
human_translation: And the other in accordance with of Rabbi Yirmeya, as Rabbi Yirmeya says: acquires from the time that he lifts he does not become liable to death until he pours
llm_translation: And the other, like Rabbi Yirmiyah - for Rabbi Yirmiyah said: From the moment of elevation he acquires; he is liable for his life until the time of libation.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר מְנַסֵּךְ, מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אָמַר מְעָרֵב? אָמַר לָךְ: מְעָרֵב
human_translation: And according to the one who says pouring, what is the reason did not say mixing? said to you: Mixing
llm_translation: And for the one who says "mixing," what is the reason he did not say "mixing"? He said to you: "mixing."

hebrew_text: הַיְינוּ ״מְדַמֵּעַ״.
human_translation: is mixing
llm_translation: This is "medamea."

hebrew_text: וְאִידָּךְ – קְנָסָא הוּא, וּמִקְּנָסָא לָא יָלְפִינַן.
human_translation: And the other is a fine. And we do not derive from a fine
llm_translation: And the other opinion - it is a penalty, and from a penalty we do not derive.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּיָלֵיף קְנָסָא מִקְּנָסָא – כֹּל הָנֵי לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: And according to the one who derive a fine from a fine why do all these
llm_translation: And for one who differentiates between a penalty of a fine from a penalty of lashes - all these, why do I need them?

hebrew_text: צְרִיכָא; דְּאִי תְּנָא מְטַמֵּא; אִי תְּרוּמָה – הֲוָה אָמֵינָא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא מַפְסֵיד לַהּ לִגְמָרֵי, וְאִי מְטַמֵּא חוּלִּין – מִשּׁוּם דְּאָסוּר לִגְרוֹם טוּמְאָה לְחוּלִּין שֶׁבְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל; אֲבָל מְדַמֵּעַ – אֵימָא לָא.
human_translation: necessary, as, had taught renders impure, If teruma I would say because he ruined it entirely, And if renders non-sacred impure, because it is prohibited to cause impurity to non-sacred in Eretz Yisrael. But mixes say not
llm_translation: The matter is necessary; for if one teaches that it renders impure, if it is Terumah - I would say it is because he is causing it to be completely lost, and if it renders impure ordinary food - it is because it is forbidden to cause impurity to ordinary food in the land of Israel; but if it is Dam Me'ah - I would say no.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן מְדַמֵּעַ – מִשּׁוּם דִּשְׁכִיחַ, אֲבָל מְטַמֵּא, דְּלָא שְׁכִיחַ – אֵימָא לָא.
human_translation: And had taught us mixes because is a common But renders impure, is uncommon, say not
llm_translation: "And if we were to hear 'from tears' - because it is common, but 'from impurity,' since it is not common - I might say no."

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן מְטַמֵּא וּמְדַמֵּעַ – מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא קִים לֵיהּ בִּדְרַבָּה מִינֵּיהּ,
human_translation: And had taught us renders impure and mixes because there no receives the greater
llm_translation: And if we were to say "he becomes impure and sheds tears" - because it does not stand to reason according to his opinion,

hebrew_text: אֲבָל מְנַסֵּךְ, דְּקִים לֵיהּ בִּדְרַבָּה מִינֵּיהּ – אֵימָא לָא; קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן – כִּדְרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה.
human_translation: But one who pours where receives the greater say not teaches us in accordance with Rabbi Yirmeya,
llm_translation: But if one pours a libation, if it is established in his heart from his own accord - say it is not; he is teaching us - like Rabbi Yirmeya.

hebrew_text: וּלְהָא דְּתָנֵי אֲבוּהּ דְּרַבִּי אָבִין: בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה הָיוּ אוֹמְרִים הַמְטַמֵּא וְהַמְנַסֵּךְ, חָזְרוּ לוֹמַר אַף הַמְדַמֵּעַ, כֹּל הָנֵי לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: And according to this that the father of Rabbi Avin taught Initially would say one who renders impure and one who pours they returned to say that even one who mixes why do all these
llm_translation: And for that which it was taught in the house of Rabbi Avin: Initially they would say one who renders impure and one who pours a libation, they returned to say also one who causes to weep, why do I need all of these?

hebrew_text: צְרִיכָא; דְּאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן מְטַמֵּא – מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא קִים לֵיהּ בִּדְרַבָּה מִינֵּיהּ; אֲבָל מְנַסֵּךְ, דְּקִים לֵיהּ בִּדְרַבָּה מִינֵּיהּ – אֵימָא לָא;
human_translation: necessary, as, had taught us renders impure, because there no receives the greater But pours where receives the greater say not
llm_translation: The matter is this: for if we were to hear that it renders impure – because it does not establish itself in its own right; but regarding libations, which do establish themselves in their own right – why not say that it does not?

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן מְנַסֵּךְ – מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא מַפְסֵיד לֵיהּ לִגְמָרֵי; אֲבָל מְטַמֵּא, דְּלָא מַפְסֵיד לֵיהּ לִגְמָרֵי – אֵימָא לָא;
human_translation: And had taught us pours because he ruined it entirely, But one who renders impure, does not ruin it entirely, say not
llm_translation: And if we were to say "me'nassech" - because it causes it to be completely lost; but if it becomes impure, since it does not cause it to be completely lost - we might say no.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַשְׁמְעִינַן הָנֵי תַּרְתֵּי – מִשּׁוּם דְּהֶפְסֵד מְרוּבֶּה; אֲבָל מְדַמֵּעַ, דְּהֶפְסֵד מוּעָט – אֵימָא לָא; צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And had taught us these two because a substantial loss. But mixes where loss is minimal say not necessary.
llm_translation: And if we were to hear those two - because of the greater loss; but if it is a small loss, we might say no; it is necessary.

hebrew_text: אָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: דְּבַר תּוֹרָה – אֶחָד שׁוֹגֵג, וְאֶחָד מֵזִיד – חַיָּיב. מַאי טַעְמָא? הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק.
human_translation: Ḥizkiyya says: By Torah law, whether unintentionally or intentionally, liable What is the reason damage that is not evident is categorized damage.
llm_translation: Hizkiyah said: A matter of Torah - whether unwittingly or intentionally - one is liable. What is the reason? Damage that is not recognizable, damage.

hebrew_text: וּמַה טַּעַם אָמְרוּ בְּשׁוֹגֵג פָּטוּר – כְּדֵי שֶׁיּוֹדִיעוֹ.
human_translation: And what is the reason said unintentionally exempt? so that will inform
llm_translation: And what is the reason they said regarding unintentional transgression one is exempt - in order to inform him.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ בְּמֵזִיד נָמֵי! הַשְׁתָּא לְאוֹזוֹקֵי קָא מְכַוֵּין, אוֹדוֹעֵי לָא מוֹדַע לֵיהּ?!
human_translation: If so even intentionally, Now, it was his intention to cause damage, will he not inform him?
llm_translation: Thus, even if intentionally, it is considered as if done unintentionally! Now, is he directing his arrows or not directing them, is it not known to him?!

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: דְּבַר תּוֹרָה – אֶחָד שׁוֹגֵג, וְאֶחָד מֵזִיד – פָּטוּר. מַאי טַעְמָא? הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר – לָא שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק. וּמַה טַּעַם אָמְרוּ בְּמֵזִיד חַיָּיב – שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד הוֹלֵךְ וּמְטַמֵּא טׇהֳרוֹתָיו שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, וְאוֹמֵר ״פָּטוּר אֲנִי״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: By Torah law, whether unintentionally or intentionally, exempt What is the reason damage that is not evident is not categorized damage. And what is the reason said intentionally liable? that each and every person should not go and render impure the other person’s pure and say: I am exempt
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: A matter of Torah - one unintentional, and one intentional - exempt. What is the reason? Damage that is not recognizable - is not called damage. And what is the reason they said intentional is liable - so that not everyone goes and contaminates the purities of his fellow, and says, "I am exempt."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: הַכֹּהֲנִים שֶׁפִּגְּלוּ בַּמִּקְדָּשׁ, מְזִידִים – חַיָּיבִין; וְתָנֵי עֲלַהּ: מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הָעוֹלָם.
human_translation: we learned priests who disqualified an offering through improper intention in the Temple, intentionally, they are liable And it is taught with regard to for the betterment of the world,
llm_translation: We learned in the Mishnah: Priests who were negligent in the Temple, intentionally - are liable; and it was taught about this: Because of the rectification of the world.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק, הַאי ״שׁוֹגְגִין פְּטוּרִין מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הָעוֹלָם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: And if you say damage that is not evident is categorized damage, it should have that unintentionally they are exempt due to the betterment of the world.
llm_translation: And if you say that Hezekiah, whose name is not recognized as Hezekiah, this "those who sin inadvertently are exempt because of the betterment of the world" - who requires it!

hebrew_text: הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: מְזִידִין – חַיָּיבִין; הָא שׁוֹגְגִין – פְּטוּרִין מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הָעוֹלָם.
human_translation: That is also what is saying, intentionally, they are liable, but unintentionally, exempt. for the betterment of the world.
llm_translation: Thus he said: Intentional transgressors - liable; but those who transgress inadvertently - exempt due to the principle of the betterment of the world.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: הָעוֹשֶׂה מְלָאכָה בְּמֵי חַטָּאת וּבְפָרַת חַטָּאת, פָּטוּר מִדִּינֵי אָדָם וְחַיָּיב בְּדִינֵי שָׁמַיִם. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק, בְּדִינֵי אָדָם נָמֵי לְחַיֵּיב!
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar raised an objection one who performs a task with the water of purification, or with the heifer of purification, exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. And if you say damage that is not evident is categorized damage, according to human laws he should also be liable.
llm_translation: Rebbe Elazar raises an objection: One who performs labor in the waters of the sin-offering and in the ashes of the sin-offering is exempt from human judgment but liable to divine judgment. And if you say that damage caused by something whose name is not recognizable as damage, in human judgment, it is considered as causing damage!

hebrew_text: הוּא מוֹתֵיב לַהּ – וְהוּא מְפָרֵק לַהּ: פָּרָה – שֶׁהִכְנִיסָהּ לְרִבְקָה עַל מְנָת שֶׁתִּינַק וְתָדוּשׁ; מֵי חַטָּאת – שֶׁשָּׁקַל בָּהֶן מִשְׁקָלוֹת.
human_translation: he, raised the objection and he resolved it: heifer, that he placed it in a pen [ lirvaka ] so that it would nurse and would thresh, water of purification, that he weighed weights with
llm_translation: He places it before her - and he explains it to her: a cow - that she brought in for Rebecca in order for her to nurse and to wash; sin-offering water - from which he weighed out its weights.

hebrew_text: וְהָאָמַר רָבָא: מֵי חַטָּאת
human_translation: But doesn’t Rava say: Water of purification
llm_translation: And Rava said: "The water of the sin offering."

hebrew_text: שֶׁשָּׁקַל בָּהֶן מִשְׁקָלוֹת, כְּשֵׁרָה! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּגוּפָן, הָא בִּכְנֶגְדָּן.
human_translation: with which he weighed weights fit? not difficult: This with itself, this against
llm_translation: He who weighed with them weights, valid! Not difficult: here in their body, here corresponding to them.

hebrew_text: בְּגוּפָן – מַעֲשֶׂה קָא עָבֵיד בְּהוּ; וְאִי הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק, בְּדִינֵי אָדָם נָמֵי לְחַיֵּיב! אֶלָּא אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי בִּכְנֶגְדָּן; וְלָא קַשְׁיָא – הָא דְּאַסַּח דַּעְתֵּיהּ. הָא דְּלָא אַסַּח דַּעְתֵּיהּ.
human_translation: with itself, he performs task with it, and if damage that is not evident is categorized damage, he should also be liable according to human laws Rather, this and that against and not difficult: This where his attention was diverted that where his attention was not diverted,
llm_translation: In their body - an action he is doing with them; and if the damage is such that his name is not recognizable, in the laws of man, he is deemed liable! Rather, both are against them; and it is not difficult - this one who has lost his mind. This one who has not lost his mind.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב פָּפָּא: גָּזַל מַטְבֵּעַ, וְנִפְסַל; תְּרוּמָה, וְנִטְמֵאת; חָמֵץ, וְעָבַר עָלָיו הַפֶּסַח; אוֹמֵר לוֹ: ״הֲרֵי שֶׁלְּךָ לְפָנֶיךָ״.
human_translation: Rav Pappa raises an objection one robbed of a coin and was rendered invalid teruma and it became impure, leavened bread and Passover elapsed over it, can say to That which is yours is before you.
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Pappa asked: If one stole a coin and it became disqualified; if one separated terumah and it became ritually impure; if one left leavened bread and Passover arrived, and it became prohibited, one says to him: "Here is yours before you."

hebrew_text: וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק, הַאי גַּזְלָן הוּא, מָמוֹנָא מְעַלְּיָא בָּעֵי שַׁלּוֹמֵי! תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: And if you say damage that is not evident is categorized damage, this is a robber, he should be required to pay full compensation a conclusive refutation,
llm_translation: If you say "Hezek" whose name is not recognized as Hezek, this is a thief, money above requires peace! Goodbye.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: הַמְטַמֵּא וְהַמְדַמֵּעַ וְהַמְנַסֵּךְ, אֶחָד שׁוֹגֵג וְאֶחָד מֵזִיד – חַיָּיב, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּשׁוֹגֵג – פָּטוּר, בְּמֵזִיד – חַיָּיב.
human_translation: Let us say parallel to tanna’im , one who renders impure, or one who mixes or one who pours whether unintentionally or intentionally, liable the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: unintentionally, exempt; intentionally, liable
llm_translation: Let us say according to the Tannaim: One who becomes impure, one who causes others to become impure, and one who pours a libation, whether unintentionally or intentionally - is liable, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: If it was unintentional - he is exempt, if it was intentional - he is liable.

hebrew_text: מַאי, לָאו בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי – דְּמָר סָבַר: הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק; וּמָר סָבַר: לָא שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק?
human_translation: What, is it not they disagree about this As Sage, holds damage that is not evident is categorized damage. And Sage, holds is not categorized damage,
llm_translation: What, is it not in this that they disagree - for Mar holds: a blemish that is not recognizable by its name is not a blemish; and Rav holds: is it not a blemish by its name?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא הֶיזֵּק שֶׁאֵינוֹ נִיכָּר לָא שְׁמֵיהּ הֶיזֵּק; וְהָכָא בְּקָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד קָא מִיפַּלְגִי – דְּמָר סָבַר: קָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד; וּמָר סָבַר: לֹא קָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said everyone, agrees that damage that is not evident is not categorized damage. And here, they disagree with regard to penalize an unintentional due to an intentional As Sage, holds penalized an unintentional due to an intentional And Sage, holds they did not penalize an unintentional due to an intentional
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: In all the world, a blemish that is not recognizable, its name is not a blemish. And here, in the case of one who mistakenly brings a sin-offering, the Mishna and Tosefta are in dispute - for one Sage holds: If they brought it mistakenly, then it is a sin-offering; and the other Sage holds: They did not bring it mistakenly, then it is a sin-offering.

hebrew_text: וְרָמֵי דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר אַדְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, וְרָמֵי דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אַדְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה – דְּתַנְיָא: הַמְבַשֵּׁל בְּשַׁבָּת; בְּשׁוֹגֵג – יֵאָכֵל, בְּמֵזִיד – לֹא יֵאָכֵל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּשׁוֹגֵג – יֵאָכֵל לְמוֹצָאֵי שַׁבָּת, בְּמֵזִיד – לֹא יֵאָכֵל עוֹלָמִית.
human_translation: But raise a contradiction between of Rabbi Meir and of Rabbi Meir; and raise a contradiction between of Rabbi Yehuda and of Rabbi Yehuda. as it is taught one who cooks on Shabbat, unintentionally, he may eat intentionally, he may not eat the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: unintentionally, he may eat at the conclusion of Shabbat. intentionally, he may never eat
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection against Rabbi Meir from Rabbi Meir, and raises an objection against Rabbi Yehuda from Rabbi Yehuda - as it was taught: One who cooks on Shabbat; if it was unintentional - it may be eaten, if it was intentional - it may not be eaten, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: If it was unintentional - it may be eaten until the end of Shabbat, if it was intentional - it may not be eaten forever.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הַסַּנְדְּלָר אוֹמֵר: בְּשׁוֹגֵג, יֵאָכֵל לְמוֹצָאֵי שַׁבָּת – לַאֲחֵרִים, וְלֹא לוֹ; בְּמֵזִיד, לֹא יֵאָכֵל עוֹלָמִית – לֹא לוֹ, וְלֹא לַאֲחֵרִים. קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר אַדְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, קַשְׁיָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אַדְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה!
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar says: unintentionally, may be eaten at the conclusion of Shabbat by others, but not by him, intentionally, may never be eaten, neither by him nor by others. a contradiction between of Rabbi Meir and of Rabbi Meir, a contradiction between of Rabbi Yehuda and of Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan the Sandal-maker says: In unintentional violation, one may eat the food prepared for the conclusion of the Sabbath – for others, and not for himself; in intentional violation, one may never eat the food prepared – neither for himself, nor for others. The difficulty of Rabbi Meir to Rabbi Meir, the difficulty of Rabbi Yehuda to Rabbi Yehuda!

hebrew_text: דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר אַדְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר לָא קַשְׁיָא – כִּי קָנֵיס, בִּדְרַבָּנַן; בִּדְאוֹרָיְיתָא לָא קָנֵיס.
human_translation: between of Rabbi Meir and of Rabbi Meir, When penalizes a rabbinic law, a Torah law, he does not penalize
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir said: Rabbi Meir did not have a difficulty - when he acquired, it was with the Rabbis; with the Torah, he did not acquire.

hebrew_text: וְהָא מְנַסֵּךְ דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הוּא, וְקָא קָנֵיס! מִשּׁוּם חוּמְרָא דַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, קָנֵס לֵיהּ.
human_translation: But isn’t pouring by Torah law, and penalizes Due to the severity idol worship, penalizes
llm_translation: And this one who pours the offering is of biblical origin, and he has acquired! Because of the severity of foreign worship, he acquires it.

hebrew_text: דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אַדְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה לָא קַשְׁיָא – כִּי לָא קָנֵיס, בִּדְרַבָּנַן; בִּדְאוֹרָיְיתָא – קָנֵיס. וְהָא מְנַסֵּךְ דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, וְלָא קָנֵיס! מִשּׁוּם חוּמְרָא דַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה. מִיבְדָּל בְּדִילִי מִינֵּיהּ.
human_translation: no contradiction of Rabbi Yehuda and of Rabbi Yehuda. When does not penalize a rabbinic law. a Torah law, penalizes But isn’t pouring by Torah law, and does not penalize Due to the severity idol worship avoid it
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: It is not difficult - when it comes to Rabbinic law, he did not acquire the status of a Nazirite; when it comes to Torah law, he acquired the status of a Nazirite. But the one who pours a drink offering according to Torah law, and did not acquire the status of a Nazirite! Due to the severity of foreign worship. Let him separate himself from it.

hebrew_text: וְרָמֵי דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר אַדְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר בִּדְאוֹרָיְיתָא – דְּתַנְיָא: הַנּוֹטֵעַ בַּשַּׁבָּת, בְּשׁוֹגֵג – יְקַיֵּים; בְּמֵזִיד – יַעֲקֹר; וּבַשְּׁבִיעִית – בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד יַעֲקֹר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: But raise a contradiction between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Meir by Torah law, as it is taught one who plants on Shabbat, unintentionally, he may keep intentionally, it must be uprooted. And during the Sabbatical whether unintentionally or intentionally, it must be uprooted; the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: The statement of Rabbi Meir is in accordance with Rabbi Meir in the Torah, as it was taught: One who plants on Shabbat, if unintentional - it will take root; if intentional - it will be uprooted; and in the seventh year - whether unintentional or intentional, it will be uprooted. These are the words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בַּשְּׁבִיעִית – בְּשׁוֹגֵג יְקַיֵּים, בְּמֵזִיד יַעֲקֹר; וּבַשַּׁבָּת – בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד, יַעֲקֹר.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: in the Sabbatical unintentionally, he may keep intentionally, it must be uprooted. And on Shabbat, whether unintentionally or intentionally, it must be uprooted.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: In the seventh year - if done unintentionally, it is valid; if done intentionally, it is nullified. And regarding Shabbat - whether done unintentionally or intentionally, it is nullified.

hebrew_text: וּלְטַעְמָיךְ, תִּקָּשֶׁה לָךְ הִיא גּוּפַהּ – מִכְּדֵי הָא דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא וְהָא דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מַאי שְׁנָא שַׁבָּת וּמַאי שְׁנָא שְׁבִיעִית?
human_translation: And according to your reasoning, raise a contradiction this itself. Since this is by Torah law and this is by Torah law, what is different about Shabbat and what is different about the Sabbatical
llm_translation: And according to your reasoning, it will be difficult for you, as it is its essence - because of what is the difference between that which is from the Torah and that which is from the Torah, what is the difference between Shabbat and what is the difference between the seventh year?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָתָם, כִּדְקָתָנֵי טַעְמָא – אָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר: מִפְּנֵי מָה אֲנִי אוֹמֵר בַּשַּׁבָּת – בְּשׁוֹגֵג יְקַיֵּים, בְּמֵזִיד יַעֲקֹר; וּבַשְּׁבִיעִית – בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד יַעֲקֹר? מִפְּנֵי שֶׁיִּשְׂרָאֵל מוֹנִין לַשְּׁבִיעִית,
human_translation: Rather, there the reason as is taught Rabbi Meir said: For what do I say: on Shabbat unintentionally, he may keep intentionally, it must be uprooted; but in the Sabbatical whether unintentionally or intentionally, it must be uprooted? because Jews count from the Sabbatical
llm_translation: Rather there, as it is taught in the reason - Rabbi Meir said: For what reason do I say regarding Shabbat - for unintentional acts one is liable, for intentional acts one is exempt; and regarding the seventh year - whether unintentional or intentional one is exempt? Because the Israelites are counted for the seventh year.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין מוֹנִין לְשַׁבָּתוֹת.
human_translation: But they do not count from Shabbat,
llm_translation: And we do not count for Sabbaths.

hebrew_text: דָּבָר אַחֵר: נֶחְשְׁדוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל הַשְּׁבִיעִית, וְלֹא נֶחְשְׁדוּ עַל הַשַּׁבָּתוֹת.
human_translation: Alternatively, Jews are suspected of the Sabbatical but they are not suspected of Shabbat.
llm_translation: Another matter: The Israelites were suspected regarding the seventh year, but they were not suspected regarding the Sabbaths.

hebrew_text: מַאי ״דָּבָר אַחֵר״? הָכִי קָאָמַר: וְכִי תֵּימָא שַׁבָּת נָמֵי, זִימְנִין דְּמִיקְּלַע יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים – בְּשַׁבָּת, דְּאִי נָטַע הַהוּא יוֹמָא הוּא דְּסָלְקָא לֵיהּ שַׁתָּא, וְאִי לָא – לָא סָלְקָא לֵיהּ שַׁתָּא,
human_translation: What alternatively? This is what is saying: And if you would say also Shabbat, times the thirtieth day falls on Shabbat. As, if he planted on that day, counts for him as year And if not it does not count for him as year.
llm_translation: "What is 'another matter' (davar acher)?" This is what he is saying: And if you say it is also about Shabbat, sometimes when the thirtieth day falls on Shabbat, for if that day is planted, it will produce a drink, but if not, it will not produce a drink.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע דָּבָר אַחֵר: נֶחְשְׁדוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל עַל הַשְּׁבִיעִית, וְלֹא נֶחְשְׁדוּ עַל הַשַּׁבָּתוֹת.
human_translation: Come hear alternatively, Jews are suspected of the Sabbatical but they are not suspected of Shabbat.
llm_translation: Come and hear another explanation: The Israelites were suspected regarding the seventh year, but they were not suspected regarding the Sabbaths.

hebrew_text: דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אַדְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה לָא קַשְׁיָא – בְּאַתְרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה חֲמִירָא לְהוּ שְׁבִיעִית.
human_translation: no contradiction of Rabbi Yehuda and of Rabbi Yehuda in Rabbi Yehuda’s place the Sabbatical was by them serious
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, it is not difficult - in the place of Rabbi Yehuda, he is stringent regarding the seventh year.

hebrew_text: דְּהָהוּא דַּאֲמַר לֵיהּ לַחֲבֵירוֹ: דַּיָּיר בַּר דַּיָּירְתָּא! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֲנָא לָא אָכְלִי פֵּירֵי דִשְׁבִיעִית כְּווֹתָךְ.
human_translation: that a certain who said to another Convert [ dayyar ], son of a convert. said to I don’t eat produce of the Sabbatical as you
llm_translation: The one who said to his fellow: "Enough, son of enough!" He said to him: "I did not eat the fruits of the seventh year as you did."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אָכַל תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה – מְשַׁלֵּם חוּלִּין טְהוֹרִין. שִׁילֵּם חוּלִּין טְמֵאִים, מַהוּ? אָמַר סוֹמְכוֹס מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מֵאִיר: בְּשׁוֹגֵג – תַּשְׁלוּמָיו תַּשְׁלוּמִין, בְּמֵזִיד – אֵין תַּשְׁלוּמָיו תַּשְׁלוּמִין. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה תַּשְׁלוּמָיו תַּשְׁלוּמִין, וְחוֹזֵר וּמְשַׁלֵּם חוּלִּין טְהוֹרִים.
human_translation: Come hear one partook of teruma , impure, he pays pure, non-sacred What is he paid impure, non-sacred Sumakhos said in the name of Rabbi Meir: unintentionally, his payment is valid. intentionally, his payment is not valid. And the Rabbis say: both this and that his payment is valid, he returns and pays pure, non-sacred
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who eats impure terumah - he pays with pure common produce. If he paid with impure common produce, what is the law? Simekos said in the name of Rabbi Meir: If it was unintentional - his payments are payments, if it was intentional - his payments are not payments. And the sages say: Whether it was unintentional or intentional, his payments are payments, and he must then repay with pure common produce.

hebrew_text: וְהָוֵינַן בַּהּ: בְּמֵזִיד – אַמַּאי אֵין תַּשְׁלוּמָיו תַּשְׁלוּמִין? תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה – דְּאָכֵיל מִינֵּיהּ מִידֵּי דְּלָא חֲזֵי לֵיהּ בִּימֵי טוּמְאָתוֹ, וְקָא מְשַׁלֵּם לֵיהּ מִידֵּי דַּחֲזֵי לֵיהּ בִּימֵי טוּמְאָתוֹ!
human_translation: And we discussed intentionally, why is his payment not valid? blessing should come upon him, as he partook of something that is not fit for during the days of his impurity, and he pays to him with something, which is fit for him during the days of his impurity.
llm_translation: And we ask in it: intentionally - why are his payments not payments? Let a blessing come upon him - for he is eating from his own, which he did not see in the days of his impurity, and he is paying him from what he did not see in the days of his impurity!

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ כְּדִי: חַסּוֹרֵי מְחַסְּרָא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: אָכַל תְּרוּמָה טְמֵאָה – מְשַׁלֵּם כָּל דְּהוּ. אָכַל תְּרוּמָה טְהוֹרָה – מְשַׁלֵּם חוּלִּין טְהוֹרִים. שִׁילֵּם חוּלִּין טְמֵאִין, מַהוּ? סוֹמְכוֹס אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי מֵאִיר: בְּשׁוֹגֵג – תַּשְׁלוּמָיו תַּשְׁלוּמִין, בְּמֵזִיד – אֵין תַּשְׁלוּמָיו תַּשְׁלוּמִין. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה – תַּשְׁלוּמָיו תַּשְׁלוּמִין, וְחוֹזֵר וּמְשַׁלֵּם חוּלִּין טְהוֹרִין.
human_translation: And Rava said, and some say it unattributed: is incomplete and this is what it is teaching: one partook of impure teruma , he can pay anything, he partook of pure teruma , he pays pure, non-sacred What is he paid impure, non-sacred Sumakhos said in the name of Rabbi Meir: unintentionally, his payment is valid. intentionally, his payment is not valid. And the Rabbis say: Both this and that his payment is valid, he returns and pays pure, non-sacred
llm_translation: And Rava said, and they said to him: as follows: lacking is lacking, and thus it was taught: one who eats impure terumah - he pays everything. One who eats pure terumah - he pays pure common food. If he paid impure common food, what is the law? Some say in the name of Rabbi Meir: if it was unintentional - his payments are payments, if it was intentional - his payments are not payments. And the sages say: whether it was unintentional or intentional - his payments are payments, and he goes back and pays pure common food.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִיקָא: הָכָא בְּקָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ (דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר סָבַר: לֹא קָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: קָנְסוּ)!
human_translation: And Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: Here, between penalized an unintentional due to an intentional Rabbi Meir holds they did not penalize an unintentional due to an intentional and the Rabbis say they penalized him.
llm_translation: And Rav Acha, son of Rav Ika, said: Here, in the case of one who was penalized unintentionally, there is a difference between them (Rabbi Meir holds: they were not penalized unintentionally, but intentionally, and the Sages say: they were penalized)!

hebrew_text: הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם – גַּבְרָא לְשַׁלּוֹמֵי קָא מִיכַּוֵּין, אֲנַן נֵיקוּם וְלִיקְנְסֵיהּ?!
human_translation: How can be compared? There, the man intends to pay; should we arise and penalize him?
llm_translation: So now?! There - a man for peace is preparing, and we should go and provoke him?!

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: דָּם שֶׁנִּטְמָא, וּזְרָקוֹ; בְּשׁוֹגֵג – הוּרְצָה, בְּמֵזִיד – לֹא הוּרְצָה.
human_translation: Come hear blood that became impure and sprinkled it unintentionally, accepted intentionally, is not accepted.
llm_translation: Come and hear: Blood that became impure, and one sprinkled it; if it was done unintentionally - it is accepted, if it was done intentionally - it is not accepted.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רַבִּי מֵאִיר: הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם – גַּבְרָא לְכַפּוֹרֵי קָא מְכַוֵּין, אֲנַן נֵיקוּם וְנִקְנְסֵיהּ?!
human_translation: Rabbi Meir said to you: How can be compared? There, the person intends to atone; should we arise and penalize him?
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir said to you: Is this the case now?! There - a man is aiming for the village of Kapori, shall we take revenge and penalize him?!

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הַמְעַשֵּׂר בַּשַּׁבָּת; בְּשׁוֹגֵג – יֹאכַל, בְּמֵזִיד – לֹא יֹאכַל. הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם – גַּבְרָא לְתַקּוֹנֵי קָא מִיכַּוֵּין, אֲנַן לֵיקוּם וְלִיקְנְסֵיהּ?!
human_translation: Come hear one who tithes on Shabbat, unintentionally, he may consume intentionally, he may not consume How can be compared? There, the man intends to repair should we arise and penalize him?
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who tithes on Shabbat; if unintentional – may eat, if intentional – may not eat. Is it so now?! There - a man is involved in rectifying matters, shall we then rise and gather him in?!

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הַמַּטְבִּיל כֵּלִים בַּשַּׁבָּת; בְּשׁוֹגֵג – יִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בָּהֶן, בְּמֵזִיד – לֹא יִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בָּהֶן! הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם – גַּבְרָא לְטַהוֹרֵי מָאנֵי קָא מִיכַּוֵּין, אֲנַן לֵיקוּם וְלִיקְנְסֵיהּ?!
human_translation: Come hear one who immerses utensils on Shabbat, unintentionally, he may use them. intentionally, he may not use them. How can be compared? There, the man intends to purify the utensils; should we arise and penalize him?
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who immerses utensils on Shabbat; if unintentional – he may use them, if intentional – he may not use them! Is it so now?! There – a man is preparing for the pure, why should we rise and enter into it?!

hebrew_text: וְרָמֵי דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אַדְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה – בִּדְרַבָּנַן, דְּתַנְיָא:
human_translation: And they raised a contradiction between of Rabbi Yehuda and of Rabbi Yehuda by rabbinic law. As it is taught
llm_translation: And the students of Rabbi Yehuda argue with Rabbi Yehuda - as it was taught:

hebrew_text: נָפְלוּ וְנִתְפַּצְּעוּ; אֶחָד שׁוֹגֵג, וְאֶחָד מֵזִיד – לֹא יַעֲלוּ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמְרִים: בְּשׁוֹגֵג – יַעֲלוּ, בְּמֵזִיד – לֹא יַעֲלוּ.
human_translation: they fell were broken whether unintentionally or intentionally, they are not nullified the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say: unintentionally, they are nullified, intentionally, they are not nullified.
llm_translation: They fell and were shattered; one unintentionally, and one intentionally - they may not ascend, the words of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say: If it was unintentional - they may ascend, if it was intentional - they may not ascend.

hebrew_text: וְהָא הָכָא, דְּמִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא חַד בִּתְרֵי בָּטֵל, וְרַבָּנַן הוּא דִּגְזוּר, וְקָא קָנֵיס רַבִּי יְהוּדָה! הָתָם הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, מִשּׁוּם דְּאָתֵי לְאִיעָרוֹמֵי.
human_translation: But here, by Torah law is nullified one in two, and the Sages who decreed And Rabbi Yehuda penalizes There, this is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda, due to that he will come to employ artifice
llm_translation: Here, since from the Torah one is nullified in two, and it is the Rabbis who decreed, and Rabbi Yehuda agrees! There, that is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda, because it leads to suspicion.

hebrew_text: וְרָמֵי דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אַדְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי – דִּתְנַן: נְטִיעָה שֶׁל עׇרְלָה וְשֶׁל כִּלְאֵי הַכֶּרֶם שֶׁנִּתְעָרְבוּ בִּנְטִיעוֹת אֲחֵרוֹת, הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יְלַקֵּט. וְאִם לִיקֵּט – יַעֲלוּ בְּאֶחָד וּמָאתַיִם, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יִתְכַּוֵּין לְלַקֵּט.
human_translation: And they raised a contradiction between of Rabbi Yosei and of Rabbi Yosei, as we learned a sapling of orla or of diverse kinds in a vineyard, became intermingled with other he may not gather And if he gathered is nullified one in two hundred provided that he did not intend to gather
llm_translation: And the statement of Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yosei - as we learned: A planting of uncircumcised trees and of mixed vineyard species that became mixed with other plantings, this one should not gather. And if one did gather - they shall pay one hundred and two hundred, provided that they did not intend to gather.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: אַף הַמִּתְכַּוֵּין לְלַקֵּט – יַעֲלוּ בְּאֶחָד וּמָאתַיִם!
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: Even if he intentionally gathered is nullified one in two hundred
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei says: Even one who intends to gather - they should ascend with one hundred and two hundred!

hebrew_text: הָא אִתְּמַר עֲלַהּ, אָמַר רָבָא: חֲזָקָה אֵין אָדָם אוֹסֵר אֶת כַּרְמוֹ בִּנְטִיעָה אַחַת. וְכֵן כִּי אֲתָא רָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: חֲזָקָה אֵין אָדָם אוֹסֵר אֶת כַּרְמוֹ בִּנְטִיעָה אַחַת.
human_translation: Wasn’t it stated with regard to Rava says: a presumption a person does not render his entire vineyard forbidden for the sake of one sapling. And similarly, when Ravin came Rabbi Yoḥanan says: a presumption a person does not render his vineyard forbidden for the sake of one sapling,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises a contradiction: Rava said: It is established that a person does not uproot his vineyard after planting it. And similarly, when Ravin came, he said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: It is established that a person does not uproot his vineyard after planting it.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַכֹּהֲנִים שֶׁפִּגְּלוּ בַּמִּקְדָּשׁ, מְזִידִין – חַיָּיבִין.
human_translation: priests disqualified an offering with improper intention in the Temple, intentionally, they are liable
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "Kohanim who were negligent in the Temple, intentionally - are liable."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הָיָה עוֹשֶׂה עִמּוֹ בִּטְהָרוֹת, וְאָמַר לוֹ: טְהָרוֹת שֶׁעָשִׂיתִי עִמְּךָ, נִטְמְאוּ; הָיָה עוֹשֶׂה עִמּוֹ בִּזְבָחִים, וְאָמַר לוֹ: זְבָחִים שֶׁעָשִׂיתִי עִמְּךָ, נִתְפַּגְּלוּ – נֶאֱמָן. אֲבָל אָמַר לוֹ: טְהָרוֹת שֶׁעָשִׂיתִי עִמְּךָ בְּיוֹם פְּלוֹנִי נִטְמְאוּ, וּזְבָחִים שֶׁעָשִׂיתִי עִמְּךָ בְּיוֹם פְּלוֹנִי נִתְפַּגְּלוּ – אֵינוֹ נֶאֱמָן.
human_translation: The Sages taught was preparing ritually pure with and he said to him: The ritually pure that I prepared with you became ritually impure, he was preparing sacrifices with and he said to him: The sacrifices that I prepared with you became disqualified due to improper intention, deemed credible But he said to The ritually pure that I prepared with you on such and such a day became ritually impure, the sacrifices that I prepared with you on such and such a day became disqualified due to improper intention, he is not deemed credible.
llm_translation: The sages taught: If one was engaging with him in matters of purification, and he said to him: The purifications that I performed with you have become impure; if one was engaging with him in matters of sacrifices, and he said to him: The sacrifices that I performed with you have been revealed as blemished - he is trustworthy. However, if he said to him: The purifications that I performed with you on such and such a day have become impure, and the sacrifices that I performed with you on such and such a day have been revealed as blemished - he is not trustworthy.

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא רֵישָׁא, וּמַאי שְׁנָא סֵיפָא? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: כֹּל שֶׁבְּיָדוֹ – נֶאֱמָן.
human_translation: What is different the first clause and what is different the latter clause, Abaye says As long as it is in his power deemed credible.
llm_translation: What is different about the beginning, and what is different about the end? Abaye said: Anything that is in his possession is trustworthy.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: כְּגוֹן דְּאַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ וְלָא אֲמַר לֵיהּ וְלָא מִידֵּי, וּלְבָתַר הָכִי אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rava said: where he found him and told him nothing and afterward he found him and told him
llm_translation: Rava said: For example, he found it but did not say to him, and not immediately, and afterwards he found it and said to him.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא דַּאֲמַר לֵיהּ לְחַבְרֵיהּ: טְהָרוֹת שֶׁעָשִׂיתִי עִמְּךָ בְּיוֹם פְּלוֹנִי – נִטְמְאוּ, אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי אַמֵּי, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שׁוּרַת הַדִּין אֵינוֹ נֶאֱמָן. אָמַר לְפָנָיו רַבִּי אַסִּי: רַבִּי, אַתָּה אוֹמֵר כֵּן? הָכִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: מָה אֶעֱשֶׂה שֶׁהַתּוֹרָה הֶאֱמִינַתּוּ.
human_translation: a certain who said to another: The ritually pure that I prepared with you on such and such a day became ritually impure. came before Rabbi Ami, said to him: in principle, is not deemed credible. Rabbi Asi said before him: My teacher, do you say this? So said Rabbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rabbi Yosei: What can I do that the Torah deemed him credible
llm_translation: That one who said to his companions: "I made pure with you on such and such a day" - they became impure. He came before Rabbi Ammi, he said to him: The ox of the law is not trustworthy. Rabbi Assi said before him: Rabbi, do you say so? Thus said Rabbi Yochanan in the name of Rabbi Yose: What shall I do that the Torah trusted him.

hebrew_text: הֵיכָן הֶאֱמִינַתּוּ? אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק בַּר בִּיסְנָא: כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים יוֹכִיחַ, דְּכִי אָמַר פִּגּוּל – מְהֵימַן; וּמְנָא יָדְעִינַן? וְהָכְתִיב: ״וְכׇל אָדָם לֹא יִהְיֶה בְּאֹהֶל מוֹעֵד״! אֶלָּא לָאו מִשּׁוּם דִּמְהֵימַן?
human_translation: Where deem him credible? Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Bisna says: The High Priest on Yom Kippur will prove as when says improper intent, deemed credible. And from where do we know But isn’t it written: “And no man shall be in the Tent of Meeting Rather, is it not because deemed credible
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Where did you find his trustworthiness? Rabbi Yitzchak bar Bisna said: The High Priest on Yom Kippur shall prove, for when it says "pigul" - he is believed; and how do we know? And it is written: "And no man shall be in the Tent of Meeting"! Rather, is it not because he is believed?

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא דִּשְׁמַעְנֵיהּ דְּפַגֵּיל! אִי לָאו דִּמְהֵימַן, אַף עַל גַּב דִּשְׁמַעְנֵיהּ נָמֵי לָא מְהֵימַן, דְּדִלְמָא לְבָתַר הָכִי קָאָמַר.
human_translation: But perhaps we heard that he disqualified with improper intention, Were not deemed credible even if we heard him would also not be deemed credible. that perhaps afterward he said
llm_translation: Perhaps he heard that he was negligent! If he is not trustworthy, even though he heard, he is also not trustworthy, for perhaps he is saying this afterwards.

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא דַּחֲזֵינֵיהּ בְּפִישְׁפָּשׁ? קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: But perhaps we saw through a small door, difficult
llm_translation: And perhaps we see it in the Pishtash? Difficult.

hebrew_text: הַהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי אַמֵּי, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה שֶׁכָּתַבְתִּי לִפְלוֹנִי, אַזְכָּרוֹת שֶׁלּוֹ לֹא כְּתַבְתִּים לִשְׁמָן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה בְּיַד מִי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בְּיַד לוֹקֵחַ. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נֶאֱמָן אַתָּה לְהַפְסִיד שְׂכָרְךָ, וְאִי אַתָּה נֶאֱמָן לְהַפְסִיד סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה.
human_translation: a certain who came before Rabbi Ami said to him: the Torah scroll that I wrote for so-and-so, I did not write the mentions with the proper intention said to him: Torah scroll in whose possession? said to him: in the buyer’s possession. said to him: You are deemed credible to cause the loss of your wage, But you are not deemed credible to cause a loss the Torah scroll.
llm_translation: The one who came before Rabbi Ammi, said to him: "The Torah scroll that I wrote for so-and-so, I did not write his praises in it." He said to him: "Whose possession is the Torah scroll in?" He said to him: "It is in the possession of the buyer." He said to him: "You are trusted to lose your reward, but you are not trusted to lose a Torah scroll."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה: נְהִי דְּהִפְסִיד שְׂכַר אַזְכָּרוֹת, שְׂכַר דְּסֵפֶר תּוֹרָה כּוּלֵּיהּ מִי הִפְסִיד?! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אִין, שֶׁכׇּל סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה שֶׁאֵין אַזְכָּרוֹת שֶׁלּוֹ כְּתוּבוֹת לִשְׁמָן – אֵינוֹ שָׁוֶה כְּלוּם.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya said to him: Although he lost wage to the mentions did he lose his wage to the entire Torah scroll, said to him: Yes, as any Torah scroll in which the mentions have not been written with the proper intention is not worth anything.
llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Yirmeya: "Even though he has lost the reward of remembrances, has he lost the reward of the entire Torah scroll?! He said to him: No, for any Torah scroll that does not have its remembrances written alongside it is worth nothing."

hebrew_text: וְלִיעַבַּר עֲלַיְיהוּ קוּלְמוֹס, וְלִיקַדְּשֵׁיהּ! כְּמַאן – נֵימָא דְּלָא כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה?
human_translation: But let pass a reed [ kulemos ] and sanctify them, in accordance with whose Shall we say not in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda?
llm_translation: "And to pass over it with a kormos, and to sanctify it! Like whom? - Say, not like Rabbi Yehuda?"

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: הֲרֵי שֶׁהָיָה צָרִיךְ לִכְתּוֹב אֶת הַשֵּׁם; וְנִתְכַּוֵּון לִכְתּוֹב ״יְהוּדָה״, וְטָעָה וְלֹא הֵטִיל בּוֹ דָּלֶת; מַעֲבִיר עָלָיו קוּלְמוֹס, וּמְקַדְּשׁוֹ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵין הַשֵּׁם מִן הַמּוּבְחָר.
human_translation: as we learned that he needed to write the name and intended to write Yehuda, but he made a mistake and did not place a dalet in he should pass over it with a reed and sanctifies it the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say: the name not in the optimal manner.
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: If one intended to write the name "Yehudah" and mistakenly did not include the letter dalet, he may correct it by scraping off the ink and rewriting it. This is the opinion of Rabbi Yehudah. However, the Sages say: The name is not among the chosen ones.

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אֶלָּא בַּחֲדָא אַזְכָּרָה, אֲבָל דְּכוּלֵּי סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה – לָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּמִיחֲזֵי כִּמְנוּמָּר.
human_translation: You even say Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Yehuda states only with regard to a single mention But entire Torah scroll not Because it would look speckled,
llm_translation: Even if you say it is Rabbi Yehuda - until here Rabbi Yehuda did not say except in one case it is mentioned, but regarding the entirety of the Torah scroll - no, because it appears like a type of deceit.

hebrew_text: הַהוּא דַּאֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה שֶׁכָּתַבְתִּי לִפְלוֹנִי, גְּוִילִין שֶׁלּוֹ לֹא עִיבַּדְתִּים לִשְׁמָן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה בְּיַד מִי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: בְּיַד לוֹקֵחַ. אָמַר לוֹ: מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁאַתָּה נֶאֱמָן לְהַפְסִיד שְׂכָרְךָ, אַתָּה נֶאֱמָן לְהַפְסִיד סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה.
human_translation: a certain who came before Rabbi Abbahu said to him: the Torah scroll that I wrote for so-and-so, I did not process its parchment with the proper intention. said to him: The Torah scroll is in whose possession? said to him: in the possession of the buyer. said to him: Since you are deemed credible to cause the loss of your wage, you are deemed credible to cause a loss the Torah scroll.
llm_translation: That one who came before Rabbi Avahu, said to him: "A Torah scroll that I wrote for so-and-so, I did not yet affix its Gvilin." He said to him: "Whose possession is the Torah scroll in?" He said to him: "It is in the possession of the buyer." He said to him: "Since you are trusted to lose your wage, you are trusted to lose the Torah scroll."

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא מִדְּרַבִּי אַמֵּי? הָתָם, אִיכָּא לְמֵימַר טָעֵי בִּדְרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה. הָכָא, כֵּיוָן דְּקָא מַפְסֵיד כּוּלֵּיהּ אַגְרֵיהּ – וַאֲתָא וַאֲמַר, אֵימוֹר קוּשְׁטָא קָאָמַר.
human_translation: And what is different from Rabbi Ami There it can be said he made the mistake of Rabbi Yirmeya. Here, since that he causes the loss of his entire wage, and comes and says say he speaks truth
llm_translation: And what is the difference from Rabbi Ammi? There, it can be said that he made a mistake in Rabbi Yirmeya. Here, since he was losing all his reward - he came and said, "Amar kushta ka'amar."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הֵעִיד רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן גּוּדְגְּדָא עַל הַחֵרֶשֶׁת שֶׁהִשִּׂיאָהּ אָבִיהָ, שֶׁהִיא יוֹצְאָה בְּגֵט;
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Gudgeda testified about a deaf-mute woman who was married by her father that she can be released through a bill of divorce,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: Rabbi Yochanan ben Gudgeda testified regarding a deaf-mute woman whose father married her off, that she is divorced through a bill of divorce.

hebrew_text: וְעַל קְטַנָּה בַּת יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁנִּשֵּׂאת לְכֹהֵן, שֶׁאוֹכֶלֶת בִּתְרוּמָה, וְאִם מֵתָה – בַּעְלָהּ יוֹרְשָׁהּ;
human_translation: And about minor daughter of a non-priest who married a priest that she may partake of teruma , And if dies, her husband inherits her
llm_translation: And regarding a minor, daughter of Israel who marries a Kohen, who eats from the Terumah, and if she dies - her husband inherits her.

hebrew_text: וְעַל הַמָּרִישׁ הַגָּזוּל שֶׁבְּנָאוֹ בְּבִירָה, שֶׁיִּטּוֹל אֶת דָּמָיו, מִפְּנֵי תַּקָּנַת הַשָּׁבִים;
human_translation: And about a stolen beam that was built into a large building [ bira ], receives the value due to an ordinance for the penitent.
llm_translation: And on the one who steals the stolen property in a pit, that he should take his blood, because of the restoration of the captives.

hebrew_text: וְעַל חַטָּאת הַגְּזוּלָה שֶׁלֹּא נוֹדְעָה לְרַבִּים – שֶׁהִיא מְכַפֶּרֶת, מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הַמִּזְבֵּחַ.
human_translation: And about a sin-offering that through robbery that was not publicly known that it effects atonement for the benefit of the altar,
llm_translation: And on the sin-offering of robbery that was not known to many - for it atones, because of the repair of the altar.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רָבָא: מֵעֵדוּתוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן גּוּדְגְּדָא – אָמַר לְעֵדִים: רָאוּ גֵּט זֶה שֶׁאֲנִי נוֹתֵן לָהּ, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר לָהּ: כִּנְסִי שְׁטַר חוֹב זֶה – הֲרֵי זוֹ מְגוֹרֶשֶׁת. מִי לָא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן גּוּדְגְּדָא לָא בָּעֵינַן דַּעְתַּהּ? הָכָא נָמֵי לָא בָּעֵינַן דַּעְתַּהּ.
human_translation: Rava says: from the testimony of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Gudgeda says to witnesses: See this bill of divorce that I give to and then he says Take this promissory note, she is divorced Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Gudgeda say we do not require consent Here too, we do not require consent.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said: From the testimony of Rabbi Yochanan ben Gudgeda - he said to the witnesses: "You saw this bill of divorce that I am giving to her," and he went back and said to her: "Take this promissory note of debt - she is hereby divorced." Who did Rabbi Yochanan ben Gudgeda not require her consent? Here too, we do not require her consent.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר: ״כִּנְסִי שְׁטַר חוֹב זֶה״, בַּטּוֹלֵי בַּטְּלֵיהּ; קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, אִם אִיתָא דְּבַטְּלֵיהּ – לְעֵדִים הֲוָה אָמַר לְהוּ. וְהַאי דְּקָאָמַר הָכִי – מִשּׁוּם כִּיסּוּפָא.
human_translation: Isn’t obvious? Lest you say: Since he said Take this promissory note, cancel teaches us: If it is so that cancel he would have told witnesses And the reason he said due to embarrassment,
llm_translation: It is obvious! What might you say, since he said: "Bring this promissory note," he nullifies it; he is teaching us, if it comes that he nullified it - he said to the witnesses. And what he is saying like this - because of suspicion.

hebrew_text: וְעַל קְטַנָּה בַּת יִשְׂרָאֵל: וְאִילּוּ חֵרֶשֶׁת – לָא אָכְלָה. מַאי טַעְמָא? גְּזֵירָה שֶׁמָּא יַאֲכִיל חֵרֵשׁ בְּחֵרֶשֶׁת.
human_translation: about the a minor daughter of a non-priest while a deaf-mute woman may not partake What is the reason decreed lest a deaf-mute feed teruma to deaf-mute
llm_translation: "And regarding a minor, the daughter of Israel: And if she is a deaf-mute - she does not eat. What is the reason? A decree lest a deaf-mute will feed another deaf-mute with deaf-mute food."

hebrew_text: וְלֹיכֵול – קָטָן אוֹכֵל נְבֵלוֹת הוּא!
human_translation: And let him feed a minor eats animal carcasses?
llm_translation: And to eat - a minor eats nevelot, he is!

hebrew_text: גְּזֵרָה שֶׁמָּא יַאֲכִיל חֵרֵשׁ בְּפִיקַּחַת.
human_translation: decreed lest a deaf-mute feed teruma to competent
llm_translation: Decree lest he feed a deaf-mute with a crumb.

hebrew_text: וְלֹאכֵול בִּתְרוּמָה דְּרַבָּנַן! גְּזֵירָה שֶׁמָּא אָתֵי לְאוֹכוֹלֵי בִּתְרוּמָה דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: But let her partake of teruma by rabbinic law, decreed lest he come to feed her teruma by Torah law.
llm_translation: And not to eat in the Trumah of the Rabbis! A decree lest one come to eat the Trumah of the Torah.

hebrew_text: וְעַל הַמָּרִישׁ הַגָּזוּל שֶׁבְּנָאוֹ: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: גָּזַל מָרִישׁ וּבְנָאוֹ בְּבִירָה – בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: מְקַעְקֵעַ כׇּל הַבִּירָה כּוּלָּהּ וּמַחְזִיר מָרִישׁ לִבְעָלָיו; וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: אֵין לוֹ אֶלָּא דְּמֵי מָרִישׁ בִּלְבַד, מִשּׁוּם תַּקָּנַת הַשָּׁבִין.
human_translation: about a stolen beam that was built the Sages taught one robbed a beam and built it into a building, Beit Shammai say: destroy the entire building and return the beam to its owners. And Beit Hillel say: only the value of the beam due to an ordinance instituted for the sake of the penitent.
llm_translation: Regarding the stolen ox that was slaughtered in its offspring: The Rabbis taught: If one stole the ox and its offspring in a pit - Beit Shammai say: He must cut up the entire pit and return the head to its owner; and Beit Hillel say: He only has to pay the value of the head alone, due to the enactment of the returning of lost items.

hebrew_text: וְעַל חַטָּאת הַגְּזוּלָה כּוּ׳: אָמַר עוּלָּא: דְּבַר תּוֹרָה, בֵּין נוֹדְעָה וּבֵין לֹא נוֹדְעָה – אֵינָהּ מְכַפֶּרֶת;
human_translation: about a sin-offering through robbery, Ulla says: By Torah law, Whether it is known or it is not known it does not effect atonement
llm_translation: Regarding the guilt-offering of robbery, it is stated: Ulla said: A matter of Torah, whether it was known or not known - it does not atone.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? יֵאוּשׁ כְּדִי לָא קָנֵי; וּמָה טַעַם אָמְרוּ: לֹא נוֹדְעָה מְכַפֶּרֶת? שֶׁלֹּא יְהוּ כֹּהֲנִים עֲצֵבִין.
human_translation: What is the reason despair does not by itself acquire And what is the reason said it was not known it effects atonement? so that the priests not be distraught
llm_translation: What is the reason? He despairs so that he does not acquire; and what is the reason they said: "The atonement is not known"? So that the priests should not be sad.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן לְעוּלָּא: וְהָאֲנַן – ״מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״ תְּנַן? אָמַר לָהֶם: כֵּיוָן דְּכֹהֲנִים עֲצֵבִין, נִמְצָא מִזְבֵּחַ בָּטֵל.
human_translation: The Rabbis said to Ulla: But didn’t we learn for the benefit of the altar, said to them: When the priests are distraught, the altar is found idle.
llm_translation: The scholars said to Ulai: And we - "Because of the repair of the altar" we learned? He said to them: Since the priests are sad, it is found that the altar is nullified.

hebrew_text: וְרַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר: דְּבַר תּוֹרָה, בֵּין נוֹדְעָה בֵּין לֹא נוֹדְעָה – מְכַפֶּרֶת; מַאי טַעְמָא? יֵאוּשׁ כְּדִי קָנֵי;
human_translation: but Rav Yehuda says: By Torah law, whether it is known or it is not known it effects atonement What is the reason despair by itself acquire
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said: A matter of Torah, whether known or unknown - atones; What is the reason? Despair is sufficient to acquire.

hebrew_text: וּמָה טַעַם אָמְרוּ נוֹדְעָה אֵינָהּ מְכַפֶּרֶת? שֶׁלֹּא יֹאמְרוּ מִזְבֵּחַ אוֹכֵל גְּזֵילוֹת.
human_translation: And what is the reason said it is known it does not effect atonement? not say the altar consumes stolen property.
llm_translation: And what is the reason they said that if it is known, it does not atone? So that they should not say, "The altar consumes stolen property."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְעוּלָּא – הַיְינוּ דְּקָתָנֵי חַטָּאת. אֶלָּא לְרַב יְהוּדָה – מַאי אִירְיָא חַטָּאת, אֲפִילּוּ עוֹלָה נָמֵי!
human_translation: Granted, Ulla, this is the reason that teaches a sin-offering: But according to Rav Yehuda, why specifically a sin-offering; a burnt-offering, as well,
llm_translation: In truth, according to Ulah - that is what is taught regarding the sin offering. But according to Rav Yehudah - what is the status of a sin offering, even an elevation offering as well!

hebrew_text: לָא מִיבַּעְיָא קָאָמַר – לָא מִיבַּעְיָא עוֹלָה, דְּכָלִיל הִיא; אֶלָּא אֲפִילּוּ חַטָּאת נָמֵי, דְּחֵלֶב וָדָם הוּא דְּסָלֵיק לְגַבֵּי מִזְבֵּחַ, וְאִידַּךְ כֹּהֲנִים אָכְלִי לֵיהּ; אֲפִילּוּ הָכִי גְּזוּר, שֶׁלֹּא יֹאמְרוּ מִזְבֵּחַ אוֹכֵל גְּזֵילוֹת.
human_translation: is speaking It is not necessary, It is not necessary a burnt-offering, which is entirely But even a sin-offering, where the fat and the blood go up on the altar and the rest is consumed by the priests, even so they issued a decree so should not say the altar consumes stolen property.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text states: "Lā mibba'ya qā'āmar – lā mibba'ya 'ōlāh, dəkhālīl hī; ʼellā ʼăfīlū ḥaṭṭā't nāmēi, dəḥēlev wādām hū dəsālēiq ləgabbēi mizbēaḥ, wəʼiddaḵ kōhānīm ʼōḵəlī lēih; ʼăfīlū hāḵī gəzūr, šellō yōmərū mizbēaḥ ʼōḵēl gəzēilōṯ."

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: עַל חַטָּאת הַגְּזוּלָה שֶׁלֹּא נוֹדְעָה לְרַבִּים, שֶׁהִיא מְכַפֶּרֶת – מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הַמִּזְבֵּחַ. בִּשְׁלָמָא לְעוּלָּא – נִיחָא, אֶלָּא לְרַב יְהוּדָה – אִיפְּכָא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: We learned about a sin-offering that through robbery that is not publicly known that it effects atonement for the benefit of the altar. Granted, according to Ulla, works out well, But according to Rav Yehuda, it should have the opposite,
llm_translation: We learned: regarding a stolen sin offering that was not known to many, which atones - because of the repair of the altar. If it is for an elevation offering - it is fine, but according to Rabbi Yehuda - it is the opposite of what he requires!

hebrew_text: הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: לָא נוֹדְעָה – מְכַפֶּרֶת, נוֹדְעָה – אֵינָהּ מְכַפֶּרֶת, מִפְּנֵי תִּיקּוּן הַמִּזְבֵּחַ.
human_translation: That is also what is saying: it is not known it effects atonement, is known, it does not effect atonement, for the benefit of the altar.
llm_translation: So it was stated: If it is not known - it atones, if it is known - it does not atone, due to the repair of the altar.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רָבָא: גָּנַב וְהִקְדִּישׁ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ טָבַח וּמָכַר – מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי כֶפֶל, וְאֵינוֹ מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי אַרְבָּעָה וַחֲמִשָּׁה. וְתָנֵי עֲלַהּ: בַּחוּץ כִּי הַאי גַוְונָא – עָנוּשׁ כָּרֵת. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ יֵאוּשׁ כְּדִי לָא קָנֵי, כָּרֵת מַאי עֲבִידְתֵּיהּ?
human_translation: Rava raises an objection one stole and consecrated and afterward he slaughtered or sold he pays double payment but he does not pay fourfold or fivefold payment, And it is taught with regard to outside in a case like this, punishable by karet And if you say despair does not by itself acquire what is the relevance of karet ?
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: If one stole and consecrated the stolen item to the Temple, and then slaughtered and sold it, he pays double restitution, but does not pay four or fivefold restitution. And it was taught in a braita: If the consecration was made outside the Temple, since this is a deceptive act – the punishment is excision. And if you say that the consecration is not effective since it was done deceptively, what is the purpose of the excision?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שֵׁיזְבִי: כָּרֵת מִדִּבְרֵיהֶם. אַחִיכוּ עֲלֵיהּ – כָּרֵת מִדִּבְרֵיהֶם מִי אִיכָּא?! אֲמַר לְהוּ רָבָא: גַּבְרָא רַבָּה אָמַר מִילְּתָא, לָא תְּחוּכוּ עֲלַהּ; כָּרֵת שֶׁעַל יְדֵי דִּבְרֵיהֶן בָּאתָה לוֹ – אוֹקְמוּהָ רַבָּנַן בִּרְשׁוּתֵיהּ כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלִיחַיַּיב עֲלַהּ.
human_translation: Rav Sheizevi said: karet by rabbinic law. laughed at him. Is there karet by rabbinic law? Rava said to them: A great man has spoken, do not laugh at him. karet that comes to him through the words the Sages placed in his possession, so that he would become liable for it.
llm_translation: Rav Sheizbi said: "Cut off their words." His brothers said to him - "Cut off their words, is there such a thing?!" Rava said to them: A great man said a matter, do not delay on it; if the cutting off came through their words - the Rabbis established it in their domain so that he would be liable for it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הָא וַודַּאי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לִי – כִּי אוֹקְמוּהָ רַבָּנַן בִּרְשׁוּתֵיהּ, מִשְּׁעַת גְּנֵיבָה אוֹ מִשְּׁעַת הֶקְדֵּישָׁהּ? לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְגִיזּוֹתֶיהָ וּוַלְדוֹתֶיהָ. מַאי? הֲדַר אָמַר רָבָא: מִסְתַּבְּרָא – מִשְּׁעַת הֶקְדֵּישָׁהּ, שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא חוֹטֵא נִשְׂכָּר.
human_translation: Rava said: this is certainly a dilemma for me. When the Sages placed in his possession, from the time of the theft or from the time of the consecration? What is the difference with regard to its wool and with regard to its offspring. What Rava then said, It stands to reason from the time of the consecration. so that the sinner not profit
llm_translation: Rava said: This, indeed, is what I am asking - when were the Sages establishing it in its domain, at the time of theft or at the time of its consecration? What is the practical difference? For its shearing and offspring. What? Rava subsequently said: It is logical - at the time of its consecration, so that the sinner should not benefit.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ לֹא הָיָה סִיקָרִיקוֹן בִּיהוּדָה בַּהֲרוּגֵי מִלְחָמָה. מֵהֲרוּגֵי הַמִּלְחָמָה וְאֵילָךְ, יֵשׁ בָּהּ סִיקָרִיקוֹן. כֵּיצַד? לָקַח מִסִּיקָרִיקוֹן, וְחָזַר וְלָקַח מִבַּעַל הַבַּיִת, מִקָּחוֹ בָּטֵל. מִבַּעַל הַבַּיִת, וְחָזַר וְלָקַח מִסִּיקָרִיקוֹן – מִקָּחוֹ קַיָּים.
human_translation: Sicarii [ Sikarikon ] did not in Judea in the people were being killed in the war. From people were being killed in the war and onward, Sicarii did there. What one purchased from a Sicarius, and returned and purchased from the landowner, his purchase is void. from the owner and he returned and purchased from a Sicarius, his purchase stands.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: There was no sikarikon in Judea among those killed in battle. From those killed in battle and onward, there is sikarikon in it. How so? He took from the sikarikon, then returned and took from the homeowner, his acquisition is nullified. From the homeowner, then returned and took from the sikarikon – his acquisition stands.

hebrew_text: לָקַח מִן הָאִישׁ וְחָזַר וְלָקַח מִן הָאִשָּׁה – מִקָּחוֹ בָּטֵל. מִן הָאִשָּׁה וְחָזַר וְלָקַח מִן הָאִישׁ – מִקָּחוֹ קַיָּים. זוֹ מִשְׁנָה רִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: one purchased from the husband and he returned and purchased from the wife, his purchase is void. from the wife, and he returned and purchased from the husband, his purchase stands. This initial mishna.
llm_translation: He took from the man and returned and took from the woman - his acquisition is nullified. From the woman and returned and took from the man - his acquisition stands. This is the first Mishnah.

hebrew_text: בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל אַחֲרֵיהֶם אָמְרוּ: הַלּוֹקֵחַ מִסִּיקָרִיקוֹן, נוֹתֵן לַבְּעָלִים רְבִיעַ. אֵימָתַי – בִּזְמַן שֶׁאֵין בְּיָדָן לִיקַּח, אֲבָל יֵשׁ בְּיָדָן לִיקַּח – הֵן קוֹדְמִין לְכׇל אָדָם.
human_translation: the court of those after said: one who purchased from a Sicarius, he must give the owner one-fourth When At a time when is unable to purchase But if he is able to purchase he precedes anyone
llm_translation: The court of their successors said: One who purchases from the market of Sikarikon, gives to the owners a quarter. When? When they do not have the ability to take, but if they have the ability to take, they have precedence over all people.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי הוֹשִׁיב בֵּית דִּין וְנִמְנוּ, שֶׁאִם שָׁהֲתָה בִּפְנֵי סִיקָרִיקוֹן שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ, כׇּל הַקּוֹדֵם לִיקַּח – זָכָה; אֲבָל נוֹתֵן לַבְּעָלִים רְבִיעַ.
human_translation: Rabbi convened a court, and they counted that if remained before, the Sicarius twelve months, whoever first purchases acquires possession but he must give the owner one-fourth
llm_translation: Rabbi sat in the court and they counted, that if she stayed in front of Sikrikon for twelve months, anyone who precedes to marry - he is successful; but he gives to the owners a quarter.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ הַשְׁתָּא בַּהֲרוּגֵי הַמִּלְחָמָה לֹא הָיָה בָּהּ סִיקָרִיקוֹן, מֵהֲרוּגֵי מִלְחָמָה וְאֵילָךְ, יֵשׁ בָּהּ סִיקָרִיקוֹן?!
human_translation: Now in people were being killed in the war, there were no Sicarii from people were being killed in the war and onward there were Sicarii?
llm_translation: Gemara: In the case of those killed in battle, there was no examination of the body for a blemish. From those killed in battle and onwards, is there an examination of the body for a blemish?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: ״לֹא דָּנוּ בָּהּ דִּין סִיקָרִיקוֹן״ קָאָמַר. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי: שָׁלֹשׁ גְּזֵירוֹת גָּזְרוּ. גְּזֵרְתָּא קַמַּיְיתָא: כֹּל דְּלָא קָטֵיל – לִיקְטְלוּהּ. מְצִיעֲתָא: כֹּל דְּקָטֵיל – לַיְיתֵי אַרְבַּע זוּזֵי. בָּתְרָיְיתָא: כֹּל דְּקָטֵיל – לִיקְטְלוּהּ. הִלְכָּךְ, קַמַּיְיתָא וּמְצִיעֲתָא, כֵּיוָן דְּקָטְלִי – אַגַּב אוּנְסֵיהּ גָּמַר וּמַקְנֵי.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said: is saying they did not apply the law of Sicarii, Rabbi Asi said: issued three decrees first decree anyone who does not kill should be killed. second anyone who kills should pay four dinars last anyone who kills should be killed. Therefore, first and second since would kill owing to the danger would fully transfer ownership
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said: "They did not judge in it a judgment of Sikarikon," he said. As Rabbi Assi said: They decreed three decrees. The first decree: Anyone who does not kill - they shall kill him. The second decree: Anyone who kills - shall pay four zuz. The third decree: Anyone who kills - they shall kill him. Therefore, the first and second decrees, once they kill - they have fulfilled their obligation and acquired the property.

hebrew_text: בָּתְרָיְיתָא אָמְרִי: הָאִידָּנָא לִישְׁקוֹל, לִמְחַר תָּבַעְנָא לֵיהּ בְּדִינָא.
human_translation: the last say Now let him take tomorrow I will claim it from him in court.
llm_translation: In the academy of Batriatha they said: "Today to lend, tomorrow to demand in court."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״אַשְׁרֵי אָדָם מְפַחֵד תָּמִיד וּמַקְשֶׁה לִבּוֹ יִפּוֹל בְּרָעָה״? אַקַּמְצָא וּבַר קַמְצָא חֲרוּב יְרוּשָׁלַיִם, אַתַּרְנְגוֹלָא וְתַרְנְגוֹלְתָּא חֲרוּב טוּר מַלְכָּא, אַשָּׁקָא דְרִיסְפַּק חֲרוּב בֵּיתֵּר.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What which is written: “Happy is the man who fears always, but he who hardens his heart shall fall into mischief” Jerusalem was destroyed on account of Kamtza and bar Kamtza. the King’s Mountain was destroyed on account of a rooster and a hen. Beitar was destroyed on account of a shaft from a chariot [ rispak ].
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said, what is the meaning of what is written: "Happy is the man who is always fearful, but he who hardens his heart will fall into misfortune"? I will explain: In the valley of Kamza and the valley of Kamtza there was a carob tree of Jerusalem, in the city of Antrongola and the city of Tarngolta there was a carob tree of the king, and in the market of Drispaq there was a carob tree of Beitar.

hebrew_text: אַקַּמְצָא וּבַר קַמְצָא חֲרוּב יְרוּשָׁלַיִם – דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא דְּרָחֲמֵיהּ קַמְצָא, וּבְעֵל דְּבָבֵיהּ בַּר קַמְצָא. עֲבַד סְעוֹדְתָּא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ לְשַׁמָּעֵיהּ: זִיל אַיְיתִי לִי קַמְצָא. אֲזַל אַיְיתִי לֵיהּ בַּר קַמְצָא.
human_translation: Jerusalem was destroyed on account of Kamtza and bar Kamtza. as a certain man whose friend Kamtza and whose enemy bar Kamtza. He made feast said to his servant: Go bring me Kamtza. went brought him bar Kamtza.
llm_translation: I found Akmatza and Bar Kamtza in Jerusalem - that man whose name was Kamtza, and the owner of the house was Bar Kamtza. He made a feast, he said to him to hear: Go bring me Kamtza. He went and brought him Bar Kamtza.

hebrew_text: אֲתָא, אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ דַּהֲוָה יָתֵיב. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִכְּדֵי הָהוּא גַּבְרָא בְּעֵל דְּבָבֵאּ דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא הוּא, מַאי בָּעֵית הָכָא? קוּם פּוֹק! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הוֹאִיל וַאֲתַאי, שִׁבְקַן וְיָהֵיבְנָא לָךְ דְּמֵי מָה דְּאָכֵילְנָא וְשָׁתֵינָא.
human_translation: came and found sitting said to That man is the enemy [ ba’al devava ] of that man, What do you want here? Arise leave. said to him: Since I have come, let me stay and I will give you money whatever I eat and drink.
llm_translation: He came, he found him sitting. He said to him: Since that man, the owner of the house of that man, is he, what do you need here? Get up and leave! He said to him: Since you have come, leave and we will give you the money for what we have eaten and drunk.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: יָהֵיבְנָא לָךְ דְּמֵי פַּלְגָא דִּסְעוֹדְתָּיךְ! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: יָהֵיבְנָא לָךְ דְּמֵי כּוּלַּהּ סְעוֹדְתָּיךְ! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא. נַקְטֵיהּ בִּידֵיהּ וְאוֹקְמֵיהּ וְאַפְּקֵיהּ.
human_translation: said to him: No, said to him: I will give you money for half of the feast; said to him: No, said to him: I will give you money for the entire feast; said to him: No, took by his hand, stood him up, and took him out.
llm_translation: He said to him: No. He said to him: I will give you the money for half of your meal! He said to him: No. He said to him: I will give you the money for your entire meal! He said to him: No. He took it in his hand, got up, and left.

hebrew_text: אָמַר: הוֹאִיל וַהֲווֹ יָתְבִי רַבָּנַן וְלָא מַחוֹ בֵּיהּ, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ קָא נִיחָא לְהוּ, אֵיזִיל אֵיכוֹל בְּהוּ קוּרְצָא בֵּי מַלְכָּא. אֲזַל אֲמַר לֵיהּ לְקֵיסָר: מְרַדוּ בָּךְ יְהוּדָאֵי! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִי יֵימַר? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: שַׁדַּר לְהוּ קוּרְבָּנָא, חָזֵית אִי מַקְרְבִין לֵיהּ.
human_translation: said Since the Sages were sitting and did not protest learn from it that they were content I will go and inform [ eikhul kurtza ] against them to the king. He went said to the emperor: The Jews have rebelled against you. said to him: Who says said to him: send them an offering see whether they sacrifice it.
llm_translation: He said: Since they were sitting, the sages, and did not protest against it, it is evident that it is pleasing to them. I will go and eat a piece of the king's bread.
