llm_translation: He said to him Rabbi Zeira to Rabba bar Sheilta: From the fact that every three that are tied together are considered as two that are separate. Just as there it is not close, so too here it is not close!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אַף לְדִידִי קַשְׁיָא לִי, וּשְׁאֵילְתֵּיהּ לְרַב הַמְנוּנָא, וְרַב הַמְנוּנָא לְרַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה, וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ: הַנַּח לִשְׁלֹשָׁה בִּמְקוּשָּׁר, דְּלָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: said to him: To me as well difficult, and I asked that to Rav Hamnuna, and Rav Hamnuna to Rav Adda bar Ahava, and he said to him: Leave three in a tied as is not by Torah law.
llm_translation: He said to him: "Even according to me it is difficult, and I asked it to Rav Hamnuna, and Rav Hamnuna to Rav Adda bar Ahava, and he said to him: 'Leave it to three who are connected, for it is not from the Torah.'"

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: גֵּט קֵרֵחַ – קְשָׁרָיו שִׁבְעָה וְעֵדָיו שִׁשָּׁה; שִׁשָּׁה וְעֵדָיו חֲמִשָּׁה; חֲמִשָּׁה וְעֵדָיו אַרְבָּעָה; אַרְבָּעָה וְעֵדָיו שְׁלֹשָׁה – עַד כָּאן מַחְלוֹקֶת בֶּן נַנָּס וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא.
human_translation: this is also taught dispute ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva a bare bill of divorce only its ties seven and its witnesses six, six and its witnesses five, five and its witnesses four, four and its witnesses three.
llm_translation: It was taught in a baraita: So said Nahum the Mede: A get of a bald man - its knots are seven and its witnesses are six; six and its witnesses are five; five and its witnesses are four; four and its witnesses are three - until here is the dispute between Ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva.

hebrew_text: הִשְׁלִים עָלָיו עֶבֶד, בֶּן נַנָּס אוֹמֵר: הַוָּלָד כָּשֵׁר; וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: הַוָּלָד מַמְזֵר. אֲבָל קְשָׁרָיו שְׁלֹשָׁה וְעֵדָיו שְׁנַיִם – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל אֵין מַשְׁלִימִין עָלָיו אֶלָּא קָרוֹב.
human_translation: a slave completed it ben Nannas says: The offspring is unflawed. And Rabbi Akiva says: The offspring is a mamzer . But its ties three, and its witnesses two, everyone agrees not complete it. Rather, only a relative
llm_translation: He completed upon him a slave, Ben Nanas says: the offspring is legitimate; and Rabbi Akiva says: the offspring is a mamzer. But his bonds are three and his witnesses are two - the words of all, they do not complete upon him except a relative.

hebrew_text: רַב יוֹסֵף מַתְנִי: ״כָּשֵׁר״. וְהָתַנְיָא: קָרוֹב! אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא, תְּנִי: כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: Rav Yosef taught: a valid But isn’t it taught A relative? Rav Pappa said: teach: Valid.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef taught: "Kosher." And it was taught: "Close!" Rav Papa said, teach: "Kosher."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא הוּכְשְׁרוּ בּוֹ אֶלָּא עֵד אֶחָד קָרוֹב בִּלְבַד, אֲבָל תְּרֵי לָא – דִּלְמָא אָתֵי לְקַיּוֹמֵי בִּתְרֵי קְרוֹבִים וְחַד כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says: In validated only one witness a relative, But two no, perhaps they will come to ratify with two relatives and one valid.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: It was not validated by him except one witness close alone, but two not - perhaps he will come to establish with two close witnesses and one valid.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: מַתְנִיתָא נָמֵי דַּיְקָא –
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: the baraita is also precise,
llm_translation: Rav Ashe said: The Mishnah is precise -

hebrew_text: דְּקָא מְדַלֵּג וְתָנֵי חַד חַד; שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: as it teaches skipping one one. Conclude from it
llm_translation: He is skipping and teaching one by one; hear from it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ, הַאי קָרוֹב חָתֵים אִי בָּעֵי – בֵּין בַּתְּחִילָּה, בֵּין בָּאֶמְצַע, בֵּין בַּסּוֹף.
human_translation: Abaye said: Learn from it this relative, sign if he wants either at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end.
llm_translation: Abaye said: Hear from it, this close seal, whether it requires - whether at the beginning, whether in the middle, whether at the end.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי – מִדְּלָא קְבַע לֵיהּ מָקוֹם. וּשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: מִכֹּל תְּלָתָא מְקַיְּימִינַן, וְלָא בָּעֵינַן רְצוּפִין.
human_translation: From where From it did not designate a place for him And learn from it, from any three we ratify And we do not need consecutive
llm_translation: From what - because he did not establish for it a place. And learn from it: from all three we establish, and we do not require them to be arranged.

hebrew_text: דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בָּעֵינַן רְצוּפִין, לִקְבַּע לֵיהּ מָקוֹם לְהַאי קָרוֹב – בַּתְּחִילָּה אוֹ בָּאֶמְצַע אוֹ בַּסּוֹף; וְלַכְשַׁר בֵּיהּ טוּבָא.
human_translation: As if it enters your mind we need consecutive they should designate a place for this relative in the beginning, or in the middle, or at the end, and they should validate many
llm_translation: If your intention is to place them in a row, to establish a place for it nearby - whether at the beginning, in the middle, or at the end; and to make it valid.

hebrew_text: כִּי אָתוּ לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי אַמֵּי, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: צֵא וְהַשְׁלֵים עָלָיו עֶבֶד מִן הַשּׁוּק.
human_translation: when they came before Rabbi Ami he said to Go out and complete it a slave from the public,
llm_translation: When they came before Rabbi Ammi, he said to him: "Go and have a slave from the market complete it for him."

hebrew_text: הֲדַרַן עֲלָךְ הַזּוֹרֵק
llm_translation: We will return to you, O Zorek.

hebrew_text: הַמְגָרֵשׁ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ, וְאָמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם, אֶלָּא לִפְלוֹנִי״. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מַתִּיר, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹסְרִים. כֵּיצַד יַעֲשֶׂה? יִטְּלֶנּוּ הֵימֶנָּה וְיַחֲזוֹר וְיִתְּנֶנּוּ לָהּ, וְיֹאמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם״. כְּתָבוֹ בְּתוֹכוֹ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁחָזַר וּמְחָקוֹ – פָּסוּל.
human_translation: one who divorces his wife and said to her You are hereby permitted to any man except [ ella ] for so-and-so, Rabbi Eliezer permits And the Rabbis prohibit What should he do He should take it from her and hand it to her again, and say to her: You are hereby permitted to any man. he wrote inside even if he then erased it, is invalid
llm_translation: The one who divorces his wife, and says to her: "Behold, you are permitted to all men, except for so-and-so." Rabbi Eliezer permits, and the Sages prohibit. How should he act? He should take it from her and return it to her, and say to her: "Behold, you are permitted to all men." If he wrote it within it, even though he retracted and erased it - it is invalid.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: הַאי ״אֶלָּא״ – ״חוּץ״ הוּא, אוֹ ״עַל מְנָת״ הוּא?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before this ella it except, Or it On the condition,
llm_translation: The Gemara inquires of them: Is this "rather" - "outside," or "for the purpose of"?

hebrew_text: ״חוּץ״ הוּא – וּבְ״חוּץ״ הוּא דִּפְלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, דְּהָא שַׁיַּיר לַהּ בְּגֵט; אֲבָל בְּ״עַל מְנָת״ – מוֹדוּ לֵיהּ, מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה אַכֹּל תְּנָאֵי דְּעָלְמָא;
human_translation: except, and it is with regard to exception that the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer because left out of her bill of divorce; But with regard to on the condition agree with just as is with regard to any typical condition
llm_translation: "Outside" it is - and in "outside" they dispute the Rabbis upon it of Rabbi Eliezer, for he permits her with a divorce; but in "Ba'al Menat" - they agree with him, since it becomes like the regular conditions of the world.

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִלְמָא ״עַל מְנָת״ הוּא – וּבְ״עַל מְנָת״ הוּא דִּפְלִיג רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אַדְּרַבָּנַן; אֲבָל בְּ״חוּץ״ מוֹדֶה – דְּהָא שַׁיַּיר לַהּ בְּגֵט.
human_translation: Or perhaps is On the condition? it is with regard to on the condition that Rabbi Eliezer disagrees with the Rabbis but with regard to exception he concedes as left out of her bill of divorce.
llm_translation: Or perhaps "on condition" it is – and with "on condition" it is that Rabbi Eliezer disagrees with the sages; but regarding "outside" he concedes – for it is effective for her in a bill of divorce.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבִינָא, תָּא שְׁמַע: כׇּל הַבָּתִּים מִטַּמְּאִין בִּנְגָעִים, אֶלָּא שֶׁל גּוֹיִם. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא ״חוּץ״ הוּא – שַׁפִּיר; אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ ״עַל מְנָת״ הוּא – עַל מְנָת דְּלָא מִיטַּמּוּ בָּתֵּי גוֹיִם הוּא דְּמִיטַּמּוּ בָּתֵּי יִשְׂרָאֵל, הָא מִיטַּמּוּ בָּתֵּי גוֹיִם – לָא מִטַּמְּאִי בָּתֵּי יִשְׂרָאֵל?!
human_translation: Ravina said: Come hear All houses become ritually impure through leprous sores except [ ella ] for belonging to gentiles. Granted, if you say is except, well But if you say is on the condition, houses of Jews become impure only on the condition that houses of gentiles do not become impure; consequently, houses of gentiles become impure, houses of Jews do not become impure.
llm_translation: Ravina said, come and hear: all houses are susceptible to impurity from afflictions, except for those of gentiles. If you say it is because it is "outside," it is fine; but if you say it is "on condition," on the condition that the houses of gentiles do not become impure, then the houses of Israel should not become impure. If the houses of gentiles become impure, should the houses of Israel not become impure?!

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד, בָּתֵּי גוֹיִם מִי מִטַּמְּאִי?! וְהָתַנְיָא: ״וְנָתַתִּי נֶגַע צָרַעַת בְּבֵית אֶרֶץ אֲחוּזַּתְכֶם״ – אֶרֶץ אֲחוּזַּתְכֶם מִטַּמְּאָה בִּנְגָעִים, וְאֵין בָּתֵּי גוֹיִם מִטַּמְּאִין בִּנְגָעִים! אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ ״חוּץ״ הוּא; שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Moreover, Do houses of gentiles become ritually impure But isn’t it taught “And I put the plague of leprosy in a house of the land of your possession” the land of your possession, becomes impure through leprous sores but houses of gentiles do not become impure through leprosy? Rather, conclude from is except. Conclude from it
llm_translation: And furthermore, the houses of gentiles, who can declare them unclean?! And it was taught: "And I will put a plague of leprosy upon a house in the land of your possession" - your possession is susceptible to plagues, but the houses of gentiles are not susceptible to plagues! Rather, understand from it that it is "outside"; understand from it.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִיתִין דְּלָא כִּי הַאי תַּנָּא – דְּתַנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה: לֹא נֶחְלְקוּ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר וַחֲכָמִים עַל הַמְגָרֵשׁ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ, וְאָמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם, חוּץ מִפְּלוֹנִי״ – שֶׁאֵינָהּ מְגוֹרֶשֶׁת. עַל מָה נֶחְלְקוּ? עַל הַמְגָרֵשׁ אִשְׁתּוֹ, וְאָמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם, עַל מְנָת שֶׁלֹּא תִּנָּשְׂאִי לִפְלוֹנִי״ –
human_translation: our mishna is not in accordance with this tanna , as it is taught Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis did not disagree with regard to one who divorces his wife and said to her You are hereby permitted to any man except for so-and-so; that she is not divorced. With regard to what did they disagree? with regard to one who divorces his wife and said to her: You are hereby permitted to any man on the condition that you will not marry so-and-so,
llm_translation: Mishnah that not like this Tanna - that he teaches, Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda said: Rabbi Eliezer and the Sages did not disagree regarding a man who divorces his wife, and he said to her: "Behold, you are permitted to any man, except for so-and-so" - that she is not divorced. What did they disagree about? They disagreed about a man who divorces his wife, and he said to her: "Behold, you are permitted to any man, on the condition that you do not marry so-and-so."

hebrew_text: שֶׁרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מַתִּיר לְכׇל אָדָם חוּץ מֵאוֹתוֹ הָאִישׁ, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹסְרִים.
human_translation: as Rabbi Eliezer permits to any man except for that man and the Rabbis prohibit
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer permits for all people except for that man, and the sages prohibit.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה אַכֹּל תְּנָאֵי דְּעָלְמָא. וְרַבָּנַן – כֹּל תְּנָאֵי דְּעָלְמָא לָא שַׁיַּיר לֵיהּ בְּגֵט, הָכָא שַׁיַּיר לַהּ בְּגֵט.
human_translation: What is the reasoning behind Rabbi Eliezer’s just as it is with regard to any typical condition. And the Rabbis any typical condition did not leave out of the bill of divorce, here he left out of the bill of divorce,
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer's opinion? Because he used to eat the delicacies of the world. And the Rabbis - all the delicacies of the world were not left for him in a divorce document, but here they are left for her in a divorce document.

hebrew_text: וּמַתְנִיתִין – דְּאוֹקֵימְנָא בְּ״חוּץ״, מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר?
human_translation: And the mishna, which we established as exception, what is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s
llm_translation: Mishnah: And the Mishnah that we establish in "outside," what is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי מִשּׁוּם זָקֵן אֶחָד, אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְיָצְאָה מִבֵּיתוֹ וְהָלְכָה וְהָיְתָה לְאִישׁ אַחֵר״ – אֲפִילּוּ לֹא הִתִּירָהּ אֶלָּא לְאִישׁ אַחֵר, הֲרֵי זוֹ מְגוֹרֶשֶׁת. וְרַבָּנַן אָמְרִי, טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: הַאי ״אִישׁ״ – לְכׇל אִישׁ וָאִישׁ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yannai said in the name of one elder the verse states “And she departs out of his house, and goes and becomes another man’s wife” even only permitted her to other man, she is divorced, And the Rabbis would say Rabbi Eliezer’s explanation this man, to any man,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yannai said in the name of one elder, the verse says: "And she went out of his house and went and became another man's" - even if she only permitted herself to another man, she is considered divorced. And the Rabbis say, the reason of Rabbi Eliezer: this "man" - to any man and any man.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר, טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מֵהָכָא: ״וְאִשָּׁה גְּרוּשָׁה מֵאִישָׁהּ לֹא יִקָּחוּ״ – אֲפִילּוּ לֹא נִתְגָּרְשָׁה אֶלָּא מֵאִישָׁהּ, נִפְסְלָה מִן הַכְּהוּנָּה – אַלְמָא הָוֵי גִּיטָּא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan said the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s is from here, “Neither may they take a woman divorced from her husband” even she was divorced only from her husband, she is disqualified from the priesthood Apparently, is bill of divorce.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said, the reason of Rabbi Eliezer is from here: "And a divorced woman from her husband they shall not take" - even if she was only divorced from her husband, she is disqualified from the priesthood - hence, it is considered a valid bill of divorce.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן – אִיסּוּר כְּהוּנָּה שָׁאנֵי.
human_translation: And the Rabbis the prohibition priesthood is different,
llm_translation: And the Rabbis - the prohibition of priesthood is different.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבִּי אַבָּא: בְּקִידּוּשִׁין הֵיאַךְ? תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba raises a dilemma: in betrothal, how Let the dilemma be raised according to Rabbi Eliezer let the dilemma be raised according to the Rabbis.
llm_translation: The question of Rabbi Abba: In marriage how? He asked Rabbi Eliezer, he asked the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הָכָא, אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דִּכְתִיבִי קְרָאֵי; אֲבָל הָתָם – קִנְיָן מְעַלְּיָא בָּעֵינַן. אוֹ דִלְמָא, ״וְיָצְאָה״–״וְהָיְתָה״.
human_translation: Let the dilemma be raised according to Rabbi Eliezer: Rabbi Eliezer saying only here because verses are written but there, a proper acquisition is necessary, Or perhaps “And she departs “And becomes
llm_translation: The question was raised to Rabbi Eliezer - until here Rabbi Eliezer did not say this, but because it is written in the Scriptures; but there, we require an acquisition. Or perhaps, "and she shall go out" - "and she shall become."

hebrew_text: תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבָּנַן – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן הָכָא, אֶלָּא דְּבָעֵינַן כְּרִיתוּת – וְלֵיכָּא; אֲבָל הָתָם – קִנְיָן כֹּל דְּהוּ. אוֹ דִּלְמָא, ״וְיָצְאָה״–״וְהָיְתָה״.
human_translation: Let the dilemma be raised according to the Rabbis: the Rabbis saying here only because severance is necessary and there is no but there, any acquisition Or perhaps “And she departs,” “And becomes,”
llm_translation: The sages asked - until here the sages did not say here, rather we need a disputation - and it is not; but there - acquisition is everything. Or perhaps, "and she shall go out" - "and she shall be."

hebrew_text: לְבָתַר דְּאִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ, הֲדַר פַּשְׁטַהּ – בֵּין לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֵּין לְרַבָּנַן, בָּעֵינַן ״וְיָצְאָה״–״וְהָיְתָה״.
human_translation: After raised the dilemma he then resolved it Both according to Rabbi Eliezer and according to the Rabbis it is necessary “And she departs” “And becomes.”
llm_translation: After he asked him, he then explained - whether for Rabbi Eliezer or for the Rabbis, we require "and she shall go out" - "and she shall be."

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר אִיתָא לִדְרַבִּי אַבָּא;
human_translation: Abaye said: If you say Rabbi Abba’s is so,
llm_translation: Abbaye said: If you find it, say it to Rabbi Abba.

hebrew_text: בָּא רְאוּבֵן וְקִידְּשָׁהּ חוּץ מִשִּׁמְעוֹן, וּבָא שִׁמְעוֹן וְקִידְּשָׁהּ חוּץ מֵרְאוּבֵן, וּמֵתוּ שְׁנֵיהֶם – מִתְיַבֶּמֶת לְלֵוִי, וְאֵין אֲנִי קוֹרֵא בָּהּ ״אֵשֶׁת שְׁנֵי מֵתִים״.
human_translation: Reuven came and betrothed her except for Shimon, and Shimon came and betrothed her except for Reuven, and they both died she performs levirate marriage with Levi, and I do not call her the wife of two dead men.
llm_translation: Reuven came and betrothed her outside of Shimon, and then Shimon came and betrothed her outside of Reuven, and they both died - she performs yibum with Levi, and I do not read in it "the wife of two deceased."

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? קִידּוּשֵׁי דִרְאוּבֵן אַהֲנוֹ, קִידּוּשֵׁי דְשִׁמְעוֹן לָא אַהֲנוֹ.
human_translation: What is the reason betrothal to Reuven was effective, betrothal to Shimon was not effective,
llm_translation: What is the reason? The sanctifications of Reuven are effective, the sanctifications of Shimon are not effective.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא אֵשֶׁת שְׁנֵי מֵתִים – הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ? כְּגוֹן שֶׁבָּא רְאוּבֵן וְקִידְּשָׁהּ חוּץ מִשִּׁמְעוֹן, וּבָא שִׁמְעוֹן וְקִידְּשָׁהּ סְתָם – דְּקִידּוּשֵׁי רְאוּבֵן אַהֲנוֹ לְמֵיסְרַהּ אַעָלְמָא, וְקִידּוּשֵׁי דְּשִׁמְעוֹן אַהֲנוֹ לְמֵיסְרַהּ אַרְאוּבֵן.
human_translation: Rather, under what circumstances is a wife of two dead men found where Reuven came and betrothed her, except for Shimon, and Shimon came and betrothed her without specifying Since Reuven’s betrothal was effective in rendering her forbidden to everyone and Shimon’s betrothal was effective in rendering her forbidden to Reuven,
llm_translation: And rather, the wife of two deceased - how does she find herself? For example, Reuven came and betrothed her except for Shimon, and then Shimon came and betrothed her without specification - the betrothals of Reuven are effective to prohibit her to the world, and the betrothals of Shimon are effective to prohibit her to Reuven.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי אַבָּיֵי, אָמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם, חוּץ מֵרְאוּבֵן וְשִׁמְעוֹן״, וְחָזַר וְאָמַר לָהּ: ״לִרְאוּבֵן וְשִׁמְעוֹן״, מַהוּ?
human_translation: Abaye raises a dilemma: said to You are hereby permitted to any man except for Reuven and Shimon, and he then said to her: to Reuven and Shimon, what is
llm_translation: Ba'ei Abaye, amar lah: "Harei at muteret le'kol adam, chutz me'Reuven ve'Shimon," ve'chazar ve'amar lah: "Li'Reuven ve'Shimon," mahhu? Ba'ei Abaye asked her: "Behold, you are permitted to all men, except for Reuben and Simeon," and he went back and said to her: "To Reuben and Simeon," what is the ruling?

hebrew_text: מִי אָמְרִינַן: מַאי דַּאֲסַר שְׁרָא; אוֹ דִלְמָא – מַאי דַּאֲסַר שְׁרָא, וּמַאי דִּשְׁרָא אֲסַר? אִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר
human_translation: Do we say what he forbade he permitted, Or perhaps what he forbade he permitted, and what he permitted he forbade, If you say
llm_translation: Who said: What is the reason that he prohibited the ox; or perhaps - what is the reason that he prohibited the ox, and what is the reason that he permitted it? If you will find to say

hebrew_text: מַאי דַּאֲסַר שְׁרָא; ״לִרְאוּבֵן״, מַהוּ? לִרְאוּבֵן – וְהוּא הַדִּין לְשִׁמְעוֹן, וְהַאי דְּקָאָמַר לִרְאוּבֵן – מִשּׁוּם דִּפְתַח בֵּיהּ; אוֹ דִלְמָא – לִרְאוּבֵן דַּוְקָא?
human_translation: what he forbade he permitted, what is to Reuven? to Reuven and the same is true to Shimon, that he mentioned to Reuven because he opened by him Or perhaps, specifically to Reuven?
llm_translation: What is the reason that it is forbidden to use שְׁרָא? "For Reuben," what is it? For Reuben - and it is the same for Simeon, and this that it says "for Reuben" - is it because he opened it, or perhaps specifically for Reuben?

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר ״לִרְאוּבֵן״ דַּוְקָא; ״לְשִׁמְעוֹן״, מַהוּ? לְשִׁמְעוֹן – וְהוּא הַדִּין לִרְאוּבֵן, וְהַאי דְּקָאָמַר ״שִׁמְעוֹן״ – מִשּׁוּם דִּסְלֵיק מִינֵּיהּ; אוֹ דִלְמָא – לְשִׁמְעוֹן דַּוְקָא?
human_translation: And if you say to specifically Reuven what is to Shimon? to Shimon and the same is true to Reuven, and that he mentioned Shimon is because he ended by him? Or perhaps specifically to Shimon?
llm_translation: "And if you find to say 'to Reuven' specifically; 'to Shimon', what is it? To Shimon - and it is the same as to Reuven, and this that it says 'Shimon' - because he was removed from it; or perhaps - to Shimon specifically?"

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: ״אַף לְשִׁמְעוֹן״, מַהוּ? ״אַף״ – אַרְאוּבֵן קָאֵי; אוֹ דִלְמָא, ״אַף״ – אַעָלְמָא קָאֵי? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi raises dilemma also to Shimon, what is also referring to Reuven, or perhaps also referring to everyone, shall stand
llm_translation: Inquiry of Rav Ashi: "Even for Shimon," what is it? "Even" - Reuven is standing; or perhaps, "Even" - the world is standing? This remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: לְאַחַר פְּטִירָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, נִכְנְסוּ אַרְבָּעָה זְקֵנִים לְהָשִׁיב עַל דְּבָרָיו, אֵלּוּ הֵן: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי, וְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן, וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה, וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא.
human_translation: The Sages taught After the death of Rabbi Eliezer, four Sages entered to refute his statement. They were: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, Rabbi Tarfon, Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, and Rabbi Akiva.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: After the passing of Rabbi Eliezer, four elders entered to deliberate on his words, they are: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, Rabbi Tarfon, Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah, and Rabbi Akiva.

hebrew_text: נַעֲנָה רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן וְאָמַר: הֲרֵי שֶׁהָלְכָה זוֹ, וְנִישֵּׂאת לְאָחִיו שֶׁל זֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו, וּמֵת בְּלֹא בָּנִים – לֹא נִמְצָא זֶה עוֹקֵר דָּבָר מִן הַתּוֹרָה? הָא לָמַדְתָּ, שֶׁאֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Tarfon responded saying: she went and married the brother of the one to whom she was prohibited and died without children, Is not found uprooting a matter of Torah law You have therefore derived that this is not severance.
llm_translation: Rabbi Tarfon answered and said: Behold, this halakha, and it is carried to the brother of this one who was forbidden upon him, and he dies without children - is this not found to be uprooting a matter from the Torah? You have learned that this is not karet.

hebrew_text: נַעֲנָה רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי וְאָמַר: הֵיכָן מָצִינוּ אָסוּר לָזֶה וּמוּתָּר לָזֶה? הָאָסוּר – אָסוּר לַכֹּל, וְהַמּוּתָּר – מוּתָּר לַכֹּל! הָא לָמַדְתָּ, שֶׁאֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei responded saying: Where do we find forbidden to this and permitted to that What is forbidden is forbidden to everyone, and what is permitted is permitted to everyone. You have therefore derived that this is not severance.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean answered and said: Where do we find something prohibited for this and permitted for this? That which is prohibited - it is prohibited for everyone, and that which is permitted - it is permitted for everyone! This teaches us that this is not a case of excision.

hebrew_text: נַעֲנָה רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה וְאָמַר: ״כְּרִיתוּת״ – דָּבָר הַכּוֹרֵת בֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ. הָא לָמַדְתָּ, שֶׁאֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya responded, saying: severance,” something that severs between him and her You have therefore derived that this is not severance.
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah responded and said: "Keritut" - a matter that cuts between him and her. This teaches that this is not keritut.

hebrew_text: נַעֲנָה רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְאָמַר: הֲרֵי שֶׁהָלְכָה זוֹ וְנִשֵּׂאת לְאֶחָד מִן הַשּׁוּק וְהָיוּ לָהּ בָּנִים, וְנִתְאַרְמְלָה אוֹ נִתְגָּרְשָׁה, וְעָבְרָה וְנִישֵּׂאת לָזֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו – לֹא נִמְצָא גֵּט בָּטֵל, וּבָנֶיהָ מַמְזֵרִים? הָא לָמַדְתָּ, שֶׁאֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva responded, saying: she went and married a man from the public, and she had children and she was widowed or divorced and she arose and married the one to whom she was forbidden isn’t the bill of divorce found nullified? And her children born from an adulterous relationship [ mamzerim ], You have therefore derived that this is not severance,
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva answered and said: Behold, this halakha, if she went and married one from the marketplace and had children with him, and then she became widowed or divorced, and she went and married another man who is forbidden to her - the divorce document is not nullified, and her children are mamzerim? Have you not learned that this is not considered kritut.

hebrew_text: דָּבָר אַחֵר: הֲרֵי שֶׁהָיָה זֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו כֹּהֵן, וּמֵת הַמְגָרֵשׁ – לֹא נִמְצֵאת אַלְמָנָה אֶצְלוֹ, וּגְרוּשָׁה אֵצֶל כׇּל אָדָם?
human_translation: an alternative the one to whom she was forbidden was a priest, and who divorced died, is she not found a widow with regard to him, and a divorcée with regard to any man?
llm_translation: Another explanation: If this one was forbidden to a priest, and the one who divorced him dies - is there no widow with him, and a divorced woman with any man?

hebrew_text: וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר: מָה גְּרוּשָׁה – שֶׁהִיא קַלָּה, אֲסוּרָה בִּשְׁבִיל צַד גֵּירוּשִׁין שֶׁבָּהּ; אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ – שֶׁהִיא חֲמוּרָה. לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?! הָא לָמַדְתָּ, שֶׁאֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: And an a fortiori just as a divorcée is minor she is forbidden due to the element of divorce that applies to her, all the more so not a married woman, which is a major You have therefore derived that this is not severance,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And a fortiori: Just as a divorcee, who is light, is prohibited because of the aspect of divorce in her; a married woman, who is severe. Not all the more so?! You have learned that this is not a case of karet. English translation: And a fortiori: Just as a divorcee - who is light, is prohibited because of the aspect of divorce in her; a married woman - who is severe. Not all the more so?! You have learned that this is not a case of karet.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָהֶן רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: אֵין מְשִׁיבִין אֶת הָאֲרִי לְאַחַר מִיתָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: one does not refute a lion after death.
llm_translation: He said to them Rabbi Yehoshua: "Do not return the lion after death."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: כּוּלְּהוּ אִית לְהוּ פִּירְכָא, לְבַר מִדְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה – דְּלֵית לֵיהּ פִּירְכָא. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי: רוֹאֶה אֲנִי אֶת דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה מִדִּבְרֵי כּוּלָּן.
human_translation: Rava said: All of have refutations except for of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, which does not have a refutation. this is also taught Rabbi Yosei said: I see the statement of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya to the statements of all
llm_translation: Rava said: All of them have a Pircha, except for Bar MiD'Rabbi Elazar Ben Azariah - who has no Pircha. It was also taught similarly: Rabbi Yosei said: I see the words of Rabbi Elazar Ben Azariah as superior to all of them.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר, נַעֲנָה רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן וְאָמַר: הֲרֵי שֶׁהָלְכָה זוֹ וְנִשֵּׂאת לְאָחִיו שֶׁל זֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו, וּמֵת בְּלֹא בָּנִים – לֹא נִמְצָא זֶה עוֹקֵר דָּבָר מִן הַתּוֹרָה? עוֹקֵר?! אִיהוּ עָקַר?! אֶלָּא ״מַתְנֶה לַעֲקוֹר דָּבָר מִן הַתּוֹרָה״.
human_translation: The Master said Rabbi Tarfon responded, saying: she went and married the brother of the one to whom she was prohibited and he died without children, is not found uprooting a matter of Torah law? uprooting he is uprooting Rather, is stipulating to uproot a matter of Torah law.
llm_translation: Master said, Rabbi Tarfon answered and said: Behold, this halakha, and it is carried to the brother of this one who was forbidden upon him, and he dies without children - is this not found to be uprooting a matter from the Torah? Uprooting?! Did he uproot?! Rather, "a gift to uproot a matter from the Torah."

hebrew_text: מַתְנֶה?! מִי קָאָמַר לַהּ: לָא סַגִּי לַהּ דְּלָא מִינַּסְבָא לֵיהּ לַאֲחוּהּ דְּהָהוּא גַּבְרָא?! אֶלָּא ״גּוֹרֵם לַעֲקוֹר דָּבָר מִן הַתּוֹרָה״.
human_translation: stipulating Did he say to her it is not sufficient if she does not marry the brother of that man, Rather, is causing a matter of Torah law to be uprooted.
llm_translation: Gift?! Who said to her: it is not enough for her that she does not marry his brother?! Rather, "causing something to be uprooted from the Torah."

hebrew_text: גּוֹרֵם?! אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, בַּת אָחִיו לֹא יִשָּׂא – שֶׁמָּא יָמוּת בְּלֹא בָּנִים, וְנִמְצָא גּוֹרֵם לַעֲקוֹר דָּבָר מִן הַתּוֹרָה! הַיְינוּ פִּירְכָא.
human_translation: is causing But if that is so, should not marry his brother’s daughter lest he die without children, and he will be found causing a matter of Torah law to be uprooted This is the refutation
llm_translation: Causing?! Rather from now on, his brother's daughter he shall not marry - lest he die childless, and it will be found that he is causing a matter to be uprooted from the Torah! That is the explanation.

hebrew_text: וּבְמַאי? אִילֵימָא בְּ״חוּץ״, מִשְׁרָא שָׁרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר!
human_translation: And with regard to what If we say with regard to except Rabbi Eliezer permits
llm_translation: And with what? If you say with "outside," it is permitted according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer!

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בִּמְגָרֵשׁ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ, וְאָמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם, חוּץ מִפְּלוֹנִי״, וְהָלְכָה וְנִיסֵּת לְאֶחָד מִן הַשּׁוּק, וְנִתְאַרְמְלָה אוֹ נִתְגָּרְשָׁה, שֶׁמּוּתֶּרֶת לָזֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו!
human_translation: As it is taught With regard to divorces his wife and said to her You are hereby permitted to any man except for so-and-so, and she went and married someone from the public and was widowed or divorced Rabbi Eliezer concedes that she is permitted to whom she was prohibited
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi Eliezer admits in the case of a divorce that a man may say to his wife, "Behold, you are permitted to everyone except for so-and-so," and if she went and engaged in conversation with one of the men in the marketplace, and she was either seduced or divorced, she is permitted to the one upon whom she was forbidden!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא בְּ״עַל מְנָת״.
human_translation: Rather, with regard to on the condition
llm_translation: Rather, with "ba'al menat."

hebrew_text: נַעֲנָה רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי וְאָמַר: הֵיכָן מָצִינוּ אָסוּר לָזֶה וּמוּתָּר לָזֶה? הָאָסוּר – אָסוּר לַכֹּל, וְהַמּוּתָּר – מוּתָּר לַכֹּל. וְלָא?! וַהֲרֵי תְּרוּמָה וְקָדָשִׁים, שֶׁאֲסוּרָה לָזֶה, וּמוּתֶּרֶת לָזֶה! בְּאִיסּוּר אִשָּׁה קָא אָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili responded, saying: Where do we find forbidden to this and permitted to that What is forbidden is forbidden to everyone and what is permitted is permitted to everyone. Is not Aren’t teruma , and sacrificial forbidden to this and permitted to that We are referring to a forbidden woman.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean answered and said: Where do we find something prohibited for this one and permitted for that one? That which is prohibited is prohibited for everyone, and that which is permitted is permitted for everyone. Is it not so? But behold, regarding terumah and holy items, which are prohibited for this one and permitted for that one! We are speaking about a prohibition related to a woman.

hebrew_text: וַהֲרֵי עֲרָיוֹת! בְּאִישׁוּת קָאָמְרִינַן.
human_translation: Aren’t those with whom relations are prohibited We are referring to marriage.
llm_translation: And behold, the forbidden relationships! We are speaking about betrothal.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ! הַיְינוּ פִּירְכָא.
human_translation: Isn’t a married woman This is the refutation
llm_translation: Behold, the wife of a man! This is Pircha.

hebrew_text: וּבְמַאי? אִילֵּימָא בְּ״עַל מְנָת״ – הֲרֵי הוּתְּרָה אֶצְלוֹ בִּזְנוּת! אֶלָּא בְּ״חוּץ״.
human_translation: And with regard to what If we say with regard to on the condition she is permitted in licentiousness with him; Rather, with regard to except
llm_translation: And with what? If you say with "ba'al menat" - behold, she is permitted to him for licentiousness! Rather, with "chutz."

hebrew_text: נַעֲנָה רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא וְאָמַר: הֲרֵי שֶׁהָלְכָה זוֹ וְנִישֵּׂאת לְאֶחָד מִן הַשּׁוּק וְהָיוּ לָהּ בָּנִים, וְנִתְאַרְמְלָה אוֹ נִתְגָּרְשָׁה, וְעָמְדָה וְנִשֵּׂאת לָזֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו, לֹא נִמְצָא גֵּט בָּטֵל וּבָנֶיהָ מַמְזֵרִין?
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva responded, saying: she went and married a man from the public, and she had children and she was widowed or divorced and she arose and married the one to whom she was forbidden, isn’t the bill of divorce nullified? And her children mamzerim ?
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva answered and said: Behold, this halakha, if she went and married one from the marketplace and had children with him, and then she became widowed or divorced, and she stood and married this one whom she is forbidden to, her get is not nullified, and her children are mamzerim?

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי – בְּכוּלְּהוּ תְּנָאֵי דְּעָלְמָא נָמֵי לָא תִּנְּסִיב, דִּלְמָא לָא מְקַיְּימָא לֵיהּ לִתְנָאֵיהּ וְנִמְצָא גֵּט בָּטֵל וּבָנֶיהָ מַמְזֵרִין! הַיְינוּ פִּירְכָא.
human_translation: If that is so, in any typical condition she should not remarry either, lest she not fulfill his condition and the bill of divorce found nullified and her children mamzerim . This is the refutation
llm_translation: If so - in all the teachings of the world, they do not agree, perhaps it will not be established, lest it be established for his teachings and a divorce document will be found null and her children will be considered mamzerim! That is the explanation.

hebrew_text: וּבְמַאי? אִילֵימָא בְּ״חוּץ״, מִשְׁרָא שָׁרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר!
human_translation: And with regard to what If we say with regard to except Rabbi Eliezer permits
llm_translation: And with what? If you say with "outside," it is permitted according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer!

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: מוֹדֶה הָיָה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בִּמְגָרֵשׁ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ, וְאָמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם, חוּץ מִפְּלוֹנִי״, וְהָלְכָה וְנִשֵּׂאת לְאֶחָד מִן הַשּׁוּק וְנִתְאַרְמְלָה אוֹ נִתְגָּרְשָׁה, שֶׁמּוּתֶּרֶת לָזֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו! אֶלָּא בְּ״עַל מְנָת״.
human_translation: As it is taught With regard to divorces his wife and said to her: You are hereby permitted to any man except for so-and-so, and she went and married someone from the public, and was widowed or divorced Rabbi Eliezer concedes that she is permitted to whom she was prohibited Rather, with regard to a condition
llm_translation: Talmudic text: It was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi Eliezer would divorce his wife in a field, and he said to her: "Behold, you are permitted to every man except for so-and-so," and the halakha is that she may go and marry one of the men from the market and either become pregnant or be divorced, for she is permitted to this one whom she was forbidden to! Rather, it is in the case of "a conditional husband."

hebrew_text: דָּבָר אַחֵר: הֲרֵי שֶׁהָיָה זֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו כֹּהֵן, וּמֵת הַמְגָרֵשׁ, לֹא נִמְצֵאת אַלְמָנָה אֶצְלוֹ, וּגְרוּשָׁה אֵצֶל כׇּל אָדָם? וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה גְּרוּשָׁה שֶׁהִיא קַלָּה – אֲסוּרָה מִשּׁוּם צַד גֵּירוּשִׁין שֶׁבָּהּ, אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ חֲמוּרָה – לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?!
human_translation: an alternative the one to whom she was forbidden was a priest, and who divorced died, is she not found a widow with regard to him and a divorcée with regard to any man? And an a fortiori just as a divorcée is minor, she is forbidden due to the element of divorce that applies to her, all the more so not a married woman, which is major,
llm_translation: Another explanation: If this one was forbidden to a priest, and the one who divorced him dies, there is no widow found with him, and a divorced woman is with any man? And an a fortiori argument: And if a divorced woman, who is light, is forbidden due to the aspect of her divorces, a married woman, who is severe - all the more so?!

hebrew_text: וּבְמַאי? אִילֵּימָא בְּ״עַל מְנָת״,
human_translation: And with regard to what If we say with regard to a condition,
llm_translation: And with what? Perhaps with "ba'al menat,"

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי גְּרוּשָׁה אֶצְלוֹ – בִּזְנוּת! אֶלָּא בְּ״חוּץ״.
human_translation: isn’t a divorcée with regard to licentious with him? Rather, with regard to exception.
llm_translation: Behold, a divorced woman with him - adultery! Rather, in "outside."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, אִי ״חוּץ״ סְבִירָא לֵיהּ – לוֹתֵיב ״חוּץ״, וְאִי ״עַל מְנָת״ סְבִירָא לֵיהּ – לוֹתֵיב ״עַל מְנָת״!
human_translation: If Rabbi Akiva holds an exception, he should raise an objection an exception, and if he holds a stipulation, he should raise an objection a stipulation.
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva: If he deems "outside" likely - he should state "outside," and if he deems "on condition" likely - he should state "on condition"!

hebrew_text: רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא שְׁמִיעַ לֵיהּ דְּאִיכָּא דְּאָמַר ״חוּץ״ וְאִיכָּא דְּאָמַר ״עַל מְנָת״; מַאן דְּאָמַר ״חוּץ״ – הַאי פִּירְכָא, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר ״עַל מְנָת״ – הַאי פִּירְכָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Akiva heard that there is who states an exception, and there is who states a stipulation. the one who says an exception, this is the refutation, and the one who says a stipulation, that is the refutation.
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva heard from someone who said "outside" and from someone who said "on condition"; the one who said "outside" - this is the explanation, and the one who said "on condition" - this is the explanation.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי פִּירְכָא? אִי נֵימָא אִיסּוּר כְּהוּנָּה שָׁאנֵי, הָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר נָמֵי מֵאִיסּוּר כְּהוּנָּה קָא מַיְיתֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: What is the refutation If we say the prohibition priesthood is different, doesn’t Rabbi Eliezer also derive from the prohibition the priesthood?
llm_translation: And what is the question? If you say that the prohibition of priesthood is different, behold, Rabbi Eliezer also derives it from the prohibition of priesthood!

hebrew_text: רָבָא – כְּרַבִּי יַנַּאי מִשּׁוּם זָקֵן אֶחָד קָא מַתְנֵי.
human_translation: Rava taught in accordance with Rabbi Yannai, in the name of one elder
llm_translation: Rava - like Rabbi Yannai in the name of one elder, is teaching.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָהֶן רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: אֵין מְשִׁיבִין אֶת הָאֲרִי לְאַחַר מִיתָה. לְמֵימְרָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ כְּווֹתֵיהּ סְבִירָא לֵיהּ?! וְהָא אִיהוּ נָמֵי מִיפְרָךְ קָפָרֵיךְ!
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: One does not refute a lion after death. Is this to say that Rabbi Yehoshua holds in accordance with But doesn’t he also raise a refutation
llm_translation: He said to them Rabbi Yehoshua: One does not return the lion after its death. Is it to be said that Rabbi Yehoshua agrees with his colleagues?! But he himself breaks your horns!

hebrew_text: הָכִי קָאָמַר לְהוּ: לְדִידִי נָמֵי אִית לִי פִּירְכָא; מִיהוּ בֵּין לְדִידִי, בֵּין לְדִידְכוּ – אֵין מְשִׁיבִין אֶת הָאֲרִי לְאַחַר מִיתָה.
human_translation: this is what he was saying to them: I also have a refutation but both my and yours one does not refute a lion after death.
llm_translation: So he said to them: According to my opinion, I have a rebuttal; however, whether for me or for you - we do not return the lion after its death.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי פִּירְכָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ? דְּתַנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: מַקִּישׁ קוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה שְׁנִיָּה, לְקוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה רִאשׁוֹנָה; מָה קוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה רִאשׁוֹנָה – דְּלָא אֲגִידָא בְּאִינִישׁ אַחֲרִינָא; אַף קוֹדְמֵי הֲוָיָה שְׁנִיָּה – דְּלָא אֲגִידָא בְּאִינִישׁ אַחֲרִינָא.
human_translation: And what is Rabbi Yehoshua’s refutation? as it is taught Rabbi Yehoshua said juxtaposes before the second marriage to before the first marriage. just as before the first marriage she is not bound to another man, so too, before the second marriage she is not bound to another man.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And what is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehoshua? For it was taught, Rabbi Yehoshua said: One who makes the latter first, let the latter be first; just as when one makes the latter first, it is not mentioned in connection with another person, so too when one makes the latter first, it is not mentioned in connection with another person.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא – מוֹדֶה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בִּמְגָרֵשׁ אִשְׁתּוֹ וְאָמַר לָהּ: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם חוּץ מִפְּלוֹנִי״, וְהָלְכָה וְנִישֵּׂאת לְאֶחָד מִן הַשּׁוּק, וְנִתְאַרְמְלָה אוֹ נִתְגָּרְשָׁה, שֶׁמּוּתֶּרֶת לָזֶה שֶׁנֶּאֶסְרָה עָלָיו.
human_translation: the itself With regard to divorces his wife and said to her: You are hereby permitted to any man except for so-and-so, and she went and married someone from the public and was widowed or divorced Rabbi Eliezer concedes that she is permitted to whom she was prohibited
llm_translation: Body - Rabbi Eliezer admits in the case of his wife and said to her: "Behold, you are permitted to every man except for so-and-so," and she walked and was taken by one from the market, and she either became leprous or was divorced, for she is permitted to this one whom she was forbidden to.

hebrew_text: הֵשִׁיב רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בַּר אֶלְעָזָר תְּשׁוּבָה לְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: הֵיכָן מָצִינוּ שֶׁזֶּה אוֹסֵר וְזֶה מַתִּיר?
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon bar Elazar raised a refutation to Rabbi Eliezer’s statement: Where do we find where this prohibits and that permits
llm_translation: Rebbe Shimon bar Elazar responded with a return to the words of Rabbi Eliezer: Where do we find that this one prohibits and that one permits?

hebrew_text: וְלָא?! וַהֲרֵי יְבָמָה – דְּבַעַל אוֹסֵר, וְיָבָם מַתִּיר!
human_translation: not But isn’t a yevama , whose husband deems forbidden and yavam , deems permitted
llm_translation: And no?! But behold, yevamah - who the levir prohibits, and the yavam permits!

hebrew_text: הָתָם, יָבָם הוּא קָא אָסַר לַהּ, דְּאִי מִבַּעַל – הָא שַׁרְיָא וְקָיְימָא.
human_translation: There, it is the yavam who renders her forbidden, since if she would have already been released from husband
llm_translation: There, yavam he is prohibiting to her, for if from husband - this permitted and established.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי נְדָרִים, דְּנוֹדֵר אוֹסֵר וְחָכָם מַתִּיר! הָא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֵין חָכָם מַתִּיר כְּלוּם אֶלָּא בַּחֲרָטָה.
human_translation: Isn’t vows, where one who takes the vow prohibits and a halakhic authority renders permitted Rabbi Yoḥanan says a halakhic authority dissolves only through regret
llm_translation: Behold, vows, one who vows prohibits and a sage permits! This is what Rabbi Yochanan said: A sage only permits through regret.

hebrew_text: הֲרֵי הֲפָרַת הַבַּעַל, דְּאִשָּׁה נוֹדֶרֶת וּבַעַל מֵיפֵר! הָתָם כִּדְרַב פִּנְחָס מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרָבָא – דְּאָמַר רַב פִּנְחָס מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: כׇּל הַנּוֹדֶרֶת – עַל דַּעַת בַּעְלָהּ הִיא נוֹדֶרֶת.
human_translation: Isn’t the nullification of the husband, where wife vows, and husband nullifies There in accordance with Rav Pineḥas in the name of Rava, as Rav Pineḥas says in the name of Rava any woman who takes a vow, on her husband’s consent she takes the vow.
llm_translation: Behold the case of the husband nullifying the vow of his wife! There, as Rav Pinchas said in the name of Rava - for Rav Pinchas said in the name of Rava: Every vow - she makes it with the knowledge of her husband.

hebrew_text: נַעֲנָה רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה וְאָמַר: ״כְּרִיתוּת״ – דָּבָר הַכּוֹרֵת בֵּינוֹ לְבֵינָהּ; הָא לָמַדְתָּ, שֶׁאֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya responded, saying: severance [ keritut ],” something that severs between him and her You have therefore derived that this is not severance.
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah responded and said: "Keritut" - a matter that cuts between him and her; you have learned that this is not keritut.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן, הַאי ״כְּרִיתוּת״ מַאי עָבְדִי לֵיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לְהוּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״הֲרֵי זֶה גִּיטִּיךְ עַל מְנָת שֶׁלֹּא תִּשְׁתִּי יַיִן; עַל מְנָת שֶׁלֹּא תֵּלְכִי לְבֵית אָבִיךְ״; ״לְעוֹלָם״ – אֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת. ״שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״ – הֲרֵי זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: And what do the Rabbis, do with this “severance”? They need it for that which is taught This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will not drink wine, On the condition that you will never go to your father’s house, that is not severance, thirty days, that is severance.
llm_translation: The sages, what does this "keritut" do to it? They want to learn it according to the teaching: "Here is your divorce on the condition that you do not drink wine; on the condition that you do not go to your father's house"; "forever" - this is not keritut. "Thirty days" - this is keritut.

hebrew_text: וְאִידָּךְ – מִ״כָּרֵת–כְּרִיתוּת״ נָפְקָא. וְאִידַּךְ – ״כָּרֵת–כְּרִיתוּת״ לָא דָּרְשִׁי.
human_translation: And the other It is derived from karet , keritut . And the other They do not interpret karet keritut .
llm_translation: And the other - from "karet-kritut" emerges. And the other - "karet-kritut" did not expound.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: ״הֲרֵי זֶה גִּיטִּיךְ, עַל מְנָת שֶׁלֹּא תִּשְׁתִּי יַיִן״; ״כׇּל יְמֵי חַיַּי״ – אֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת. ״כׇּל יְמֵי חַיֵּי פְּלוֹנִי״ – הֲרֵי זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: Rava says This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will not drink wine all the days of my life, that is not severance, all the days of the life of so-and-so, that is severance.
llm_translation: Rava said: "Here is your bill of divorce, on the condition that you do not drink wine"; "all the days of my life" - this is not a complete severance. "All the days of the life of so-and-so" - this is a complete severance.

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא חַיֵּי פְלוֹנִי – דְּדִלְמָא מָאֵית וּמְקַיְּימָא לֵיהּ לִתְנָאֵיהּ; חַיֵּי דִידֵיהּ נָמֵי – דִּלְמָא מָאֵית, וּמְקַיְּימָא לֵיהּ לִתְנָאֵיהּ!
human_translation: What is different the life of so-and-so? because perhaps will die and she will fulfill the condition, his own life also perhaps he will die and she will fulfill the condition.
llm_translation: What is the difference between the life of so-and-so - that perhaps he exists and fulfills his obligations; our own lives are uncertain - perhaps we exist, and fulfill our obligations!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אֵימָא: ״כׇּל יְמֵי חַיֵּיכִי״ – אֵין זֶה כְּרִיתוּת, ״כׇּל יְמֵי חַיַּי״ אוֹ ״חַיֵּי פְלוֹנִי״ – הֲרֵי זֶה כְּרִיתוּת.
human_translation: Rather, say all the days of your life, that is not severance, all the days of my life, or: so-and-so’s life, that is severance,
llm_translation: Rather say: "All the days of your life" - this is not a cutting off, "all the days of my life" or "the life of so-and-so" - this is a cutting off.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבָא מֵרַב נַחְמָן: ״הַיּוֹם אִי אַתְּ אִשְׁתִּי, וּלְמָחָר אַתְּ אִשְׁתִּי״, מַהוּ? תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman: Today you are not my wife, and tomorrow you are my wife, what is Let the dilemma be raised according to Rabbi Eliezer let the dilemma be raised according to the Rabbis.
llm_translation: Requested from him Rava from Rav Nachman: "Today you are my wife, and tomorrow you are my wife," what is the ruling? Should it be asked to Rabbi Eliezer, or should it be asked to the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הָתָם, אֶלָּא דִּלְמַאן דְּקָא שָׁרֵי – קָא שָׁרֵי לְעוֹלָם; אֲבָל הָכָא – לָא. אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא.
human_translation: Let the dilemma be raised according to Rabbi Eliezer: Is Rabbi Eliezer saying only there, because concerning the one whom permits he permits to marry him forever, but here, not Or perhaps it is no different
llm_translation: The question was asked to Rabbi Eliezer - until here Rabbi Eliezer did not say there, but perhaps according to whom it is permitted - it is permitted forever; but here - no. Or perhaps it is not different.

hebrew_text: תִּיבְּעֵי לְרַבָּנַן – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן הָתָם, אֶלָּא דְּלָא פַּסְקַהּ מִינֵּיהּ לִגְמָרֵי; אֲבָל הָכָא, כֵּיוָן דְּפַסְקַהּ – פַּסְקַהּ.
human_translation: Let the dilemma be raised according to the Rabbis: the Rabbis are saying only there because did not separate her from himself entirely, But here, once he separates her, he has separated her
llm_translation: The sages asked - until here the sages did not say there, rather that she did not completely cut it off from him; but here, once she cut it off - she cut it off.

hebrew_text: בָּתַר דְּבַעְיָא, הֲדַר פַּשְׁטַהּ:
human_translation: After raised the dilemma he then resolved it
llm_translation: After Be'aya inquired, he then explained:

hebrew_text: מִסְתַּבְּרָא, בֵּין לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֵּין לְרַבָּנַן, כֵּיוָן דְּפַסְקַהּ – פַּסְקַהּ.
human_translation: It stands to reason, both according to Rabbi Eliezer and according to the Rabbis, once he separates her, he has separated her
llm_translation: When it is clear, whether for Rabbi Eliezer or for the Rabbis, once he has decided - he has decided.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״הֲרֵי זֶה גִּיטִּיךְ עַל מְנָת שֶׁתִּנָּשְׂאִי לִפְלוֹנִי״ – הֲרֵי זוֹ לֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא, וְאִם נִשֵּׂאת – לֹא תֵּצֵא.
human_translation: The Sages taught This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you marry so-and-so, she may not marry but if she marries she not leave
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "Here is your bill of divorce on the condition that you marry Ploni" - if she does not marry Ploni, she shall not marry, and if she does marry, she shall not leave.

hebrew_text: מַאי קָאָמַר? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן, הָכִי קָאָמַר: הֲרֵי זוֹ לֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא לוֹ, שֶׁמָּא יֹאמְרוּ נְשֵׁיהֶן נוֹתְנִין בְּמַתָּנָה. וְאִם נִשֵּׂאת לְאַחֵר – לֹא תֵּצֵא.
human_translation: What is saying? Rav Naḥman said this is what is saying: She may not marry him, lest say are giving their wives as a gift. But if she marries another she not leave
llm_translation: What is he saying? Rav Nachman said, thus he is saying: This one should not be married to him, lest their wives give as a gift. And if she is married to another - she shall not leave.

hebrew_text: וּמִשּׁוּם גְּזֵרָה – לָא מַפְּקִינַן מִינֵּיהּ, וְשָׁרֵינַן אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ לְעָלְמָא?!
human_translation: Do we not remove her from him, allowing a married woman to anyone, due to decree,
llm_translation: And because of the decree - we do not remove from it, and we permit a man's wife for eternity?!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן, הָכִי קָאָמַר: הֲרֵי זוֹ לֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא לוֹ, שֶׁמָּא יֹאמְרוּ נְשֵׁיהֶם נוֹתְנִין בְּמַתָּנָה. וְאִם נִשֵּׂאת לוֹ – לֹא תֵּצֵא, דְּמִשּׁוּם גְּזֵרָה לָא מַפְּקִינַן.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Naḥman said this is what is saying: She may not marry him, lest say they are giving their wives as a gift. But if she marries him she not leave as we do not remove due to a decree.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Nachman said, thus he is saying: This one shall not be married to him, lest their wives say they give as a gift. And if she is married to him - she shall not leave, because of the decree we do not annul.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: לוֹ – הוּא דְּלֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא, הָא לְאַחֵר – תִּנָּשֵׂא?! וְהָא בָּעֲיָא קַיּוֹמֵיהּ לִתְנָאָה!
human_translation: Rava said to it is to him that she may not get married, but she may marry another But isn’t required fulfill the condition
llm_translation: He said to him, Rava: "For him - that he should not marry, but for another - he should marry?! And this requires clarification according to the Mishnah!"

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא: אֶפְשָׁר דְּמִינַּסְבָא הַיּוֹם וּמִיגָּרְשָׁה לִמְחַר – וּמְקַיְּימָא לִתְנָאָה; וּלְהָךְ דִּפְלִיגַתְּ עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַב יְהוּדָה קָמְדַמֵּית לֵיהּ – דְּאִתְּמַר: ״קֻוֽנָּם עֵינַי בְּשֵׁינָה הַיּוֹם, אִם אִישַׁן לְמָחָר״, אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: אַל יִישַׁן הַיּוֹם, שֶׁמָּא יִישַׁן לְמָחָר;
human_translation: And if you would say it is possible for her to get married today and get divorced tomorrow and fulfill condition and you compare it to that over which you disagree with Rav Yehuda. As it was stated Sleeping is as if an offering [ konam ] for my eyes today if I will sleep tomorrow, Rav Yehuda says he may not sleep today lest he sleep tomorrow,
llm_translation: And if you will say: Perhaps one can engage in sexual relations today and divorce tomorrow - and fulfill the obligation; and to counter the argument of Rav Yehudah who opposes it - for it was stated: "I will set my eyes upon the harlotry today, if she will sleep with another tomorrow," Rav Yehudah said: One should not engage in sexual relations today, lest he engage in sexual relations tomorrow.

hebrew_text: וְרַב נַחְמָן אָמַר: יִישַׁן הַיּוֹם, וְאֵין חוֹשְׁשִׁין שֶׁמָּא יִישַׁן לְמָחָר;
human_translation: And Rav Naḥman says: He may sleep today, and we are not concerned that perhaps he will sleep tomorrow,
llm_translation: And Rav Nachman said: One may sleep during the day, and we are not concerned that perhaps he will sleep tomorrow.

hebrew_text: הָכִי הַשְׁתָּא?! הָתָם בְּדִידֵיהּ קָיְימָא, דְּאִי בָּעֵי – מְבָרֵיז נַפְשֵׁיהּ בְּסִילְוָאתָא, וְלָא נָאֵים; הָכָא – בְּדִידַהּ קָיְימָא לְאִיגָּרוֹשֵׁי?!
human_translation: How can be compared? There, is in his as, if he wants he can prick himself with thorns [ silevata ] and he will not fall asleep. Here, is it in to get divorced?
llm_translation: So now?! There, on its own, it stands, for if it desires – it separates itself with a garment, and it is not fitting; here – on its own, does it stand for divorce?!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: הֲרֵי זוֹ לֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא לֹא לוֹ, וְלֹא לְאַחֵר. לוֹ לֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא – שֶׁמָּא יֹאמְרוּ: נְשׁוֹתֵיהֶם נוֹתְנִין בְּמַתָּנָה; לְאַחֵר לֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא – דְּבָעֲיָא קַיּוֹמֵיהּ לִתְנָאָה.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said This may marry neither nor another She may not marry him lest say are giving their wives as a gift, she may not marry another because she is required to fulfill condition.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: Behold, this one shall not be married neither to him, nor to another. Not to him shall she be married - lest they say: their wives give gifts; not to another shall she be married - for it requires fulfillment of a condition.

hebrew_text: וְאִם נִשֵּׂאת לוֹ לֹא תֵּצֵא – דְּמִשּׁוּם גְּזֵרָה לָא מַפְּקִינַן; לְאַחֵר תֵּצֵא – דְּבָעֲיָא לְקַיּוֹמֵיהּ לִתְנָאָה.
human_translation: And if she marries she not leave as we do not remove due to a decree. to another she must leave as she is required to fulfill condition
llm_translation: "And if she is married to him, she shall not go out" - because of the decree, we do not remove her; "she shall go out to another" - because he wants to fulfill her marriage contract."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: הֲרֵי זוֹ לֹא תִּנָּשֵׂא לֹא לוֹ וְלֹא לְאַחֵר, וְאִם נִשֵּׂאת לוֹ – לֹא תֵּצֵא, לְאַחֵר – תֵּצֵא.
human_translation: It is taught in accordance with Rava: This may marry neither him nor another but if she marries him she not leave to another she must leave
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rava: Behold, this one shall not be married neither to him nor to another, and if she is married to him - she shall not leave, to another - she shall leave.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״הֲרֵי זֶה גִּיטִּךְ עַל מְנָת שֶׁתַּעֲלִי לָרָקִיעַ״; ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁתֵּרְדִי לַתְּהוֹם״; ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁתִּבְלְעִי קָנֶה שֶׁל אַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת״; ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁתָּבִיאִי לִי קָנֶה בֶּן מֵאָה אַמָּה״; ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁתַּעַבְרִי אֶת הַיָּם הַגָּדוֹל בְּרַגְלַיִךְ״ – אֵינוֹ גֵּט.
human_translation: The Sages taught This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you ascend to the sky, on the condition that you descend to the depths on the condition that you swallow a four-cubit reed, on the condition that you bring me a hundred-cubit reed, on the condition that you cross the Great Sea, by foot, it is not a bill of divorce.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "Here is your bill of divorce on the condition that you ascend to the sky"; "on the condition that you descend to the depths"; "on the condition that you swallow a reed measuring four cubits"; "on the condition that you bring me a reed of one hundred cubits"; "on the condition that you cross the great sea on foot" - this is not a valid bill of divorce.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן תֵּימָא אוֹמֵר: כָּזֶה – גֵּט. כְּלָל אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן תֵּימָא: כׇּל תְּנַאי שֶׁאִי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹ לְקַיְּימוֹ בְּסוֹפוֹ, וְהִתְנָה עָלָיו מִתְּחִילָּתוֹ – אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא כְּמַפְלִיגָהּ בִּדְבָרִים, וְכָשֵׁר.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima says: like this bill of divorce, Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima said principle: any condition that cannot be fulfilled in the end, yet stipulated it initially, he is only hyperbolizing. and is valid
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Tema says: "Like this - a get." Rabbi Yehuda ben Tema said in general: Any stipulation that cannot be fulfilled in the end, and was stipulated upon from the beginning - it is nothing but like a dispute in words, and it is valid.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַב: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן תֵּימָא. אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: מַתְנִיתִין נָמֵי דַּיְקָא, דְּקָתָנֵי: כׇּל שֶׁאֶפְשָׁר לוֹ לְקַיְּימוֹ בְּסוֹפוֹ, וְהִתְנָה עָלָיו בִּתְחִילָּתוֹ – תְּנָאוֹ קַיָּים; הָא אִי אֶפְשָׁר – תְּנָאוֹ בָּטֵל; שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman says Rav says: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: the mishna is also precisely as it teaches: any that can be fulfilled in the end and stipulated initially, his condition stands Consequently, his condition cannot it is void. Learn from it
llm_translation: Rav Nahman said in the name of Rav: The halacha is according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima. Rav Nahman bar Yitzhak said: The Mishnah supports this, as it teaches: "Anything that one can fulfill in the end, and he accepted upon himself at the beginning - his vow is valid; but if it is impossible - his vow is annulled." Learn from this.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: ״הֲרֵי זֶה גִּיטִּיךְ עַל מְנָת שֶׁתֹּאכְלִי בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר״, מַהוּ? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הִיא הִיא. רָבָא אָמַר: אֶפְשָׁר דְּאָכְלָה וְלָקְיָא.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you eat pig meat, what is Abaye said: It is the same. Rava said: It is possible for her to eat and be flogged
llm_translation: The Gemara raises a dilemma: "Here is your bill of divorce on the condition that you eat pork," what is the law? Abaye said: It is valid. Rava said: It is possible that she ate and vomited.

hebrew_text: לְאַבָּיֵי, ״כְּלָל״ – לְאֵתוֹיֵי בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר. לְרָבָא, ״כָּזֶה״ – לְמַעוֹטֵי בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר.
human_translation: According to Abaye, principle to include pig meat. According to Rava, like this to exclude pig meat,
llm_translation: To Abbaye, "klal" - to include pig meat. To Rava, "kazeh" - to exclude pig meat.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״הֲרֵי זֶה גִּיטִּךְ עַל מְנָת שֶׁתִּבָּעֲלִי לִפְלוֹנִי״, נִתְקַיֵּים הַתְּנַאי – הֲרֵי זֶה גֵּט, וְאִם לָאו – אֵינוֹ גֵּט. ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁלֹּא תִּבָּעֲלִי לְאַבָּא, וּלְאָבִיךְ״ – אֵין חוֹשְׁשִׁין שֶׁמָּא נִבְעֲלָה לָהֶן.
human_translation: raises an objection This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you engage in sexual intercourse with so-and-so, the condition is fulfilled, this is bill of divorce. And if not it is not bill of divorce. On the condition that you do not engage in sexual intercourse with my father or your father, we are not concerned that perhaps she engaged in sexual intercourse with them.
llm_translation: Challenger: "Here is your bill of divorce on condition that you marry Ploni." If the condition is fulfilled - it is a valid divorce, but if not - it is not a divorce. "On condition that you do not marry Abba and your father" - we are not concerned that perhaps she may have married them.

hebrew_text: וְאִילּוּ ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁתִּבָּעֲלִי לְאַבָּא וּלְאָבִיךְ״ – לָא קָתָנֵי; לְאַבָּיֵי נִיחָא, לְרָבָא קַשְׁיָא!
human_translation: But does not teach On the condition that you engage in sexual intercourse with my father or your father, According to Abaye works out well, According to Rava difficult.
llm_translation: "And if 'on the condition that you marry Abba and your father' – it is not taught; for Abbaye it is fine, for Rava it is difficult!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ רָבָא: בִּשְׁלָמָא בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר – אֶפְשָׁר דְּאָכְלָה וְלָקְיָא; פְּלוֹנִי נָמֵי – אֶפְשָׁר דִּמְשַׁחֲדָא לֵיהּ בְּמָמוֹנָא; אֶלָּא אַבָּא וְאָבִיךְ – בְּדִידַהּ קָיְימָא?! נְהִי דְּאִיהִי עָבְדָא אִיסּוּרָא, אַבָּא וְאָבִיךְ מִי עָבְדִי אִיסּוּרָא?!
human_translation: Rava said to you: Granted, pig meat it is possible for her to eat and be flogged. so-and-so, it is also possible for her to bribe him with money But father or your father, is it in her Though she can perform a forbidden act would father or your father perform a forbidden act?
llm_translation: Rava said to you: With regard to pork meat - it is possible that one may eat it and be acquitted; so-and-so, the name of a certain person - it is possible that he bribed him with money; but your father and your mother - is it possible that they transgressed?! Even if he committed a sin, did your father and your mother commit a sin?!

hebrew_text: לְרָבָא, ״כְּלָל״ – לְאֵתוֹיֵי אַבָּא וְאָבִיךְ; ״כָּזֶה״ – לְמַעוֹטֵי בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר.
human_translation: according to Rava, principle to include my father and your father, like this to exclude pig meat,
llm_translation: To Ravah, "klal" - to include both father and mother; "kazeh" - to exclude pig flesh.

hebrew_text: לְאַבָּיֵי, ״כְּלָל״ – לְאֵתוֹיֵי בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר; ״כָּזֶה״ – לְמַעוֹטֵי פְּלוֹנִי.
human_translation: according to Abaye principle to include pig meat, like this to exclude so-and-so,
llm_translation: To Abbaye, "klal" - to include pig meat; "kazeh" - to exclude a specific individual.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״הֲרֵי זֶה גִּיטִּיךְ עַל מְנָת שֶׁתֹּאכְלִי בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר״; וְאִם הָיְתָה זָרָה – ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁתֹּאכְלִי בִּתְרוּמָה״; וְאִם הָיְתָה נְזִירָה – ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁתִּשְׁתִּי יַיִן״; נִתְקַיֵּים הַתְּנַאי – הֲרֵי זֶה גֵּט; וְאִם לָאו – אֵינוֹ גֵּט. לְרָבָא נִיחָא, לְאַבָּיֵי קַשְׁיָא!
human_translation: raises an objection This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you eat pig meat; or if she was a non-priestess, On the condition that you partake of teruma ; or if she was a nazirite On the condition that you drink wine the condition is fulfilled it is bill of divorce, and if not, it is not bill of divorce. works out well according to Rava, according to Abaye difficult.
llm_translation: Challenger: "Here is your bill of divorce on the condition that you eat pork"; and if she was a stranger - "on the condition that you eat terumah"; and if she was a nazirite - "on the condition that you drink wine"; if the condition is fulfilled - this is a bill of divorce; and if not - it is not a bill of divorce. Rava finds it satisfactory, but Abaye finds it difficult!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לָךְ אַבָּיֵי: מִי סָבְרַתְּ דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל הִיא?! הָא מַנִּי – רַבָּנַן הִיא.
human_translation: Abaye said to you: Do you hold is agreed by everyone? whose is this It is the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Abaye said to you: Who thinks that the words of everyone are the same?! Here, it is the opinion of the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ דְּמַתְנֶה עַל מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה הוּא, וְכׇל הַמַּתְנֶה עַל מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה – תְּנָאוֹ בָּטֵל!
human_translation: derive that is stipulating counter to that which is written in the Torah, and anyone who stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void.
llm_translation: And let him bring forth that he is relying on what is written in the Torah, and anyone who relies on what is written in the Torah - his claim is nullified!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַדָּא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִיקָא: כִּי אָמְרִינַן מַתְנֶה עַל מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה תְּנָאוֹ בָּטֵל – כְּגוֹן שְׁאֵרָהּ כְּסוּתָהּ וְעוֹנָתָהּ, דְּהוּא קָא עָקַר; אֲבָל הָכָא – אִיהִי קָא עָקְרָה.
human_translation: Rav Adda son of Rav Ika said When we say stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah his condition is void, such as her food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, as he is uprooting But here, she is uprooting
llm_translation: Rav Adda, son of Rav Ika, said: When we say that a condition made regarding something written in the Torah is null and void - for example, her leftover food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, which he has uprooted; but here, she has uprooted it.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רָבִינָא: כְּלוּם קָא עָקְרָה אִיהִי – אֶלָּא לְקַיּוֹמֵי לִתְנַאי דִּידֵיהּ; אִישְׁתְּכַח דְּאִיהוּ קָא עָקַר!
human_translation: Ravina strongly objects to this Isn’t she uprooting only to fulfill his condition? found that he is uprooting
llm_translation: Ravina objects to her: Perhaps she uprooted it - rather, to fulfill the opinion of our Mishnaic authority; it is evident that he uprooted!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבִינָא: כִּי אָמְרִינַן מַתְנֶה עַל מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה תְּנָאוֹ בָּטֵל – כְּגוֹן שְׁאֵרָהּ כְּסוּתָהּ וְעוֹנָתָהּ, דְּוַדַּאי קָא עָקַר; אֲבָל הָכָא – מִי קָאָמַר לַהּ: לָא סַגִּיא דְּלָא אָכְלָה?! לָא תֵּיכוֹל, וְלָא תִּיגָּרַשׁ.
human_translation: Rather, Ravina said: When we say stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void, such as her food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, as he is definitely uprooting But here, is he saying to her not possible for her not to eat? She may not eat and not get divorced.
llm_translation: Rather, Ravina said: When we say that a gift given based on what is written in the Torah is nullified, for example, her leftover food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, it is certainly uprooted. But here, who is saying to her: "It is not excessive that you did not eat?!" She cannot, and she will not be divorced.

hebrew_text: כֵּיצַד יַעֲשֶׂה – יִטְּלֶנּוּ הֵימֶנָּה וְכוּ׳: מַאן תַּנָּא? אָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר הִיא.
human_translation: What should he do He should take it from her, Who taught Ḥizkiyya said it is Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.
llm_translation: "How should one do it? - He should take it from her and so on. Who is the Tanna? Chizkiyah said: It is Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar."

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: עַד שֶׁיִּטְּלֶנּוּ הֵימֶנָּה, וְיַחֲזוֹר וְיִתְּנֶנּוּ לָהּ, וְיֹאמַר לָהּ: ״הֵי גִּיטִּיךְ״.
human_translation: As it is taught Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says until he takes it from her, and hands it to her again, and says to her: This is your bill of divorce.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Until he places it in her hand, and then takes it back and gives it to her, and says to her: "Here is your bill of divorce."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי – דִּילְכוֹן אָמַר: שָׁאנֵי הָכָא, הוֹאִיל וְקִנְאָתוֹ לִיפָּסֵל בּוֹ לַכְּהוּנָּה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: You even say Rabbi Your said it is different here, since acquired to becoming disqualified into the priesthood due to it,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Even if you say "Rabbi," for here it is different, since his intention is to disqualify him from the priesthood.

hebrew_text: כְּתָבוֹ בְּתוֹכוֹ: אָמַר רַב סָפְרָא: ״כְּתָבוֹ בְּתוֹכוֹ״ תְּנַן.
human_translation: wrote inside Rav Safra said: We learned he wrote inside
llm_translation: He wrote within it: Rav Safra said, "He wrote within it," as we learned.

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא, ״כְּתָבוֹ בְּתוֹכוֹ״ תְּנַן! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי לְאַחַר הַתּוֹרֶף, אֲבָל לִפְנֵי הַתּוֹרֶף – אֲפִילּוּ עַל פֶּה נָמֵי פָּסוּל, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: is obvious we learned he wrote it inside. lest you say this matter applies after the essential but before the essential even orally, invalid, teaches us
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Peshita, 'k'tavo b'tokho' tenan! Mahu d'teima hanei milei l'achar hatoref, aval lifnei hatoref – afilu al peh namei pasul, ka mashma lan." English translation: "It is obvious, 'write it within it' we have learned! What might you say, these matters are after the burning, but before the burning – even if it is by word of mouth it is invalid, it is evident to us."

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא אָמַר: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא לְאַחַר הַתּוֹרֶף, אֲבָל לִפְנֵי הַתּוֹרֶף – אֲפִילּוּ עַל פֶּה נָמֵי פָּסוּל.
human_translation: And Rava said: They taught only after the essential But before the essential even orally, is invalid.
llm_translation: Rava said: They only stated this regarding after the Torah portion has been read, but before the Torah portion has been read - even if it is on the mouth of a mute, it is invalid.

hebrew_text: וְאַזְדָּא רָבָא לְטַעְמֵיהּ – דַּאֲמַר לְהוּ רָבָא לְהָנְהוּ דְּכָתְבִי גִּיטֵּי: שַׁתִּקוּ שַׁתּוֹקֵי לְבַעַל, עַד דְּכָתְבִיתוּ לֵיהּ לְתוֹרֶף דְּגִיטָּא.
human_translation: And Rava followed his reasoning, as Rava said to those who write bills of divorce: Silence husband until you write the essential of the bill of divorce,
llm_translation: And Rava went according to his reasoning - for Rava said to them: "Be silent, be silent, in the presence of the husband, until you write for him the divorce document."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: כׇּל הַתְּנָאִין פּוֹסְלִין בַּגֵּט, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: כֹּל שֶׁפּוֹסֵל עַל פֶּה פּוֹסֵל בִּכְתָב, וְכֹל שֶׁאֵינוֹ פּוֹסֵל עַל פֶּה אֵינוֹ פּוֹסֵל בִּכְתָב – ״חוּץ״, שֶׁפּוֹסֵל עַל פֶּה, פּוֹסֵל בִּכְתָב; ״עַל מְנָת״, שֶׁאֵינוֹ פּוֹסֵל עַל פֶּה, אֵינוֹ פּוֹסֵל בִּכְתָב.
human_translation: The Sages taught: All conditions in a bill of divorce invalidate the statement of Rabbi And the Rabbis say: Any that invalidates orally invalidates when written, and any that does not invalidate orally does not invalidate when written. except which invalidates orally, invalidates when written, condition, which does not invalidate orally, does not invalidate when written.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: All conditions invalidate a bill of divorce, according to Rabbi. And the Sages say: Anyone who invalidates orally invalidates in writing, and anyone who does not invalidate orally does not invalidate in writing - "except," one who invalidates orally, invalidates in writing; "on condition," one who does not invalidate orally, does not invalidate in writing.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: מַחְלוֹקֶת לִפְנֵי הַתּוֹרֶף – דְּרַבִּי סָבַר: גָּזְרִינַן ״עַל מְנָת״ אַטּוּ ״חוּץ״; וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: לָא גָּזְרִינַן ״עַל מְנָת״ אַטּוּ ״חוּץ״. אֲבָל לְאַחַר הַתּוֹרֶף –
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: dispute before the essential as Rabbi holds we issue a decree a stipulation due to an exception, and the Rabbis hold we do not issue a decree a stipulation due to an exception. But after the essential
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: A dispute before the Torah - Rabbi holds: We decree "on condition" inside "except"; and the Rabbis hold: We do not decree "on condition" inside "except." But after the Torah -

hebrew_text: דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל כָּשֵׁר. וּמַתְנִיתִין, דְּקָתָנֵי ״כְּתָבוֹ״ וְאוֹקִימְנָא בְּ״חוּץ״; אֲבָל ״עַל מְנָת״ לָא פָּסֵיל – אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לִפְנֵי הַתּוֹרֶף, וְרַבָּנַן; וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לְאַחַר הַתּוֹרֶף, וְדִבְרֵי הַכֹּל.
human_translation: everyone agrees is valid. And the mishna, which teaches he wrote and we established to an exception, but a condition does not render invalid, if you wish, say before the essential and the Rabbis. And if you wish, say after the essential and everyone, agrees
llm_translation: Words of everyone valid. And Mishna, as it teaches "his writing" and we establish it as "outside"; but "on condition" is not invalid - if you wish, say: before the Torah, and the Rabbis; and if you wish, say: after the Torah, and words of everyone.

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא אָמַר: מַחְלוֹקֶת לְאַחַר הַתּוֹרֶף – דְּרַבִּי סָבַר: גָּזְרִינַן אַטּוּ לִפְנֵי הַתּוֹרֶף; וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: לָא גָּזְרִינַן אַטּוּ לִפְנֵי הַתּוֹרֶף. אֲבָל לִפְנֵי הַתּוֹרֶף – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל פָּסוּל.
human_translation: And Rava said: dispute is after the essential as Rabbi holds we issue a decree due to before the essential and the Rabbis hold we do not issue a decree due to before the essential But before the essential everyone agrees is invalid.
llm_translation: Rava said: A dispute regarding after the slaughter - for Rabbi holds: we decree after the slaughter; and the Rabbis hold: we do not decree after the slaughter. But before the slaughter - the words of everyone are invalid.

hebrew_text: וּמַתְנִיתִין, דְּקָתָנֵי ״כְּתָבוֹ״ וְאוֹקִימְנָא בְּ״חוּץ״; אֲבָל ״עַל מְנָת״ לָא פָּסֵיל – אַחַר הַתּוֹרֶף, וְרַבָּנַן הִיא.
human_translation: And the mishna, which teaches he wrote and we established to an exception, but a condition does not render invalid, after the essential and it is the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Mishnah, as it is taught: "In writing" and we establish it "outside"; but "on condition" is not disqualified - after the burning, and it is the view of the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי אֲבוּהּ דְּרַבִּי אָבִין קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי זֵירָא: כָּתַב גֵּט עַל תְּנַאי – דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל פָּסוּל. דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל פָּסוּל?! וְהָא מִיפְלָג פְּלִיגִי!
human_translation: The father of Rabbi Avin taught before Rabbi Zeira: wrote a conditional bill of divorce, everyone agrees is invalid. Everyone agrees is invalid? But don’t they disagree
llm_translation: The father of Rabbi Avin taught before Rabbi Zeira: If one writes a bill of divorce conditionally - the words of everyone are invalid. The words of everyone are invalid?! But they disagree with each other!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אֵימָא: לְדִבְרֵי הַכֹּל כָּשֵׁר, וְהֵיכִי דָּמֵי – לְאַחַר הַתּוֹרֶף.
human_translation: Rather, say everyone agrees is valid. And what are the circumstances after the essential
llm_translation: Rather say: According to everyone it is valid, and how so? - After the fact of the injury.

hebrew_text: וְלֵימָא: הֲרֵי זֶה פָּסוּל – וְרַבִּי! תַּנָּא ״דִּבְרֵי הַכֹּל״ אַתְנְיֵיהּ; ״כָּשֵׁר״ בְּ״פָסוּל״ מִיחַלַּף לֵיהּ, ״הֲרֵי זֶה״ בְּ״דִבְרֵי הַכֹּל״ לָא מִיחַלַּף לֵיהּ.
human_translation: Let say It is invalid, and Rabbi The tanna taught him everyone agrees, he may confuse valid with invalid, he does not confuse It is, with Everyone agrees.
llm_translation: And say: Behold, this is disqualified - and Rabbi! A Tanna taught: "The words of everyone" he teaches it; "kosher" in "disqualified" he exchanges it, "this" in "the words of everyone" he does not exchange it.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם – אֶלָּא לְאַבָּא״; וּ״לְאָבִיךְ״; ״לְאָחִי״; וּ״לְאָחִיךְ״; לְעֶבֶד; וּלְנׇכְרִי; וּלְכׇל מִי שֶׁאֵין לָהּ עָלָיו קִדּוּשִׁין – כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: You are hereby permitted to any man, except to my father or to your father, to my brother or to your brother, to a slave or to a gentile, or to anyone she cannot betrothed, is valid.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "Behold, you are permitted to marry any man - except for your father"; and "for your father"; "for your brother"; and "for your brother"; for a slave; and for a non-Jew; and for anyone upon whom she does not have sanctity - it is valid.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מוּתֶּרֶת לְכׇל אָדָם״ – אֶלָּא אַלְמָנָה לְכֹהֵן גָּדוֹל; גְּרוּשָׁה וַחֲלוּצָה לְכֹהֵן הֶדְיוֹט; מַמְזֶרֶת וּנְתִינָה לְיִשְׂרָאֵל; בַּת יִשְׂרָאֵל לְמַמְזֵר וּלְנָתִין; וְכׇל מִי שֶׁיֵּשׁ לָהּ עָלָיו קִדּוּשִׁין, אֲפִילּוּ בַּעֲבֵירָה – פָּסוּל.
human_translation: You are hereby permitted to any man, except a widow to a High Priest; a divorcée or a yevama who performed ḥalitza [ ḥalutza ] to a common priest; a mamzeret or a Gibeonite woman to an Israelite an Israelite woman to a mamzer or to a Gibeonite or anyone she can betrothed, even a transgression, is invalid.
llm_translation: "Behold, you are permitted to all men" - rather, a widow to a High Priest; a divorcee and a halutzah to an ordinary priest; a mamzeret and a natin to an Israelite; a daughter of Israel to a mamzer and to a natin; and any woman who has sanctity upon her, even through transgression, is disqualified.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ כְּלָלָא דְּרֵישָׁא – לְאֵתוֹיֵי שְׁאָר חַיָּיבֵי כָרֵיתוֹת. כְּלָלָא דְּסֵיפָא – לְאֵתוֹיֵי שְׁאָר חַיָּיבֵי לָאוִין, כְּגוֹן עַמּוֹנִי וּמוֹאָבִי (נְתִינִי, מִצְרִי וַאֲדוֹמִי).
human_translation: the generalization in the first clause to include the rest of those liable karet the generalization in the last clause to include the rest of those liable by a prohibition such as an Ammonite and a Moabite, a Gibeonite, an Egyptian, and an Edomite
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara k'lala d'reishah - l'etoyei she'ar chayavei kareitot. K'lala d'seifa - l'etoyei she'ar chayavei lavin, k'gon Ammoni u'Moavi (Netini, Mitzri va'Edomi). English translation: The general principle of the first part - to include other transgressors liable to karet. The general principle of the latter part - to include other transgressors not liable, such as an Ammonite, a Moabite (a Netin, an Egyptian, and an Edomite).

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבָא מֵרַב נַחְמָן: חוּץ מִקִּדּוּשֵׁי קָטָן, מַהוּ? מִי אָמְרִינַן הַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא לָאו בַּר הֲוָיָה הוּא, אוֹ דִלְמָא אָתֵי לִכְלַל הֲוָיָה?
human_translation: Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman: except for a betrothal to a minor boy what is Do we say now, he is in any event not eligible for betrothal, Or perhaps, he will reach betrothal,
llm_translation: Rava asked a question from Rav Nachman: Except for the sanctification of a minor, what is the law? Do we say that now it is not a valid act, or perhaps it will come to be included as valid?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ, תְּנֵיתוּהָ: קְטַנָּה מִתְגָּרֶשֶׁת בְּקִידּוּשֵׁי אָבִיהָ.
human_translation: said to him: You learned A minor girl can get divorced through her father’s betrothal,
llm_translation: He said to him, "Give it to her: a minor becomes divorced through the betrothal of her father."

hebrew_text: אַמַּאי? וְהָא בָּעֵינַן: ״וְיָצְאָה״–״וְהָיְתָה״? אֶלָּא אָתְיָא לִכְלַל הֲוָיָה; הָכָא נָמֵי – אָתְיָא לִכְלַל הֲוָיָה.
human_translation: Why But don’t we need “And she departs,” “And becomes” Rather, she will reach betrothal Here also, will reach betrothal,
llm_translation: אַמַּאי? - Why? וְהָא בָּעֵינַן: "וְיָצְאָה" - "and she shall go out"? ״וְהָיְתָה״ - "and she shall be"? אֶלָּא - Rather, אָתְיָא - it comes לִכְלַל - to include הֲוָיָה - existence; הָכָא - here too נָמֵי - also אָתְיָא - it comes לִכְלַל - to include הֲוָיָה - existence.

hebrew_text: ״חוּץ מִן הַנּוֹלָדִים״, מַהוּ? הַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא לָא אִיתְיְלִיד[וּ], אוֹ דִּלְמָא עֲתִידִי דְּמִתְיַילְדִי?
human_translation: except for those who will be born what is now, in any event they are not yet born, Or perhaps they will be born in the future.
